I've played a bunch, and I really actually do enjoy the game!
That said, I cant really recommend it right now...
Everyone says "Oh this is a PvP game", and AGS forces you to do PvP for a lot of different things, but when you then dont play amazing at it, or run a build you enjoy but isnt on meta, the community is honestly just toxic. And those same people are the ones that will tell you "why do you want to pve, this is a pvp game".
Like, if you want people to play pvp you kind of have to be okay with people who arent perfect at it being in your 3v3 arena, because AGS put it on the season bingo card, and sometimes you cant get around it if you want to be able to complete it.
Either this is a PvP game, and the community needs to become more inclusive of new players, or it isnt, and AGS needs to stop forcing people who dont really care about PvP but like PvE and the world to do content they dont like.
You cant have it both ways, I dont think.

Beautiful but Broken: A Stunning MMO Undone by Its Own Systems

At first glance, this game is breathtaking. The visual quality is top-tier ‚Äì environments are richly detailed, and I have to give special praise to the dungeon design. The atmosphere, lighting, and visual storytelling in those areas truly blew me away while exploring the game for the first time. It felt like there was something magical here ‚Äì something worth investing time in.

And yet, as I reached the later stages of the game, that initial wonder began to fade. What replaced it was something much less enchanting: a system built around grind, RNG, and what feels like a casino-inspired loot loop.

Inventory Hell
Let‚Äôs start with the biggest flaw: the inventory system. It's a mess. You spend an absurd amount of time just sorting through endless piles of junk ‚Äì useless armor, weapons, and trinkets that serve no purpose. There's no satisfying way to sell or discard them. It‚Äôs not just clutter; it actively kills momentum and enjoyment. In WoW, even bad loot had a reason to exist. Here, it‚Äôs just digital garbage.

Combat and Progression
The combat is actually good ‚Äì smooth, responsive, and enjoyable. But the progression is bizarrely lopsided. Leveling is way too fast and easy, while gathering professions like mining become a painful, drawn-out grind. It feels like two separate games ‚Äì one rushing you forward, the other dragging you back.

Disconnected World, Shallow Exploration
Despite the beautiful locations, the world feels oddly disconnected. There's no meaningful interaction with the environment, no real sense of presence. You don‚Äôt need to explore, and once you've seen an area, there‚Äôs little reason to return. The world is too small, too static. New zones should be arriving yearly, along with a steady flow of new dungeons and raids ‚Äì not just recycled ones with increased difficulty.

From Immersion to Slot Machines
This is where the real disappointment hits. The game slowly shifts from immersive MMO to something that feels designed around loot crate addiction. The gameplay ends up revolving around opening boxes, hoping for a lucky drop ‚Äì like a slot machine in a 24/7 convenience store. That kind of design breaks the fantasy, breaks the immersion, and ultimately breaks the game.

Economy in Chaos
The auction house is another weak link. Because of the nonsensical item system, prices are wildly inconsistent. It‚Äôs difficult to judge value, and trading becomes more frustrating than rewarding. It‚Äôs a symptom of the game‚Äôs deeper design issues.

Bright Spots Still Exist
To be fair, there are elements worth celebrating. The voice-acted NPC dialogue during story quests is a huge plus. Hearing characters speak adds a layer of immersion and personality that plain text just can‚Äôt deliver ‚Äì and it genuinely made me care more about the main story, at least at first. More MMOs should do this.

World bosses and live events also shine ‚Äì for brief moments, you feel part of a living, breathing community. And the musical instruments and group performances? Pure genius. These systems are fun, original, and show a glimpse of the game‚Äôs untapped potential.

Conclusion: A Lost Opportunity
This game could have been one of the greats. It had the budget, the engine, the setting. For a while, it looked like it might truly rival the giants of the genre. But over time, poor design choices, inventory frustration, and a shift toward ‚Äúcasino-style‚Äù systems have dragged it down.

It‚Äôs beautiful, but broken. A haunting reminder of how potential means nothing without vision.

Base game is ok but not my cup of tea after 30ish hours (never gonna click with every game). However, recently a dear friend of mine (who loves the game) told me about the seasonal server. 

Sounded cool so I installed, choose the seasonal server, created a character and enter the world...intro cut scene begins, I hold escape to skip and boom, back to start up screen. Choose my new character, enter the world, intro cut scene begins but this time I wait for the prompt in the bottom corner to tell me to "Hold ESC to Skip).

Bad idea, back to start up screen. "No biggie" I think, choose my character and login knowing I must sit through the intro scene I have watched 15-20 times in previous attempts to find the fun over the last couple years. Cut scene finishes, my character loads in and.....this is when I am told "Your Character is Locked" and to go pound sand until I buy the X-Pac.

Easy decision at this point, uninstalled and a thumbs down from me (pretty sure this is not how you bring players back).

Why not just tell us before we create the character? I would have still uninstalled but no way the negative review would have even entered my mind..

As a traditional fantasy MMORPG format, this is one of the newest and by far the best iterations of that genre. This game has one of the best combat systems ever put in an MMORPG, BY FAR. With active, split second dodging, real hit-boxes where you can jump over and duck under projectiles and swings actually miss if they don't physically touch you. I believe there are character collisions as well, IIRC. All projectiles have to actually be aimed, which adds a HUGELY immersive element to large raids or the fortress defense activity things. For instance, as an archer, you are actually aiming the arrows slightly upward to compensate for gravity's pull, so the arrows fall into the mob of melee fighting going on ahead of you between the enemy NPC melee and your own RAID group. Combat is fast paced, and positioning matters greatly, ESPECIALLY when using a weapon like rapier. Every fraction of a second matters because some of your abilities effectively teleport behind the enemy, but doesn't stun for like 3 seconds like in WOW. You are just using your abilities and positioning to actually physically dodge the enemies attacks. Not getting hit no matter what, and hoping it rolls well, again, like in traditional MMORPGs. The combat in this is much faster paced and way more movement, positioning, and timing involved because you actually have to 'HIT' the enemy, and they you.

The class system is great; you can effectively level every class on one character if you choose, and the same goes for crafting/skills type leveling. 

The music system is bar-none the absolute best. The game practically has Guitar Hero (without the guitar controls, so step mania?) or Rockband just built into the game as a skill to level and progress. And you can do it with your other party members or whomever, and each person plays a different instrument and part of the song.. for like 100s of songs, IIRC.

The builds system is unique and very customizable. Each weapon has a major and minor stat that contributes to it. And you can equip two weapon types to switch between. So, I.E. speccing with high dexterity helps you as a 'major' stat for both bow and spear. But, it also helps by contributing half points to things like Hatchet and Two handed sword as a 'Minor' stat. combine this with magic type weapons, and a talent tree style system, and you get the picture. 

Sorry if some of it is vague, a lot is coming from memory. But I am actually reinstalling the game right now.

One tip: Check the server populations online before you make your character. Currently, in the US, Us West servers are virtually empty compared to the healthy population on Us East. XD

Anyways, if you're looking for a traditional(ish) fantasy MMORPG with great combat and leveling and skills system.... New World is actually my 10/10 favorite.

So far, I don't really understand the hate with this game. Most of the expansion definitely should of been apart of base game but, that's a review of the expansion not the base game. 

Good----
1. Story lines are good shoot most of the side quests are pretty fun too. 
2. You feel strong with good gear and eventually as you level you start weakening out and need to get new stuff which feels balanced and fair. 
3. The zones blend pretty smooth and there's more variety of mobs compared to New World when it was released.
4. The faction system really encourages you to get into pvp BUT it doesn't feel shoved down your throat
5. Buy it once, no monthly sub, no P2W that I've noticed

Bad---
1. Sometimes there's some (minor) connectivity issues.
2. Every time I see someone on a mount I get miffed that in order to ride one (something every other MMO has base game) I need to pay another $30 for
3. While the game is a buy once, play forever style it's frustrating that for things like transmog and other basic stuff they charge for it. The main problem here I think is it costs way too much for something like that. I want my character to look cool but damn if it's going to cost that much I'd rather pay a sub and have it thrown in for free.
4. The setting camp feature is a really neat feature but it's a pita to find one nearby to use.

Overall, 7/10

Very fun action combat PvP MMORPG. Loved the open world skirmishes, wars, OPR, 3v3s. Blunderbuss and firestaff are a lot of fun. Gathering is also some of the best in any MMO game. Chopping down trees is so satisfying. The transmog feature addition is also very good, along with the projectile bullet change. Many good changes over the years. Not a big fan of their focus on pumping out boring dungeons, or the PvE in OPR, their Junkyard engine, all the bugs, the massive amount of gold going to territory company owners (although the horizontal gear progression made this less of an issue), and imbalance with bows/muskets. There's a large focus on PvE when it's not that great; very little focus on open world PvP, wars, 3v3s, and OPR which is where this game shines. Devs seem to listen to their players but the shift in focus away from NW at AGS hurt the PC playerbase (especially after the Aeternum console update). Also I think the corruption portals should be more similar to those seen in the game Oblivion! Stopped playing after the game rename patch. Mainly played BB/FS, BB/Hatchet, GS/Hatchet. I think adding friendly fire would be interesting, just to see how it would change the meta for wars.

After Guild Wars 2, this is the best MMO for a solo player. Great graphics and excellent optimization. Combat is very satisfying, and hitboxes work perfectly, which makes every fight feel smooth and rewarding. Crafting is also very satisfying. This game doesn‚Äôt really have any major downsides if you‚Äôre a casual player and not even looking for an MMO, but rather a good RPG.

What I appreciate most is the lack of ‚ÄúAsian-style‚Äù influences. Maybe the side quests aren‚Äôt too ambitious, but the overall atmosphere of the game is fantastic.

Another big plus is the absence of aggressive microtransactions (even though they do exist). Still, having to pay for a mount as part of a DLC feels a bit over the top. But you can‚Äôt have everything. After around 50 hours, I did get a bit bored, but maybe that‚Äôs just because I play solo :) Either way, I highly recommend it.

Any downsides? Maybe the world is a bit small.
I‚Äôm eagerly waiting for the second part.

TLDR: Fun earlygame but even before reaching the end of Main Story line it becomes very repetitive and boring. Needs more variety when it comes to combat and content.

Story is decent, although has a few dips here and there (IMO first big bad introduction as corrupting cunning force was pretty weak, she seemed like a 100% villain with taunts rather than making valid points). Sidequests range from normal to a bit weird, but almost all are voiced. They do lack variety though, there aren't really any proper puzzles or custom mechanics tied to quests like in some other MMOs.

The world is pretty but looting broken houses for absolutely the same materials gets quite repetitive very fast. The game really would benefits from metas and dynamic world events that some other MMOs have.

Combat is a mixed experience. From one point of view it's very responsive. From another it's just switching between 2 weapons with 3 active skills of out 6 toal + very minor skill customization. Oh and also +1 skill from heartrune. It lacks depth, variety. Feels spammy and by the time I reached Elysian Wilds I got bored with it, even though I started switching ranged weapon between bow and firestaff.
On top of that DPS builds are too squishy. It's not fun when enemy sneezes at you and you lose 50% hp or straight up get oneshot.
Blocking is very hard because of visual spam, it's just impossible to see when enemies attack. And there is no option to turn down/hide ally skill effects, so if you're part of 20-man raid, the screen is a multicolored vomit.

I didn't quite get into endgame content aside from trying some open world elite chest runs and M1 expeditions, but it seems that endgame is mostly raid and mutated expedition grind. There aren't many mutated expeditions and once again they get repetitive fast, while giving barely any useful rewards.

Gearing could be done better. You loot various named upgradeable gear pieces with 600+ GS but in reality when it comes to PvE gear, everyone is running the same 3 perks, because they're strictly better for survivability. At the end of the day, you salvage 99% of gear you loot.

New World was one of the first MMOs I truly got into‚Äîand for a while, I loved it.
The launch was exciting, the world was beautiful, and the gameplay loop was fresh. For those first few weeks, it really felt like something special. Everyone seemed to be having a great time.

But over time, the magic faded. Player numbers dropped, and the updates felt either too minor or too slow to make a difference. It‚Äôs hard to pinpoint exactly where things went wrong‚Äîbut something definitely did.

Now with Aeternum, it feels more like an attempt to revive something that had so much potential but was never fully realized. I really wanted this to be a long-term MMO home for me. Sadly, it just didn‚Äôt stick.

This was the game that was going to change the MMO/RPG scene. Unfortunately like most developers they promise gold and give you turd. 

The foundation of the game was promising, the world looked stunning, the quests where okay to grind, the grind wasn't to quick or to long, the classes, weapons, and armour where good but it quickly shown you had no idea what you was doing . 

The first problem was not enough worlds on servers. You had friend groups who were on all different worlds and servers because they was that full they couldn't get in together. They promised that once more worlds were available you could switch worlds and SERVERS to join friends and told us to keep grinding . We had a friend group of about ten that was all split up and I think half left the game soon as it was announced we couldn't change to be with our friends . 

The ones who kept playing enjoyed the game (despite some of us having to start back at level 0) all the way up to the point of end game. Full story and quests done. The raids were fun but only so much you can do over and over again . 

The main problem was the PVP. Iv always said that for a game to survive long term there has to be a good and fair PvP system for all players, once the main PvE story is done and completed hundreds of raids what then? It's check out PvP or go play a different game.

Now the PvP combat was fun and so was the PvP events but the problem they had was the Territory wars for settlements.
Now settlements gave clans massive bonuses and incomes of gold if they held them so was really important but only the biggest and top clans could compete for these settlements leaving smaller clans having no look in. So the only option to be apart of these wars was to join a big clan right? Wrong, even if you join a clan the leader selects who he wants to fight in the wars so you never get a look in because he picks all his mates and sweats. 

Why not make smaller settlements to be took over that can only be took over by clans with 10 or less people ? Or 20 ? Everyone can have a good PvP experience and enjoy the wars

o Le syst√®me de qu√™te et de leveling sont vraiment bien adapt√© pour les profils casuals comme moi. On peut atteindre le level max (65) sans groupe, tout peut √™tre fait en solo, m√™me si certains bosses sont compliqu√©s.
o Le stuffing en terme de scaling est bon aussi. On re√ßoit des items qui nous permettent largement de matcher les d√©g√¢ts des monstres lorsqu'on √©volue de zone au cours de la qu√™te principale.
o Le syst√®me d'arme est vraiment styl√©. Pas de classe, que des armes qui donnent des comp√©tences et qui permettent d'adopter un style diff√©rent d'une arme √† une autre sans changer de personnage, ce qui est tr√®s agr√©able.

Points neutres :
o Les m√©tiers sont biens pens√©s, mais le leveling pour certains est tellement long et lent que lorsqu'on passe √† c√¥t√© de certaines ressources et qu'on ne peut pas les prendre, c'est frustrant mais je trouve que pour le endgame c'est cool.
o Les qu√™tes annexes sont biens mais sur le d√©but de jeu, √ßa n'exp rien par rapport √† la qu√™te principale ce qui est dommage pour les gens qui aiment faire les qu√™tes annexes avant la principale. Le ration : b√©n√©fice/temps investi n'est pas rentable sur l'early et c'est dommage

Point n√©gatifs :
o Le fait d'acheter le jeu √† 60‚Ç¨, je trouve qu'il les vaut, cependant, les micro-transactions pour les cosm√©tiques et surtout pour les jetons transmog pour avoir l'apparence d'√©quipement... Bon √ßa c'est pas ouf. Si vous voulez avoir un beau perso harmonieux, faut compter rajouter 50-60‚Ç¨ facile.
o L'apr√®s-leveling 65 : La transition est pas tr√®s fluide parce qu'il n'y a pas de point de rep√®re pour optimiser son stuffing ou de te faire comprendre o√π aller pour t'optimiser et devenir meilleur pour peut √™tre passer sur du JcJ ou du contenu very endgame qui requi√®re de l'optimisation maximal.
o  Les exp√©ditions (Les donjons) : Je suis sur le monde Ari√®s et pour trouver une exp√©dition facilement en normal, il faut vraiment se lever t√¥t. Le jeu n'est pas mort, mais compliqu√© de trouver si vous n'√™tes pas dans une faction ou une "guilde"/communaut√©.
o Certains bugs un peu relou comme l'apparition de mobs sans barre de vie (donc immortel) qui te lache des moins 500 au level 35, pas ouf ouf.

Conclusion :
Le jeu est cool et je pense vraiment que c'est un tr√®s bon jeu. J'ai fait 42h de jeu en 5 jours, ce qui est vraiment pas mal, j'y ai accroch√© au vu de mon profil de joueur de MMO RPG. Je pense que si vous √™tes un hardcore des MMO type Wow, etc. et un gros gros consommateur de contenu very endgame PvE, je ne sais pas si ce jeu s'adresse √† vous. Mais si vous √™tes comme moi un casu qui aime bien jouer de mani√®re chill et juste passer du bon temps en jouant, le jeu est √† mon sens adress√© pour vous.

The thing is, I saw some new vids on youtube and was like hell yeah let me revisit New World, you know, Amazon's flagship MMORPG, or as I like to call it, Jeff Bezos‚Äô $500 million Minecraft server for bored spreadsheet enjoyers. If this game is the future of gaming, then grab your loincloth and stone tools, because we‚Äôre going back to the Dark Ages. Not the fun, sword-swinging Dark Ages the ones with lice, mud, and dysentery.

This game is less ‚ÄúNew World‚Äù and more like ‚ÄúExpired Product Left in Bezos‚Äô Garage Since 2018.‚Äù You log in, greeted by a loading screen (on my new killer rig with suck yo dack nvmes and shit) that lasts longer than Amazon‚Äôs commitment to workers‚Äô rights, and enter a world where every single player is either a tree-chopping automaton or a shirtless gremlin spawn-camping a wolf den for crafting mats. You‚Äôre not building a fantasy empire you‚Äôre doing unpaid labor in a digital Amazon warehouse.

Fighting is is a mix of circle jerk and pray with all the satisfying impact of hitting a wiffle ball with a wet sock. Somehow, despite this being 2025, swordfighting feels like two mannequins slap-fighting  in a 2004 Dr. Who episode.   PVP boils down to what I call... the dance.   Moving on.
The story, which is like someone asked ChatGPT to write a fantasy plot but trained it exclusively on Amazon Prime TV scripts. You‚Äôve got your usual ‚Äúancient evil,‚Äù ‚Äúcorrupted magic,‚Äù and ‚Äúyou are the chosen one‚Äù tropes, but written with all the depth of a Jeff Bezos LinkedIn post. The voice acting is a buffet of accents nobody asked for. One guy sounds like a Narubian pirate that has never seen the ocean, another like he‚Äôs doing a low-budget Bridgerton audition on syrup. I half-expected someone to say, ‚ÄúBy the light of the Amazon Algorithm, Bezo's protects!‚Äù

Oh yeah the algorithms, i mean... auction house.  The game‚Äôs economy is a lawless stock market simulator run by dupe fiends who majored in meme coins. Inflation runs wild. A stick costs more than your first car. Gold farming is more lucrative than your actual job. Crafting is a Kafkaesque nightmare requiring 900 bear pelts, three star-metal penile implants, and the blood of Bezos himself to make a Level 3 chair.

The true glory here though, what really makes New World special is its glorious commitment to soulless bloat. Everything takes forever. Walk for 15 minutes, fight a boar, get 2 XP, repeat until you are dead inside. Bruh, I have played F2P Korean MMOs with more forgiving grinds.

This game has a horrible endgame loop and feels like it was developed by a team that has been clueless from the start. It‚Äôs hard to tell if the game is supposed to be pvp or pve focused, because both aspects are poorly executed. Other games do each of these far better, so I‚Äôm left wondering: why should I even bother with this one?

The only real positive is the graphics, but even that is inconsistent. The environments look great, but the character models are ugly and feel out of place, like they were made by a completely different team. It‚Äôs a jarring mismatch that breaks immersion.

Combat is passable. It feels okay for an action-based MMO, but nothing more. Definitely not a standout feature.

To make matters worse, the game is full of bugs. Features often don‚Äôt work as intended. Want to try the new event quest? Too bad‚Äîyour chest chain might bug out, and there‚Äôs no fix. This happened to me at least twice, and it's incredibly frustrating.

Overall, this game is a mess. Between the broken systems, unfocused design, and endless technical issues, it‚Äôs hard to find a reason to recommend it.

10/10 game New World gives you a continent and says, ‚ÄúGood luck.‚Äù

Best parts; 

{1} Open World Exploration and the world building is 10/10. Each biome is unique in quests, animals, enemies, houses, people and the culture. For Example, Brimstone sands is a massive desert territory with scorpions, coyotes, lions, ect. The Brimstone quests all focus on Ancient Egyptian and Roman mythology and lore. If youre not interested in that, here are some other long questlines built around other mythologies and legends; 
Greek Mythology: Greek mythology can be found within the game's lore. including a boss fight with Medusa.
Viking/Norse Mythology: There are Norsemen characters, such as the Rus' Varangians led by Warlord Varik, who play a role in the island's story, connecting to legendary figures.
Arthurian Legends: King Artorius (King Arthur) and the Knights of the Round Table are featured in the lore, adding elements of British and Arthurian mythology. The amount of effort put into making each region feel unique makes this a game you could easily spend hundreds of hours in without even touching PvP or grinding.

{2} Combat in New World: Aeternum is one of the best in the MMO genre. It's fluid, responsive, and actually skill-based a huge breath of fresh air compared to the usual tab-targeting systems in other MMOs. You have to dodge, aim, block, and time your attacks, which gives every fight a more action RPG feel. Whether you‚Äôre swinging a greatsword, firing a musket, or casting void magic, every weapon feels weighty and distinct. It feels like playing an action RPG in a MMORPG setting. There is also a lot of variety with the weapon choices and skills so you can play any way you want. 

{3} PVE PVE PVE PVE I lowkey hated pvp in any MMO before new world and other MMOs put more effort into PVP then unique enemies. enemies in Mew World behave differently depending on faction undead enemies fight very differently than corrupted knights or ancient constructs. Boss fights often require real strategy and positioning, especially in expeditions (dungeons) or elite zones. And in PvP? The combat system makes 1v1s and group battles feel intense, fast-paced, and fair (as long as your build isn‚Äôt completely busted, anyway) but PVP is fun asf and not forced theres a Free For All zone with dabloons you collect if you die you lose them, if you get out you keep them. FFA is fun, Outpost Rush is super fun and they added a new map for it. PVE content is amazing theres tons of expeditions, dungeons, elite raids Weekly invasions which are fucking amazing 20 people in a discord VC with someone giving everyone directions on where to go. there is a daily refresh for soul trials so you can do daily solo boss fights for unique rewards. and WEEKLY rotation for Mutated dungeons, and massive world events like Myrk, Siren, Well, and World Tours. 


{4}The trade skills in New World: Aeternum are a full game on their own. This isn‚Äôt your typical MMO crafting where you just click ‚Äúcraft‚Äù and walk away. Every profession from gathering to refining to crafting has real depth and impact on your character and the game world. There are 17 different trade skills split across gathering, refining, and crafting, and each one has its own leveling path, perks, and unique gameplay loops.
Gathering includes mining, logging, harvesting, skinning, and fishing. Each resource node is placed in the open world, and they don‚Äôt just sit in plain sight.
Refining lets you process those raw materials into usable components like turning iron into steel or rawhide into rugged leather. These aren‚Äôt throwaway skills either; mastering refining improves efficiency and quality, unlocking rare materials and bonuses.
Crafting is where it all comes together. Whether you're making gear (weapons, armor), consumables (potions, food), or furniture for housing, crafting in New World feels rewarding. There‚Äôs a ton of customization, with stats, perks, and even luck modifiers influencing the quality of what you make.
There is also a skill called Music which is what made me get the game originally. Many different instruments to play and tons of songs to play that give buffs to your group. Player Economy, Goated Af this one goes hand in hand with trade skills, anything you craft or even powerful loot you find in a dungeon can be sold on the market or traded between players for Gold or Other items, makes the world feel soooo alive and I truly love this feature.

{5} Fashion in this game is great there is an amazing transmog system and Ive spent hours making new outfits. Any armor you pick up saves that style as a transmogable piece to any armor youre wearing, are you wearing light armor but wanna look like youre in full plate armor to bamboozle players in PvP? easy and you can get transmog tokens in the battle pass or just buy them. 

Theres much more I could say but I'll leave it at this; There‚Äôs much more I could say, but I‚Äôll leave it at this: New World: Aeternum is one of the most underrated MMOs out there right now and it deserves your time.

I came back to the game after a few years. I bought the DLC because I figured a lot had changed and it was worth playing again. A new season has started, and a hardcore server is about to launch in the coming days. It‚Äôs a good time to give it a try. There‚Äôs a season pass with an option to buy premium access. That‚Äôs fine‚Äîmany games have something like that. The free rewards are decent too. There‚Äôs a new storyline, modified areas, and added mechanics. I got really into it while playing on a fresh start server. There are lots of players. Finally, the HC seasonal server is launching‚Ä¶ Everything looks great. I really like the accelerated leveling and item acquisition system.

Hardcore mode means that if your character dies, you can still keep playing, but you lose the ability to earn the seasonal reward given only to those who survive. That‚Äôs awesome‚Äîa real challenge, and a very difficult one at that.

If your character dies, you still have a chance to earn a different reward, but you have to focus on PvP and defeat players who haven‚Äôt died even once. To help with this, you get bonus stats after each death, making the task a bit easier. It‚Äôs an interesting and very engaging system that encourages open-world PvP.

And here‚Äôs where my enthusiasm ends. Even though I paid a lot of money for the game, in order to unlock rewards from the main seasonal system, I have to buy the premium pass. Without it, there‚Äôs no point in even trying to avoid death, because it won‚Äôt get you anything. I‚Äôm simply excluded from the fun. It‚Äôs a low blow and a moral downfall for the game‚Äôs developers.

I really tried to give New World: Aeternum a fair shot, but it‚Äôs just not worth it.

This game is not new-player friendly at all. From the moment you step into Aeternum, you're met with confusing systems, poor onboarding, and a community that seems more interested in flaming newbies than helping them. There's no guidance, no welcoming atmosphere‚Äîjust a constant uphill battle to understand the basics while getting mocked in chat.

The overall vibe is toxic. Whether it‚Äôs in global chat, PvP zones, or even some group content, people are constantly rude, dismissive, or flat-out aggressive. It feels like if you didn‚Äôt play since launch day, you‚Äôre already the enemy.

Visually, the game looks great, and the combat can be fun at times‚Äîbut none of that matters if the experience makes you feel unwelcome and frustrated.

If you're looking for a game to enjoy casually or as a newcomer, this is NOT it.

üí¨ "Come for the views, stay for the wars."

After almost 100 hours in Aeternum, here‚Äôs my honest take:

üëç What I Liked:

    Stunning visuals. The world is gorgeous. Forests, ruins, sunsets‚Äîthis game is pure eye candy.

    Combat feels great. No tab-targeting here‚Äîevery dodge, block, and swing matters. Very action-oriented.

    Territory wars & PvP. Join a faction, fight for land, and actually influence the game world. Super addictive.

    Crafting is satisfying. You can literally make a living off crafting and gathering. Everything you do matters.

    Exploration is rewarding. Secret spots, rare resources, cool lore‚Äîit's easy to get lost (in a good way).

ü§î What Could Be Better:

    Some bugs and balance issues, though they‚Äôve been improving with regular updates.

    PvE content is a bit repetitive early on, but endgame expeditions and seasonal content help a lot.

üî• Final Verdict:

If you enjoy immersive worlds, skill-based combat, and building your own story in an ever-changing sandbox, New World is worth diving into. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it‚Äôs growing into something really special.

‚úÖ Recommended

Dear New World Support Team,

I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to respectfully appeal the recent permanent ban on my Aeternum account,
which was issued due to an alleged use of a known cheat program. I take both the integrity of my gameplay and the health of the Aeternum community very seriously,
and I can assure you that I have never installed, run, or otherwise used any third-party software to gain an unfair advantage.

On the day I received the ban notification 2025/5/29,
I was actively engaged in completing the main story quests and exploring New World as I have faithfully done for over 1,700 hours of gameplay.
My commitment to the game and its community has always been to play honestly and respectfully,
and I would never take actions that could damage my account or harm other players‚Äô experiences. The sudden ban for my second character was therefore both surprising and distressing,
as I have invested significant time and passion into this world.

I kindly request that you review my case and the relevant log files to verify the absence of any unauthorized software on my account.
If there is any further information I can provide to facilitate your investigation,
please let me know.
I greatly value New World and would be deeply grateful for the opportunity to continue playing and contributing to the community under a fair and transparent review process.

Thank you for your time and understanding. I look forward to your response.

tl;dr: It's worth the price and I've enjoyed my 370hrs in-game, but the game leaves you wanting more, which it unfortunately cannot give. Keep that in mind.

It's an MMORPG that always draws me back from time to time, mainly because of its atmosphere, its sound design, its enjoyable combat and the memorable interactions I've had with other players throughout my several play-throughs. Though,  it's a pity that the devs are trying to mend the game into some theme park MMORPG with endless boring quests, whilst spending resources on voice-acted dialogue and cut scenes. That choice alone makes progressing in this game feel like a big chore.  That's not what makes the game great. I remember the game not because of some main story character or an event, I remember it for the times people arranged town-long "human centipedes", the open world ganking with friends and  group and guild pvps, sieges and generally global chat banter. I hate seeing MMORPGs where the devs are trying to make the stories, not the players themselves as it should be in an MMORPG.

This game had (or maybe still has) so much potential, but it's just being over sighted and wasted.

P.S. I hope I won't have to bear seeing Gallahad's hideous character model ever again.

New World: Aeternum is a visually stunning game that offers a blend of crafting, gathering, and combat. The game's unique atmosphere and stunning landscapes make it a captivating experience. Players can explore lush forests, clear rivers, and ancient ruins, each with its own unique vibe. The gameplay is smooth and action-oriented, making each encounter feel dynamic. Players can easily pick up skills and abilities, but there's still room for character development. The social aspect is appreciated, as teaming up with friends or strangers for quests and battles adds an extra layer of fun. However, server queues can be frustrating during peak times. The crafting system is another highlight, as gathering resources and creating gear keeps players engaged. Leveling up skills provides a sense of progression. Despite its challenges, New World: Aeternum is an enjoyable journey for exploration and a mix of RPG elements. However, players should be prepared for a bit of a wait to get in.

Ich habe wirklich das Gef√ºhl, dass die meisten negativen Bewertungen von Spielern kommen, die das Spiel entweder gar nicht, oder nur teilweise gespielt haben. Ich ver√∂ffentliche eher selten bis gar keine Bewertungen, aber dieses Spiel hat es verdient, dass man sich daf√ºr ausspricht. Voll vertonte Questen, eine atemberaubend sch√∂ne Grafik mit wundersch√∂nen unterschiedlichen Gebieten und Vegetationen, ein absolut zug√§ngliches Handwerkssystem, das sogar ich als Craftingmuffel gut und ansprechend finde, und (ganz wichtig) die FREIE Wahl, tun zu d√ºrfen, worauf man gerade Lust hat, w√§hrend nichts davon sinnlos ist, weil alles gut belohnt wird. Auch als Solo-Spieler hat man die M√∂glichkeit, sich gute und starke Ausr√ºstung zu erspielen, ganz ohne, dass man Echtgeld ausgeben oder Raids laufen muss. Jede Spielweise, jede spielerische Vorliebe kommt in NWA auf seine Kosten. 

Dar√ºber hinaus ist das Kampfsystem ansprechend und doch keine Raketenwissenschaft. Es gibt jede Menge Gegner, die es in sich haben, was zu einem anspruchsvollen Schwierigkeitsgrad f√ºhrt, der durchaus meisterbar ist und dennoch ein gutes Gef√ºhl zur√ºckl√§sst. 

Der Open World Gruppencontent, bei dem sich Spieler einfach spontan finden, so dass man auch ohne Gildenzwang und PvP das Gef√ºhl erh√§lt, Teil einer lebendigen Welt zu sein, rundet das Ganze ab. Und nicht zuletzt das sehr ansprechendes Housingsystem, das nicht so heftig einschr√§nkt wie andere Spiele. Hinzu kommen all die guten Quality of Life Elemente, die mich als neue Spielerin sofort abgeholt haben. Ich habe noch nie ein Spiel erlebt, das mir gleich zu Beginn so viel Lagerm√∂glichkeiten gibt oder mich recht schnell mit ausreichend W√§hrung versorgt, egal ob es nun Gold oder Azoth ist. Danke an die Entwickler, dass sie sich schlussendlich so viel M√ºhe gaben, denn zu Beginn von New World war ich leider gar kein Fan. Das hat sich mit Aeternum vollkommen ge√§ndert. 

Mein Fazit ist, wer z√∂gert, weil es immer noch negative Bewertungen gibt, sollte sich bitte einfach selbst ein Bild machen. Das Spiel hat unglaubliches Potential. Und mal ehrlich, in welchem Spiel ist nicht mal ein NPC verbugt? Daran eine Bewertung festzumachen, ist f√ºr mich ziemlich albern.

I‚Äôve got over 4,000 hours in New World: Aeternum, so I‚Äôve been through it all‚Äîleveling, grinding, crafting, gearing up, and tackling pretty much every bit of content the game throws at you. And for the most part? It‚Äôs a blast. Learning expedition mechanics, pushing into raid content, upgrading gear, leveling weapons‚Äîthat‚Äôs the good stuff. It‚Äôs rewarding, it‚Äôs challenging, and it‚Äôs why I kept coming back for thousands of hours.

The problem? Once you've done all that, there‚Äôs not much else to keep you going. Chest runs‚Äîaka joining a zerg to loot the same boxes every 24 hours‚Äîare straight-up boring. It‚Äôs the least engaging form of endgame, and unfortunately, it's one of the few repeatable things left once you're geared out. The game nails a lot of its core systems but really falls short when it comes to variety in late-game content.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong‚ÄîNew World is still 100% worth playing. If you‚Äôre into PvE, combat depth, or just love the grind, you‚Äôll easily get hundreds or even thousands of hours out of it like I did. But once you hit the ceiling, you‚Äôll definitely start wishing for more meaningful stuff to do on a daily basis.

TL;DR:
Amazing combat and PvE progression keep you hooked for ages, but the endgame could use more variety beyond chest zerging.

Amazon Games‚Äô New World launched in 2021 with ambition the size of Aeternum‚Äôs sprawling wilderness‚Äîand baggage just as heavy. What began as a PvP-focused survival sandbox evolved awkwardly into a full-fledged MMO, then struggled under the weight of inconsistent updates, endgame grind, and a bleeding player base.

Now, with New World: Aeternum, Amazon isn‚Äôt just trying to patch holes‚Äîthey‚Äôre rebuilding the ship and inviting console players aboard. And while it‚Äôs not a flawless rebirth, it‚Äôs the most compelling version of New World to date.

The fictional island of Aeternum has always been New World's greatest strength: a hauntingly beautiful, cursed paradise filled with ancient ruins, corrupted creatures, and factions vying for control. Aeternum doubles down on that promise with a more focused narrative structure, voiced dialogue, and expanded lore.

The new story content introduces stronger characters, better pacing, and a sense of purpose that was missing at launch. You still gather resources and level up, but now you‚Äôre not just grinding‚Äîyou‚Äôre adventuring.

Combat in Aeternum remains action-oriented‚Äîthink dodge rolls, timed blocks, and skill-based strikes‚Äîbut feels significantly more polished. The addition of target locking, improved animation feedback, and controller support make it feel less clunky and more deliberate.

The weapon system (you equip two, switching between them) continues to offer strong build diversity, and classless progression is still a major selling point. Want to be a heavy-armored mage who lobs ice storms while swinging a greatsword? You can.

The PvE content has seen noticeable improvements, and PvP remains an intense affair‚Äîespecially in large-scale faction wars, which are now more stable and fun to participate in.

Aeternum preserves New World‚Äôs deep and rewarding crafting system. Nearly everything you wear, use, or sell can be player-made, and gathering professions feel meaningfully integrated into the world.

Base-building in the form of housing gets expanded utility, offering more than just cosmetic flair‚Äîadding real bonuses and customization, especially for solo players. If you like life-sim elements baked into your MMO, this is where Aeternum shines brightest.

With its launch on Xbox Series X|S and PlayStation 5, New World: Aeternum introduces a revamped UI, controller support, and full cross-play. It runs well on console hardware, thanks to engine improvements and streamlined interfaces.

For new players, the onboarding experience is vastly improved. You‚Äôre no longer dumped into an overwhelming world without direction. Now, the game guides you with story missions, tooltips, and better pacing.

Aeternum has done a lot right, but it still inherits some of its predecessor‚Äôs grindy DNA. Mid-to-late game content can feel repetitive, and while gear progression is smoother, it still requires commitment. Some systems‚Äîlike territory control‚Äîremain complex and time-consuming for casual players.

And while cross-play is a great step forward, the game doesn‚Äôt quite bridge the gap between casual MMO fans and hardcore min-maxers. It walks the line‚Äîbut not without stumbles.

New World: Aeternum is less a sequel and more a soft reboot, but it earns the right to ask for your attention again. The game is more focused, more fun, and far more complete than it‚Äôs ever been. It doesn‚Äôt reinvent the MMO genre, but it confidently reclaims its place within it‚Äîthis time with sharper tools and a broader reach.

Whether you‚Äôre a returning player or stepping into Aeternum for the first time, there‚Äôs finally a compelling reason to make this world your own.

Best For: Fans of action MMOs, crafting-heavy progression, and immersive open worlds

When New World came out the game was very bland. The exploration was great, but the quests were all the same. However it was fun because you learned about all the systems in the game as you went along and wanted to know what was around every corner. But now 3 years later? It's an entirely different game. And not in a good way. The world is so vastly different than at launch I really know nothing about this world. The main cities are cluttered and hard to follow. The enemies you fight that used to offer some level of difficulty and enjoyable gameplay are now super easy to kill and offer no challenge (very diablo esc) and ALL of the fast travel areas I had before are reset so I have to rediscover the ENTIRE world to travel to cities I already discovered. Realistically it feels as though all of my efforts were wiped away and now I have to start from scratch. Also the fun systems I enjoyed like having an ammo limit and NEEDING food are now irrelevant systems in the game. It just lost all of its appeal. All they needed was better quests and more than 2k players per server, but no, reinvent the wheel. smh. Good game wasted. Thanks Amazon.

What starts out as a decent and refreshing MMO gradually becomes an increasingly frustrating experience. The visuals are great and overall gameplay and combat are solid. The experience of getting to max level is pretty pleasant but once you hit max the experience quickly becomes a boring and relentless grind. Gear is centered around perks and max level gear will have 3 randomly assigned. Your job is to grind as much content as possible in the hopes of finding gear with the perfect combination of perks needed, I imagine several hundred hours would be required to get a full set. Its possible, but prohibitively expensive, to influence one of the perks when upgrading gear. Getting gear with all 3 desired is a very rare occurrence.

Alternatively you might decide to craft gear instead. With crafting you can use randomly dropped items to influence one of the perks, slightly reducing the random chance of getting the gear you need. However, before you're able to craft max level gear you need to max out crafting. Very few people actually accomplish this because the amount of materials needed for levelling are absolutely staggering. To give an idea of just how much grinding is required you will need roughly 850,000 (yes, eight-hundred and fifty thousand) leather alone to level just armouring. With getting between 15-40 resources per node, you'll be skinning, mining, logging, harvesting for several weeks to get just one of the 7 crafting professions maxed out. If that wasn't bad enough the already limited resource nodes scattered throughout the world are often preyed upon by an army of bots and other players masochistic enough to attempt the humiliating grind to max crafting level.

PvP is equally grindy and often completely baffling. Balance is a foreign concept in NW with seemingly minor changes uprooting well established class/builds rendering the current gear grind meaningless in one fell swoop. Some classes are absolutely useless in PvP altogether. Perks again play a major role in being successful in PvP, more so than with PvE. What perks you actually need is a mystery for the average player, the game gives no hint whatsoever as to what might make you survive just a few hits from veteran players. Unleashing your strongest attacks will often barely register on some players and devastate others. Although gear score is normalised for PvP the difference in having perfect gear perks and not is colossal. Unless you're prepared to dedicate your entire existence to min/maxing gear, I'd give the PvP a miss.

The final source of frustration is the prevalence of bugs that just should not be there. The game has been live for over 3 years and still suffers from embarrassingly simple but ultimately annoying glitches. Very often the map might not display everything correctly; the compass (no minimap here) frequently fails to register points of interest or gathering nodes nearby; UI elements get stuck on-screen; sudden crashes to desktop when logging in or an inexplicable failure to connect to the servers unless you do a reboot of your computer and router are common occurrences. Every new update will introduce new and exotic bugs to the experience.

I honestly can't recommend NW to anyone looking for their next long term MMO. If you get it cheap you might enjoy it for the 2-3 weeks before the frustration kicks in but don't expect to stay here long!

In der Zwischenzeit widmete ich mich anderen Spielen: World of Warcraft, Forza Horizon und Co. Doch New World hatte ich nie ganz aus dem Blick verloren. Die Faszination blieb irgendwo tief im Hinterkopf erhalten.

Anfangs war ich etwas √ºberrascht von den Archetypen, aber schnell merkte ich, dass sich am grundlegenden Spielprinzip nichts ge√§ndert hatte: Waffe leveln, Builds optimieren ‚Äì alles ganz ohne nerviges Klassensystem. Und genau das liebe ich an diesem Spiel.

Optisch hat sich kaum etwas ver√§ndert ‚Äì aber das ist gar nicht schlimm, denn New World sieht nach wie vor absolut fantastisch aus. Die Hauptstory rund um Artorius und Isabella wurde zwar teilweise nachtr√§glich eingef√ºhrt, aber das merkt man kaum ‚Äì vieles wurde so sauber integriert, dass sich die Geschichte rund und stimmig anf√ºhlt.

Das Kampfsystem ist f√ºr mich nach wie vor eines der besten im Genre ‚Äì wenn nicht sogar das beste. Was New World f√ºr mich so besonders macht, ist die Freiheit, die es mir gibt: Ich kann stundenlang Holz hacken, Tiere h√§uten, nach Erzen suchen, Berufe leveln, Ruf farmen, mein Haus dekorieren, Expeditionen bestreiten oder mich ganz der Story widmen. Playing this through slowly really does make this game shine. When you aren't trying to rush or min max everything it really is a great game.

üëç [b] Pros: [/b]

[u] Fun and Fast-Paced Combat [/u]
The fighting system is smooth and exciting. You can easily switch between weapons and skills, which keeps battles fun and varied. It feels more like an action game than a typical MMO, and that‚Äôs a good thing.

[u] Crafting Feels Meaningful [/u]
If you enjoy gathering materials and making things, you‚Äôll love this. Whether it‚Äôs cooking, blacksmithing, or woodcutting, crafting is well-designed and makes you feel like you‚Äôre progressing even outside of battle.

[u] Beautiful and Immersive World [/u]
The game looks stunning. From glowing forests to misty ruins, the world feels alive and is a joy to explore. It‚Äôs easy to get lost in the scenery‚Äîin a good way.

üëé [b] Cons: [/b]

[u] Low Player Population [/u]
Servers can feel pretty empty at times. It‚Äôs harder to find groups for certain content, and towns can feel a bit like ghost towns. This affects how social and active the game feels.

[u] Endgame Feels a Bit Repetitive [/u]
The early parts of the game are great, but once you hit the high levels, there isn‚Äôt as much to do. The endgame content doesn‚Äôt have the same excitement and can start to feel a bit samey.

[u] Not Easy for New Players [/u]
Group content can be tough for newcomers. Many experienced players assume you already know the mechanics, so if you're new, you might feel lost or left behind in high-level activities.

I have probably received as much enjoyment as I will get from this game. The game is quite immersive, from background music, to atmospheric sounds and the visuals of the environments. The real time action combat, while overly simple, does feel like every hit is making an impact. This is a negative review time for the parts that aren't so great. Character models are clunky and weird looking, the progress through the main story line is pretty generic, the itemization is too simplistic, crafting starts feeling good then turns into a massive grind. The resource nodes for say mining or gathering, have long cool downs the higher the tier and are public, you can go hours and barely gather any resources. It's been almost 2 years since the game has had a new weapon type. Due to having the gear work for both PvP and PvE, that stat effect numbers are pretty tiny, sometimes barely noticeable. Every update is rough, something almost always breaks, or the content is spread out over a couple of weeks, there's always additional monetization putting up a barrier for something that is often free in most games. Last but not least, Aeternum was advertised as being for solo players or group play. Most of the content at end game can't be soloed, and the best gear is locked behind group play. The game has had good potential since release, but that's all it has ever had.

As a day-one player of New World, Amazon‚Äôs ambitious MMORPG, I can confidently say the game has undergone a dramatic transformation since its rocky launch in September 2021. Back then, it was a visually stunning but flawed experience, plagued by repetitive quests, a lackluster PvE loop, and technical hiccups like long queues and bugs. Fast forward to 2025, and New World: Aeternum feels like an entirely different game‚Äîin the best possible way. If you haven‚Äôt played in a while, it‚Äôs absolutely worth giving it another shot.

A Revamped Experience

The core of New World‚Äîits gorgeous world, action-based combat, and deep crafting system‚Äîremains, but nearly every aspect has been polished or overhauled. The leveling experience, once a slog of repetitive fetch quests, has been completely reimagined. The Brimstone Sands update and the Rise of the Angry Earth expansion introduced a more narrative-driven main storyline with cinematic cutscenes, voiced characters, and engaging lore that pulls you into the mystical island of Aeternum. Questing now feels purposeful, with varied objectives and a stronger sense of progression.

The introduction of mounts (horses, wolves, and lions) has addressed one of the biggest early complaints: excessive running. While the quests to unlock mounts can be a tad tedious, they drastically improve mobility, making exploration across Aeternum‚Äôs diverse landscapes a joy. The addition of new zones, like the visually stunning Ebonscale Reach and the reimagined First Light, adds fresh content and variety to the map.

Combat and Gameplay: Smoother and More Dynamic

Combat, always a highlight with its real-time, skill-based mechanics, has been refined further. New weapons like the Great Sword, Void Gauntlet, and Blunderbuss expand build diversity, while tweaks to weapon swapping and animations make fights feel more fluid. The classless system, where your abilities are tied to weapons and attributes, remains a refreshing departure from traditional MMOs, and the ability to respec easily encourages experimentation.

PvE content has seen significant upgrades. Expeditions (dungeons) are now more engaging, with challenging mechanics and unique enemies, especially in mutated versions. The Rise of the Angry Earth expansion added a new dungeon that, while not perfect, offers thrilling encounters. Enemy variety, a weak point at launch, has improved, though some reskinned mobs still linger. For solo players, the open world is more accessible, with activities like story quests and faction missions that don‚Äôt require grouping.

PvP, a cornerstone of New World, shines brighter than ever. The addition of 3v3 Arenas, a new open-world PvP zone, and a rewarding PvP track has reinvigorated competitive play. Territory control and faction wars feel more meaningful, with large-scale battles that foster community and strategy. Whether you‚Äôre a solo player or part of a company, there‚Äôs something for everyone.

Quality-of-Life and Endgame Improvements

Quality-of-life changes have been a game-changer. Fast travel is cheaper and more accessible, group finders make forming parties easier, and the expertise system for gear progression has been streamlined. The endgame, once a tedious grind, now offers a variety of activities: mutated expeditions, elite world bosses, and Outpost Rush (OPR) provide diverse ways to chase high gear scores. While some players still find the endgame loop repetitive, it‚Äôs a far cry from the barren state at launch.

The economy, once chaotic due to duping glitches and a lack of coin, is more stable, with a player-driven market that rewards dedicated crafters and gatherers. Speaking of crafting, it remains one of the most satisfying systems in any MMO, letting you gather, refine, and create everything from weapons to housing decorations.

A Vibrant World with Room to Grow

Aeternum‚Äôs atmosphere is unmatched, with a dynamic weather system, immersive sound design (thanks to composers like Ramin Djawadi), and breathtaking visuals powered by the Lumberyard engine. The game‚Äôs transition to a free-to-play model in 2023, with an optional premium battle pass and cosmetic-focused in-game shop, makes it more accessible, though some players grumble about the paid Rise of the Angry Earth expansion locking mounts and certain content.

There are still areas for improvement. Some dungeons could use more innovative boss mechanics, and the endgame can feel grindy for hardcore players. Performance issues persist for some, depending on hardware, and the lack of swimming remains a quirky immersion-breaker. However, Amazon‚Äôs commitment to regular updates and community feedback is evident, with each patch building on the last.

Is It Worth Playing in 2025?

For those who played at launch and left disappointed, New World: Aeternum is a revelation. The game has evolved from a promising but flawed MMO into a robust, immersive experience that rivals genre giants. Newcomers will find a beginner-friendly entry point with enough depth to keep them hooked for hundreds of hours. Returning players will be blown away by the improvements‚Äîfaster leveling, richer storytelling, and a more rewarding endgame make it feel like a true second chance.

If you‚Äôre an MMO fan craving a vibrant world, satisfying crafting, and dynamic combat, New World deserves your attention. For just a one-time purchase (or free-to-play with some limitations), it‚Äôs a steal, especially with the Rise of the Angry Earth expansion adding significant value. I‚Äôve sunk countless hours into Aeternum since day one, and I‚Äôm still excited to log in. Give it another shot‚Äîyou won‚Äôt regret it.

Score: 8.5/10

I'm truly sorry.

When I first got the game, everything was working fine. I thought I could manage for a while despite minor issues. Due to various problems, I hadn‚Äôt opened it in a long time. When I finally remembered and reinstalled it, I felt a new wave of excitement ‚Äî but it took 10 minutes just to launch. Then it asked me to adjust some settings, and after completing them all, I had to wait another 5 minutes just to proceed. The struggle I went through just to get into the game was unbelievable. I really wanted to continue and give it more time, but I simply don‚Äôt have that much time to spare, and honestly, I don‚Äôt think the outcome justifies the effort. I'm truly sorry...
ÂæàÂ•ΩÁé©

I was enjoying it a lot. But then I switched from my subpar PC to ShadowPc, closed based gaming pc service, because I wanted to see if it ran better. Story shot, I got permanently banned because I was ‚Äúcheating‚Äù. ShadowPC is not cheating software, but they don‚Äôt care. Appealed the ban but was denied. Tried reaching out for clarification and to plead my case but kept getting the run around. Overall really sucked any joy I had playing it out of me. Highly recommend skipping this game, solely because they have the worst customer service. O top of all of it, I payed full price plus the season pass and some in game currency for cosmetics and won‚Äôt ever be able to access them again. They couldnt be bothered to check my account to see if I was actually cheating. They would have seen that my account was constant with the average player for the amount of progress I had. No t much gold, subpar gear because I was grinding to upgrade, and most of my skills were only stating to get to high levels.

It's really hard to express exactly how I feel about this game, part of me wants to praise it while another part of me can't deal with the various problems that are presented throughout the experience. But after much reflection, a negative rating seems more appropriate due to the weight between reward and cost.

[h3]THE GOOD AND MAJESTIC THINGS[/h3]
It's certainly not a game that I would say deserves the title of "polished" but it certainly comes very close, the progression system is casual, it didn't make me feel forced to have to go after every single thing seconds into the game.

Each part of the story connects well, the narrative is not boring and maintains the right pace without getting lost too much between locations.

For those who played old games similar to grinding, with skills to create specific items for each activity (Herbalism, Weaponsmith, Tailor, etc.), you will have a great experience.

Without a doubt, one of my biggest compliments is the game's sound design, oh boy are they SATISFYING to listen to, from the sounds of harvesting, combat, and even notifications, they fit well without breaking the rhythm and immersion of the game.

[h3]THE HORRIFIC AND SCARY THINGS[/h3]
The price of this game (R$ 327.89) in my country is completely absurd for the amount of content it has (low, for the price), and since the game already has a very low population of players, this price will only drive more and more people away from even trying it.

Is there a battle pass inside an MMO? Along with an DLC expansion that is practically half the price of the base game, AND that locks a new mechanic? (Mounts and Weapons) Another game for the serious cases of infection coming from premium things in a game that is ALREADY PAID.

The Early game is the best experience of the game, where all its history, mechanics and plot are presented in a stupendous way, but after that, it becomes monotonous, the game itself no longer knows where to go or how to proceed, and then it becomes something more generic.

In resume,
I don't recommend it because has a very low active playerbase, it's a very expensive game, which has more paid content inside, plus expansion, plus cosmetics, plus battle pass, plus DLC that blocks game mechanics.
A little grindy to say the least but a whole lot of fun and a time sink. A good alternative to the usual mmorpg.

Da ich die ganzen Negativen Bewertungen hier gar nicht nachvollziehen kann und mir pers√∂nlich das Spiel extrem gut gef√§llt, m√∂chte ich euch hier meine eigene Meinung zum Spiel dalassen:

Auch ich musste die ersten Stunden ein bisschen warm werden mit dem Spiel und den vielen M√∂glichkeiten, dass es bietet. Zuallererst ist es mal ein Buy - To - Play Titel. Das ist f√ºr mich schon mal sehr gut, da es keine Monatlichen Kosten hat. 

Es gibt ingame zwar einen kaufbaren Season - Pass, den man allerdings nicht gezwungenerma√üen kaufen muss. Obwohl es einen kaufbaren gibt, wurde hier trotzdem an alle Spieler gedacht, da es einen kostenlosen Season Pass gibt. Und hier sind tats√§chlich auch tolle Dinge dabei und auch keinen M√ºll, den man von so manch anderem MMORPG kennt. Hier gibt es auch mal Skins, die man bekommt oder sogar W√§hrungen, mit denen man selbst etwas aussuchen darf. F√ºr mich ist das hier tats√§chlich etwas besonderes.

Hier ist wirklich f√ºr jeden etwas dabei:

- detailreiches Crafting - System
- man kann eigene Charaktere erstellen
- es gibt zwar die Holy Trinity (Tank , DD, Heal) aber man kann hier jede Waffe tragen, die man m√∂chte
- Skills werden erlernt, indem man das tut, was man m√∂chte. Man kommt z.B. im Crafting weiter und h√∂her, wenn man es macht. Man nutzt die Waffe, die einem gef√§llt und levelt sie dadurch.
- Dungeons (Achtung: hier kann man nur mit mind. 3 Spieler rein. Alles darunter geht hier leider nicht, mehr ist m√∂glich)
- Raids
- Tolles Housing System. Hier kann man sogar erbeutete Troph√§en ausstellen, um Boni zu bekommen. Nicht nur toll dekorieren, sondern auch davon profitieren. Allerdings zahlt man an die momentan herrschende und inhabende PVP Gruppe Steuern. Diese allerdings sorgt daf√ºr, dass die Stadt upgegradet wird mit diesen Steuern. Davon profitiert man dann wieder selber. Also ein dynamisches System.
- es gibt PVE und PVP - beides kann und nichts muss. F√ºr mich ein Riesen Vorteil =) 
- Fischen, was sehr intuitiv ist.
- es gibt eine Gruppensuche
- man kann Companin erstellen, was Gilden gleichkommt
- Im Game selbst gibt es 3 Fraktionen, die wichtig f√ºrs PVP sind. Diese kann man allerdings alle 30 Tage wechseln, falls man m√∂chte. 
- Emotes nutzen und sogar Musik spielen, indem man sich selbst oder andere Spieler Buffs geben kann. 
Auch kann man hiermit Geld verdienen und mit anderen gemeinsam musizieren =D 
- Mounts, die man sich selber erspielen kann (hier ben√∂tigt man allerdings Angry Earth DLC)
- es gibt auch einen ingame Shop, der allerdings weder aufdringlich ist, noch schnell zu finden. Zudem gibt es hier keine Dinge, die einen weiter bringen oder das Game ma√ügeblich beeinflussen. Lediglich Skins zum versch√∂nern, die man haben kann, aber nicht muss =D 

Man kann auch unglaublich viel auf der Karte erkunden. √úberall hat man Quest, die man erledigen kann. Hier geht es von Gebietsquests bis hin zu kleineren Quest, die man von z.B. Gegenst√§nden wie einer Kette, erh√§lt. 

Aber auch ein bisschen Negatives gibt es von meiner Seite aus:

- innerhalb von St√§dten ist es trotz guter Hardware sehr ruckelig und stockend. Gerade zu den normalen "Gamezeiten" am Abend und am Wochenende.
- die Deutsche √úbersetzung ist mehr wie Grauenhaft. Vor allem das Gendern ist hier nur noch lachhaft und so im Vordergrund z.B. bei den Titeln (Naturliebhaber*in......) dass es weder Sinn noch Verstand hat. Auch in den Quests ist es sehr verwirrend. Da ist mal ein Mann, der von anderen pl√∂tzlich als "Sie" angesprochen wird und der Quest den kompletten Sinn wegnimmt, da man ewig nach "ihr" sucht... oder die Quest absolut nicht verstehen kann. F√ºr mich geht so etwas gar nicht und geh√∂rt hier auch nicht hin.
Hier muss ich leider sagen, dass ich mich entschieden habe, auf Englisch zu stellen, da dies viel besser, runder und sch√∂ner ist. An meinem Beispiel der Titel: Hier steht dann Nature Lover. Viel besser oder? 
Man muss sich nicht √ºberall die Deutsche Sprache zerst√∂ren lassen und ehrlich gesagt, ist dass Englisch hier leicht zu verstehen. Sollte es euch dennoch schwer fallen, ist es sogar m√∂glich Untertitel einzustellen =D 

Ansonsten kann ich allerdings nicht meckern. Alles, was man hier macht, sei es Crafting, Dungeons, Fischen usw. hat alles Sinn und man sp√ºrt merklich, dass man seinen Charakter weiter bringt und alles einen Zweck hat. 

Ich kann euch das Spiel nur empfehlen. Ob Roleplayer, Abenteurer oder einfach mal in andere Welten eintauchen: Hier findet ihr einen sch√∂nen Ort, wo man viel erleben kann. Alleine oder mit Freunden und Partner- es lohnt sich vorbeizuschauen.

Klare Empfehlung und euch viel Spa√ü =D

Let me tell you how my relaxing evening spiraled into madness.

I spawned on the beaches of Aeternum, shirtless, confused, and wielding a sword made of regret. Within 10 minutes, I had joined a faction that promised eternal glory (and discounts on repair kits), chopped down half the island's trees like a caffeinated lumberjack, and got mugged by a pack of wolves because I tried to pet one.

The combat? Imagine Dark Souls met Skyrim at a Renaissance fair. It's crunchy, satisfying, and sometimes you‚Äôll block the wrong way and get slapped into next week by a zombie in a pirate hat.

I tried crafting. An hour later, I had 300 rawhide, 47 iron ingots, and absolutely no idea what I was doing. But hey‚ÄîI made a pair of boots so nice I wore them in real life for emotional support.

Joined a war once. Lasted 6.7 seconds. Didn‚Äôt even see the guy who killed me. Might‚Äôve been an actual god.

Also, there‚Äôs a killer turkey named Turkulon. He shows up once a year to ruin your day and humble entire armies. I saw 20 players die in unison and honestly? It brought a tear to my eye.

Pros:

Beautiful world, full of things to mine, chop, skin, and get lost in.

Combat that rewards skill‚Ä¶ or panic-rolling.

Players who will either help you or sell you a healing potion for 900 gold.

Cons:

Inventory management is now my part-time job.

I forgot what real sunlight looks like.

Final Score: 10/10, would die to a turkey again.

I've tried a few times to get into New World, but I really struggle. It's not because the game isn't good looking, this game is BEAUTIFUL! The story seems really good too, at least in the first part of the game. It's by far the best and most immersive game you'll ever play, it's really quite breathtaking. The problem for me, is the combat. Coming from the holy trinity (Wow, FF14, GW2) it's more like a souls-like combat, which I hate! It was obviously designed for controller, which it does excellently. It plays AMAZING on Steam Deck, fits the little handheld perfectly! However, as an MMORPG, the combat is so basic and boring. Sadly, that's the main hook with a game like this, and New World doesn't feel like an MMORPG to play. I mean the towns are packed with players so it looks like an MMO, but combat really does feel like a souls-like.

I've reviewed this once before in 2023 on another account. Came to revisit the game 2 years later.

This is a really fun game, and it's very immersive with lots to do but has a really strange player base. If you're someone who likes fishing, wood chopping, hunting, harvesting, mining, crafting weapons and armor, etc, you will probably like this game. If you are familiar with Runescape, it is very similar to that game with all the skills you can level such as the ones previously mentioned. If you like Elder Scrolls Online, you might like this as well. If you like doing nothing but standing in town and trading at the auction house, there's that as well. You can also own houses and decorate them.

Combat is very fun and actually feels like you're making contact with the enemy compared to other MMO's such as WoW. There are lots of quests if you're someone who likes questing by yourself. 2 years ago I used to skip through some of the main quests because I thought it was just boring honestly, but ever since they overhauled it a little bit and introduced Rise of the Angry Earth I have been enjoying myself a lot more and not skipping quests. There are also mounts now, 2 years ago they did not exist and you had to run everywhere on foot (though you have to buy the dlc to access the mounts which I think is silly). Not a huge complaint about buying the dlc to access mounts because at the end of the day the entire game is free and you only really have to pay once and then the rest of the game is yours to play forever with no subscription bulls**t, which is great.

The graphics are really amazing. I love exploring zones like Edengrove because of how colorful and exotic it looks, and also the surrounding woods from the Windsward area. Sometimes I just go right outside of Windsward and just chop trees for like 30 minutes simply because of how pretty nature looks in this game. They did an excellent job with the environments and the overall atmosphere of the game, which is why I think it is extremely immersive.

The community is still weird like I remember it. Lots of arguing, s**t talking, trolling, stage 5 clinger type personalities, you name it, people saying "dEaD gAmE" every 2 seconds like 9 year olds (doesn't seem as bad now, 2 years ago it was incessant though). Some random person once private messaged me wanting to go troll people for some strange reason (I guess because they saw something I said in chat and got the wrong impression of me due to misinterpretation of tone through text, etc). I ignored them because I thought they were an idiot. So they got mad and started harassing me for not wanting to be mean to other people, but the thing is that I didn't do or say anything that could have given them the idea that I logged in this game specifically to be a moron. I guess their own goofy perception told them I was a sociopath like they were based on a comment I made? It makes absolutely no sense and I still scratch my head about it lol. Also, I remember having a question about a character in the game in regards to the story (nature lady, I believe Adiana Theron is the characters name) asking why she is so angry at humanity and someone came out of nowhere and said "You must not be married, that was a jab at women". 

I sat for like 5 minutes trying to rationalize and figure out how their comment had anything at all to do with the question I asked (made absolutely no sense). Some of these people will take the smallest things and turn it into something that has absolutely nothing to do with anything at all just for the sake of conversation and trolling, I just don't get it.... but I guess that's the nature of MMO's in general. If you don't speak these people's lingo, you'll be confused. Perhaps I am witnessing a bit of brainrot and I don't realize it? Who knows. Makes my brain hurt honestly. Stuff like this is why 2 years ago I said "Stay away from global chat or your IQ will drop a lot if you engage" and based on my personal experiences I still stand by that. My personal theory is that the game's community is the way it is because of PvP being a heavy focus in New World, and in turn that will attract edgelords and super toxic types lol. It's the same thing with WoW, amazing game and really beautiful world filled with the most terrible and goofiest people you can imagine. It's sad really, but I digress.

But don't get me wrong, as I said, this is a very good game and you will most likely be immersed in it's gorgeous world and perhaps have fun with tradeskills or pvp stuff if you enjoy going to war with other people. If you're an introverted type of person you will probably still enjoy this game, there is something for everyone here. Personally, my wife and I like to stay to ourselves and play together, farm, quest, etc. Allows us to keep our sanity lol.

Epic game

As you can see by my hours I've definitely had my fun in this game. But there are serious development issues, they will never keep up with the players content cravings, in fact they really don't add much content at all.

The game has been out for like 3-4 years now and all they've done is rework after rework of the same content that they had already in the pipeline on launch, they keep adding new dungeons that don't matter at all instead of making the dozen or so dungeons that they already have into viable ways to play and progress. The raid was fun but it was really hard to find groups that could finish it for a while until all the noobs quit the game, but that'snot at all how you want that problem to be solved.

Pvp has been a balancing nightmare the whole time regardless of bugs the range meta is pure cancer and makes playing melee almost imposibble if you want to actually have fun. If you play games for fun then this aint it.

gathering and crafting was viable as a way to gain wealth and progress but they've reworked it so much that people don't want to gather because they have no idea if the stuff they pick up will be worth it in a month or two.

The boss fights are fun but all the open world mobs are a bit lackluster and copy paste, you'll notice after the first few hours that you fight the same stuff with new names and maybe a reskin, kinda boring after a bit.

The state of the game is just dead now, I don't think that will change as long as the current development and management stay the same and I've lost hope for it changing.

Great MMORPG! Loved it from level 1 till 65, well built crafting system, cool dungeons / raids / trials, love the way you can do everything from one character without needing alts like other MMO. Combat feels rusty in the beginning on low levels but gets a lot better on max level and very complex in end game. Lots of rewards / achievements, a continuous sense of progress. You are always rewarded for your time spent in the game, no matter what you do, as little as it is or as much as it is, you always are rewarded accordingly. Any MMO lover must give it a try. Community is great compared to other MMO I played and I like that staff is acting quickly on reports against players who are toxic. Great discord server as well, with possibilies to give feedback on anything regarding the game and a membert of staff always answers, quite often also taking into consideration and making changes in future patches for the benefit of the players! Good job Amazon Games!
