If you‚Äôve ever played Neverwinter, the Dungeons & Dragons MMO, you might recognize some similarities in New World. Both share a somewhat simple combat system at first glance, but New World stands out by offering a more refined and rewarding experience. Unlike Neverwinter, which is often criticized for its problematic monetization and pay-to-win mechanics, New World manages to avoid these pitfalls, allowing players to focus on the game without constant distractions from microtransactions.

Combat System:

At first, New World‚Äôs combat may seem simplistic‚Äîat least in comparison to some other MMOs. However, the more you play, the more you‚Äôll appreciate the underlying depth. If you‚Äôve ever played World of Warcraft (or any other game with a tab-targeting system) and found yourself wishing there was a bit more skill required in landing those chaotic, powerful attacks, New World will scratch that itch.

The combat system is dynamic and engaging, requiring real-time positioning, dodging, and aiming. It's a refreshing take on the traditional MMO combat mechanics, and it provides a level of satisfaction that‚Äôs hard to come by in games that lean too heavily on a "press-button-and-wait" approach. Whether you're wielding a sword, casting spells, or swinging a warhammer, every action feels deliberate and impactful, making the battles feel more like a test of skill than simple number crunching.

Story and World Design:

One of the standout features of New World is its incredible world-building. The environment is amazingly crafted, and the level of detail in both the visuals and the lore is remarkable. From the dense forests and foggy swamps to the snow-covered mountains, each area has its own unique feel and atmosphere. It's clear that the developers put a lot of thought into creating a living, breathing world that‚Äôs rich in history and filled with opportunities for discovery.

The story itself is intriguing, though it serves more as a backdrop for the exploration and survival elements. That said, the world of Aeternum‚Äîthe setting of New World‚Äîhas enough depth to pull you in and keep you invested in its mysteries. Whether you‚Äôre uncovering ancient ruins or delving into the story behind the corruption that plagues the land, the narrative weaves seamlessly into the gameplay, offering plenty of incentives to explore every nook and cranny.

Crafting System:

The crafting system in New World is another highlight. It's comprehensive without feeling overwhelming. There‚Äôs a real sense of satisfaction when you gather resources and craft items, whether it‚Äôs weapons, armor, or consumables. The system is complex enough to feel rewarding but doesn't require excessive grinding or micromanagement. Whether you‚Äôre an experienced crafter or someone new to the mechanic, there‚Äôs something deeply satisfying about creating items that directly impact your gameplay. Plus, the materials and crafting stations are scattered across the world, making crafting an integral part of your journey, not just a side activity.

Overall Impressions:

So far, I don‚Äôt have a lot of negative things to say about New World. The game excels in so many areas: the skill-based combat, the stunning world design, and the rewarding crafting system all come together to create an experience that feels fresh and exciting. There‚Äôs a good balance of depth without overwhelming the player, and the attention to detail in the game world is evident in every corner.

If you‚Äôre someone who‚Äôs looking for a traditional MMO experience with more skill-based combat and a world that feels alive, New World is definitely worth checking out. It‚Äôs a refreshing change from the typical MMO formula, and whether you‚Äôre a fan of Neverwinter, World of Warcraft, or other MMOs, this game brings something new to the table without the frustrating pay-to-win mechanics.

There is also the issue of Angry Earth, You are basically paying $30 for the ability to use mounts, something which should have been in the game from the beginning. You also get a "new" zone however its just a re-skinned starter zone that is now for end game, instead of just adding a new zone altogether. 

AGS has made an absolutely fantastic game, that they simply dont care about. Its just there to milk money from the microtransaction store and expansions that add basic functions that should have been there from the beginning. They dont care about the game, they dont care about the players, and its starting to show as player counts hit all time lows even during peak hours.

Un MMO sin gente t√≥xica.
Predomina la comunidad de Brasil.
En cuanto a las armas, hay un abanico muy amplio que te habilita a jugar lo que vos quieras. Si queres ser tank de aguante, tenes varias formas de hacerlo, si queres ser tank y aportar da√±o/utilidad, tambien tenes varios recursos. Si queres curar, podes hacerlo con el b√°culo de vida en el arma principal y en la secundaria podes tener un arma que aporte utilidad al equipo o tambi√©n da√±o. En cuando a los DPS, hay miles de combinaciones que podes usar. Dependiendo de donde vayas, si raid, mazmorra o pvp, podes elegir el arma que mas se adapte a tu forma de juego. En caso de raid (la tipica 1 vez x semana y tal) hay armas que sirven mas que otras por su forma de juego, por sus habilidades y es bastante interesante estudiarlo. Si te gusta el PvE, lo mas parecido a una mitica plus en el wow es hacer mazmorras en tiempos records, tambien usando determinadas armas, determinada composici√≥n con respecto a tus otros 4 compa√±eros. En cuanto al PvP puedo decir que podes pelear con cualquier arma.
 El juego te da la info, te toca leerla, entenderla y encontrar tu roll dentro de este precioso mundo de new world. 
Cabe recalcar que no todo depende de que armas uses, sino que tambien dependes del equipo que lleves. Casco, pechera bla bla, joyer√≠a.. Como en todo MMO serio, hay estad√≠siticas y beneficios que debes respetar para que tu equipo sea lo mas excelente posible, pero ya te digo, hay millones de formas para equiparse, millones de "builds". Eso es bastante atrapante, lo prometo.
 En cuanto a la gente, como mencion√©, no es t√≥xica.. Suele pasar de que la misma comunidad pone en la lista negra a quienes intentas pasarse de graciosos y se genera un gran ambiente.
 El juego es pago, no es para nada ptw, y la comunidad es peque√±a. Tienen que mejorar en algunos aspectos como bajarle el precio al juego o promocionarlo mas para que haya mas atracci√≥n. Como todo MMO, necesitas tiempo para todo. Nada es gratis y las cosas cuestan lo que tiene que costar.
 Recomiendo muchisimo ver algun PoV de Raid ya sea gorgonas o gusano para que veas que en este juego existen las mecanicas y hay que usar discord si o si para coordinar entre varios. 
 Jugu√© toda mi vida al wow, desde muy chico que me encantaba ver los MDI. Por cuestiones de trabajo+universidad tuve que dejar ese juego. Ahora que estoy estabilizado con mis proyectos personales, no tengo tiempo para wow pero si para New World y si estas en la misma que yo, este juego es para vos. The game is carried by build diversity (very enjoyable to theorycraft) and combat system (soulslike, let's say). 

The rest is trash. I've expent lots of hours waiting for new content (PVP, in my case), never came. At endgame point you have about 8-10 types of content, but you only can get the best gear doing pve (raids, dependant on other people) or crafting it (after farming dozens of hours). Most of the gear adquisition is unnecesarily timegated ("you can get only X material once a week").

The endgame loop is basically horrible and the company does not listen the comunity. They waste their resources adding unnecessary stuff that nobody asked for while the playerbase is dwindling by days. They did from scratch THREE TIMES the main questline to get max level, while endgame content is non-existent. 

It's really sad to see how a potentially very good game is destroyed by a really bad directives. But whatever.

I would really not recommend wasting time in this game.

Truly a shame that this is very pay-to-win, You already pay for the game, then have to buy an expansion for a basic free feature in most games which is the mounts. This is not a 100$ game but they want you to pay close to that to enjoy the game. Many other games release expansions like new maps or new functionality or skill set, but they make it free after they release the next expansion. This keeps the game alive and enjoyable behind a time-locked period where the new expansion must be purchased in order to enjoy the features, BUT if you can't then wait 1 year until our next expansion release and this one becomes part of the base game.

Overall the game has high potential but it can get redundant and boring after just a few months.

So yet again another review. I started New World on Dec 25th 2023 and beat the game in about 2-3 weeks.
From that time that I first played(i played some before Aeternum released)all the way up until now, I can see this game has made drastic improvements. I played alot before the major update released and yes the game was pretty fun, back to the time where Archetypes didnt exist and you just started the game on the beach and had a basic sword. I can firmly say that with the combat improvements, world and story improvements/changes and with the addition of new stuff, that I can indeed recommend this to someone who is looking for a new mmo or looking for something different from Black Desert or something. Though the one thing that is repeating itself, are the events. One event in particular stands out as one of the most repeated event being the Legacy of Crassus(yes I know, pretty much all if not most of the events are constantly copied and pasted). Anyways.
Game: 7.5/10 (5/10 for pre Aeternum)
Graphics: 6/10
Combat: 8/10
Story: 10/10

New World is a solid MMO with enjoyable combat and a world that‚Äôs fun to explore, but the story is a bit strange and doesn't really draw you in. When I first played, the game was more of a grind, especially with Azoth management‚Äîit felt like you were constantly hoarding it to fast travel, but nowadays, you could never run out of Azoth if you tried. The addition of mounts helped improve travel, making getting around much faster. Over time, the game has solidly improved, and it‚Äôs become an MMO I return to whenever I‚Äôm in the mood to dive into something online. It may not be perfect, but it‚Äôs definitely a fun and evolving experience.

Just wish I had spent my 550 hours on something else before realizing this game deeply disrespects its players at every level from design and QC to monetization and marketing. For far less money, there are much more polished and robust MMOs with pvp on the market.

Falta um pouco de carinho do desenvolvedor nos conte√∫dos antigos e no progresso do jogador para aumentar o gear score. No geral √© um jogo muito bom!
Importante dizer que a DLC √© obrigat√≥ria para o late game. Infelizmente voc√™ fica travado se n√£o comprar.

üîπ New World ‚Äì Review (144+ Hours Played) üîπ

After 144+ hours in New World, I‚Äôve explored every corner of Aeternum, from sun-drenched beaches to frostbitten peaks, and thrown myself into countless territory wars. Here‚Äôs my veteran take:

üëç Pros:

‚úî Immersive Exploration ‚Äì Aeternum‚Äôs biomes (lush jungles, misty swamps, snowy highlands) are gorgeous, and stumbling on hidden shrines or dynamic world events never gets old.
‚úî Deep Crafting & Player Economy ‚Äì Gathering, refining, and crafting gear feels impactful. Playing the auction house and cornering a market on rare materials is genuinely satisfying.
‚úî Epic Faction PvP ‚Äì Outpost Rush and 50v50 Territory Wars are adrenaline-pumping. Coordinated sieges with siege weapons and strategic choke points make for memorable battles.
‚úî Flexible Combat Builds ‚Äì With five weapon types and armor weights, you can go light-and-agile with dual blades or slow-and-strong with halberds and heavy plate. Dodge mechanics and weapon synergies keep combat engaging.
‚úî Steady Live Updates ‚Äì Amazon‚Äôs added new expeditions, quality-of-life patches, and seasonal events since launch, smoothing out many rough edges.

üëé Cons:

‚ùå Late‚ÄëGame Grind ‚Äì Chasing gold‚Äëtier gear demands repetitive boss runs, crafting loops, and gear score farming. Once capped, goals narrow to PvP ranks or cosmetic drops.
‚ùå Technical Hiccups ‚Äì Server desync, rubber‚Äëbanding, and occasional quest bugs still pop up, breaking immersion. Some expeditions have pathing or trigger issues that require resets.
‚ùå Population & Queues ‚Äì High‚Äëtraffic zones can lock and spawn long queues; low‚Äëpop servers struggle to fill faction fights.
‚ùå Faction Imbalance ‚Äì Many servers see one faction dominate territories, making it tough for underdogs to catch up unless you reroll.
‚ùå Repetitive PvE Tasks ‚Äì After unlocking fast travel, most side missions feel like ‚Äúkill X‚Äù or ‚Äúgather Y,‚Äù which can become rote.

‚öñ Final Verdict:

New World is at its best when you‚Äôre adventuring with a company, mastering a quirky weapon build, or laying siege to a fortress under a blood‚Äëred moon. But the endgame grind, server quirks, and occasional bugs can wear you down. If you love open‚Äëworld PvPvE, deep crafting, and large‚Äëscale warfare‚Äîand don‚Äôt mind repetitive loops‚Äîthis will keep you busy for a long time.

‚≠ê 8/10 ‚Äì A beautiful, ambitious MMO that rewards camaraderie and strategy, but tempered by grind and technical rough spots.

[b]F√ºr alle neuen Spieler: Ihr m√ºsst nicht das Hauptspiel plus Add-ons kaufen, wenn ihr die Standard- oder Deluxe-Version w√§hlt ‚Äì ist  "Rise of the Angry Earth" bereits enthalten.[/b]

Das Spiel ist einfach gro√üartig, riesig und bietet eine unglaublich umfangreiche Welt, in der f√ºr jeden etwas dabei ist. Es macht wirklich Spa√ü, egal ob beim Angeln, bei PvP-Schlachten oder beim Erkunden der vielf√§ltigen Inhalte.

Der PvE-Content ist beeindruckend vielf√§ltig, und das Jagen nach Schatztruhen und Ressourcen f√ºr das Crafting motiviert mich jeden Tag aufs Neue. Die Grafik, die Musik und der Stil sind stimmig und tragen dazu bei, dass New World zu einem der besten MMOs wird, die ich je gespielt habe. Das Preis-Leistungs-Verh√§ltnis ist top: F√ºr das Geld bekommt man einen riesigen Titel mit einer voll vertonten Story, [b]ohne monatliche Abogeb√ºhren.[/b] Es gibt einen optionalen Battle Pass, einen Premium-Shop und kosmetische Items, aber alles ist optional.

This game has progressively worsened since 2023 with shifting priorities, broken code and combat imbalances. Played a bunch in early launch and consistently try to give the game a go up into 2025 after each iterative update, only to see noticeable decline with each release and the followed disappointment. 

The game really had stuff going for it with unique combat mechanics, great world design and high quality visual/audio that set a new bar for comparable games.  It's just not what it used to be, and could have been great had the development stayed true to it's creation.  

Enjoyed my time playing it and may briefly comeback with future world expansions, but I believe the player base mostly hold the same sentiment that the game would need a massive overhaul to gain any consistent return to this.

Pros:  
A great alternative to World of Warcraft, which I have played since 2006.  I'm not a PVP guru, but I can see why this game appeals to those who are.  If you are a profession lover and/or one who likes to farm materials for profession leveling or selling to make gold, then you will definitely enjoy your time in this game.  Character builds are definitely plenty and being able to switch these up with short downtime is a big plus.    

Cons:  
Lack of storage options - No central bank option for companies like say, World of Warcraft has to help out players within your company.  No way of using one character to help out another character as there is not an account wide storage.  Plenty of space to be utilized, but being able to maybe trade in some of this storage for your own account would be beneficial.  

All in all, I give this game an A+ or 8.5/10.

The main concepts of this game are fun and engaging. Builds are great to play with, the game looks and feels gorgeous, and I have had many fun hours playing it. So why do I not recommend it? Because of the one thing this game just cant get right. The end game.

Levelling to max level (65) is fun, but very very fast. Before you know it you're there and you're asking yourself "what now?". The answer? PvP. Yes that's right, take part in all the PvP aspects of the game. Cool, you may think. I love a bit of PvP action. Step into a war or an outpost rush and get absolutely creamed in a second. Why? Because your gear is trash and to be even remotely competitive you have to spend hundreds of hours grinding out crafting levels so that you can upgrade your gear to be remotely decent so that you can be dragged through the highest level content (because, lets face it, your gear is still trash), to have a remote chance to get a piece of gear that is going to be what you need to make your build decent. Before all of this, don't even bother getting into that PvP stuff, you will just lose.

The game has no balancing to speak of. You are not put into content against players with similar gear score, not that that would help you as the power difference between a very high 710 gear score and the max (725) is that vast, that the 710 can barely even scratch the 725.

So how do you get there? How do you get to that last 15 gear score that seemingly turns you from a feeble peasant into a master of death and destruction? GRIND... grind your a$$ off!!! I'm not talking about Elite: Dangerous levels of grind (love that game btw), no no no... Elite's grind levels have nothing on this game. If you've ever played Elite, then you know what I am talking about. How any game could beat that in terms of grinding is beyond me, and yet, I give you New World!

So lets say you need to get yourself to level 250 in Engineering. You would start by crafting 28 Treated Wood Bows to get to level 50. This requires 336 Timber, 336 Rawhide and 56 Linen. Doesn't sound too bad, right? Let me go on...

To get from level 50 to 100, you're best off crafting 89 Lacquered Wood Spears. This requires 979 Lumber, 445 Iron Ingot  and 178 Course Leather. But to make the Lumber, you need 2 Timber for every 1 piece of Lumber, so add to that recipe 1,958 Timber. For every Iron Ingot, you need to farm up 4X that amount if Iron Ore, so that is 1,780 Iron Ore that you have to find.

These numbers get worse the higher in quality you go. All recipes require 2 for 1 of the previous tier till you get to the top tier. To get from 205 Engineering to 250, you need to make an astonishing 178 Mythril Blunderbuss (or relative equivalent of other recipes). This requires a grand total of 1602 Mythril Ingots. So to make 1 Mythril Ingot, you need 12 Mythril Ore, 2 Orichalcum Ingot, 1 Flux, 2 Charcoal. (I hope I'm not losing you here). The 2 Orichalcum requires 8 Ore, 2 Starmetal Ingots, 1 Flux, 2 Charcoal. Starmetal costs 6 Ore, 2 Steel Ingot, 1 Flux, 2 Charcoal. Steel costs 3 Iron Ingots, 1 Flux, 2 Charcoal. Iron Ingots cost 4 Ore.

To make 178 Mythral Blunderbuss, you need (Just the metal)
1,602 Mythril Ingots (19,224 Ore)
3,204 Orichalcum Ingots(25,630 Ore)
6,408 Starmetal Ingots (38,448 Ore)
12,816 Steel Ingots (38,448 Iron Ingots (153,792 Iron Ore))
48,060 Charcoal (96,120 Timber)
24,030 Flux (which you may find around 7 of in a chest on occasion, if you're lucky)

Do you see where I am going with this? Each node will give you from about 7 to 60 Ore depending on size and your character's gear. But that's if the node is even there in the first place because some other player has got to it first and taken it.

I made a spreadsheet detailing how much grinding you actually had to do to get just a single trade skill to 250, but gave up when I started to breach the millions of materials that you need for just 1 trade skill. "Just buy from the Trade Centre!" Yes but players have their prices set so exorbitantly high that you can go bankrupt just trying to make a few levels.

All in all this game is the biggest grindfest of a game I have ever played. You have to do the grind to be even remotely competitive, and this game is probably the worst game for any newcomer.

The game truly is a fun game. The whole colonial vibe is awesome, exploration and quests are fun, crafting is excellent, a lot of people, myself included, loved this game and was hoping it would be something more, but after almost 4 years since the original release, the only content that has been made is a re-release of the game (New World: Aeternum) so we can have cross platform play and ONE actual DLC that released back in October of 2023. So 4 years and one DLC but loads of updates to the cosmetic store so you can spend your money there. If the game is ever on sale and you have a couple of buddies that wanna try it, the standard edition wouldn't be a bad idea. But if you're looking for something that gets DLC yearly, I don't recommend this game. Elder Scrolls Online, WoW or FFXIV would be my recommendation.

PVP kann ich nicht einsch√§tzen, muss man auch nicht betreiben. Es mangelt etwas an der Vielfalt spielerischer M√∂glichkeiten, die Kern-Gameplay-Mechaniken sind aber absolut akzeptabel umgesetzt. Mir scheint, dass ein √ºberwiegender Teil der negativen Kritiken mit entt√§uschten Erwartungshaltungen zu tun hat, sowie einer fragw√ºrdigen und unprofesionellen Kommunikationspolitik. St√∂rt mich: Die Character-Creation ist eher basic und viele der Gesichter sehen grotesk und √ºberstilisiert aus. Die merkw√ºrdigen Gender-Formulierungen (Xier/Xien und * in Titeln) in der deutschen √úbersetzung wirken aufgesetzt, inhomogen und entsprechen auch nicht dem Sprachgebrauch der weit √ºberwiegenden Mehrheit der Deutschsprechenden - keine Ahnung, wie man auf solche Ideen kommt. 
Die Bewertung mit "ausgeglichen" spiegelt den Production Value von New World nicht wider, vor allem wenn man bedenkt, das zb Quinfall ebenfalls eine solche Bewertung hat - und da liegen qualitativ Welten dazwischen. This game started out beautifully and required real skill to play. Unfortunately, the current state‚Äîwith heavy aim assist and target lock mechanics, especially on consoles‚Äîhas made it nearly unplayable for PC players who value skill-based competition.
The assist features allow players with little to no skill to simply point and shoot. Shots unnaturally curve around obstacles like trees and corners, and no amount of movement or dodging seems to help. If you're a PC player looking for fair, skill-based engagements, this game may no longer be the right fit

Healers Got Gutted ‚Äì Disappointed and Frustrated

As someone who has mained a healer in New World since launch, I‚Äôve never felt more discouraged. The recent nerfs have completely ruined the experience of playing a support role. Healing is no longer fun or effective ‚Äì it‚Äôs become a frustrating chore.

The changes to healing output, cooldowns, and stamina management make it feel like we‚Äôre being punished for choosing to help others instead of dealing damage. Group content is now a nightmare. I used to feel valuable in Expeditions and PvP ‚Äì now I just feel like dead weight. It‚Äôs impossible to keep up with damage, especially when the enemies hit harder and our healing tools have been drastically weakened.

What‚Äôs even worse is the lack of communication or justification. It feels like the devs have caved to the loudest DPS players and forgotten the people who held groups together. Healing should be rewarding, not a constant uphill battle.

If this was meant to encourage more diverse builds, it‚Äôs backfired. Instead, you‚Äôve driven support mains away. I‚Äôm seriously considering switching roles or quitting altogether ‚Äì and I know I‚Äôm not the only one.

Fix this, New World. Support players deserve better.

I bought this game shortly after it came out because it went on sale and I liked the idea of an MMORPG that you buy once and get to play forever with no subscription fees. I played for about 5 months and while I enjoyed it, I got bored with it as it was still very raw, didn't have a lot of content, and had a lot of problems like not being able to swim and other silliness that showed it just wasn't ready for release.

Fast forward to a little over a month ago and a friend of mine starts playing because of the console release so I buy the Angry Earth update and give it a go again. 

I'm pleasantly surprised by how far this game has come. Its not a "No Man's Sky" or a "Cyberpunk 2077" style rebirth, but its a much much better game today. Now it still has issues like the lack of any real end-game, but it sounds like the development team is really small and that Amazon Game Studios isn't backing this game properly. It has great bones, but still needs more content. The community is small, but honestly pretty great as far as MMORPGs go. I'm on Pangea and its busy and alive.

I'm not sure I would pay full price for it, but if you manage to grab it while its on sale, you will likely enjoy it.

New World Aeternum is a fun, albeit flawed and high-potential MMORPG.

What works:
- Great feeling combat
- Intriguing setting
- Settlement interaction (incl. player housing)
- Survival-lite elements (good crafting and life-skills)
- Gorgeous environments to explore
- Varied enemy AI (some enemies dumb as dogshit, others have two brain cells that work relatively well together and actually dodge or block some of your attacks)
- PVP is a lot of fun 

What's ok:
- Character build variety and viability across builds
- Voice acted NPC interactions (varies in quality; sometimes audio is bugged)
- Story-telling (it's ok, nothing to write home about which is a wasted opportunity for the setting. The tone also feel really uneven and outright cartoonish in some circumstances)
- Factions are interesting but there's something missing (covered below) 
- Invasions are a cool idea but... (more below)

What's missing:
- 'Class identity/fantasy' (your weapon load-outs determine your role and which 2 stats you're gonna dump all your points into; little incentive to spread your points into other attributes outside of you main damage outputting stats resulting in little in the way of building a true identity outside of that)
- An 'indigenous' faction (you play entirely as a settler and whilst there are 'nature-aligned' people in the story, you never really get to side with them a la GreedFall. This faction could be oriented towards fighting the corruption of the island and resisting the influence of colonists)
- No incentive to specialise in specific crafting vocations (everyone can max all crafting skills like Runescape; cheapens the building of 'character identity')
- Greater variety of skill builds among weapons (combining 2 weapon types could unlock a new set of abilities that can be used when either weapon is equipped)
- The consequences for failing an invasion don't feel all that meaningful (settlement upgrades get reduced slightly; would be better if the settlement was wiped and the subsequent corruption of place had to be 'purified', 'destroyed', or 'contained for study' prior to resettlement; this would also give factions the opportunity to genuinely 'leave their mark' on the world in a meaningful way and deepen their respective character and provide more PVPVE content).
- Could lean more into survival elements (ie a weather/environmental system that has an impact on resources, character performance, weapon, armour, and tool durability to create money-sinks to benefit the economy, etc.)

Overall it's a fun game and I'm enjoying it casually. Assuming there's developer appetite for more expansions, which may sadly not be the case, some of the missing items above could be partially addressed. I think it's a good experience that struggles to be genuinely great. It makes some bold moves for the genre, but never fully commits to them which leads to some disappointing missed opportunities.

Also, the buy price is too damn high. I know this game cost heaps to make, but the box price is a real barrier to entry for lots of people. Perhaps the devs should look to FFXIV or GW2 for examples of monetisation.

Alrighty fellas, I know I am only 1,210 hours deep at the time of posting, but I figured since discord is broken that I would go ahead and post yall an honest review based on my experience.

Before anything, let me just help out and let yall know to just buy the standard edition of the game if you want to try it out, don't worry about the angry earth dlc that's still on the store, you only need the standard edition of New World Aeternum to have the full game +dlc.

Before buying New World, you must keep a few things in mind:

This game is ran by developers who don't care about the game in any way, if they did care, they would update the game once in a while, and give us fresh stuff to do without introducing a million bugs on the rare occasion that they do listen.

New World has bugs... Game is literally just a bug in itself, and you need to treat these bugs like mechanics of the game. You are likely to start noticing bugs pretty quickly, and some are pretty annoying. Please do not let this change your mind about buying the game though. I bought the game in January knowing exactly what the state of the game was, and it was in fact worth buying. You really have to go in with low expectations, that is how you set yourself up for the best possible experience.

New World is dying... New world has been dying for years. The developers don't care, and we rarely get anything new that is enough to keep the player-base strong. Latest big update was a pvp update that introduced seasonal pvp servers to the game that are just not fun for players that don't enjoy being killed constantly and jumped by 10+ players while trying to finish a quest. This update also split the already small community. We should have had more pvp related updates to bring life back to the main game, not just a server that closes at the end of the season for minimal rewards.
We need more content for those of us who already completed everything hundreds of times...

Amazon Games refuses to reward their players for grinding their content... If you are a fan of raiding, and endgame content in mmos. This game has a really good raid called Hive of Gorgons. Before I get into what it is and how to prepare for it, I want to let yall know about the weekly rewards... The Hive raid will only give you loot once per week, this includes schematics, which are used to craft endgame gear or you can sell them for a profit. I think its a 1/200 chance to get the schematic on your first clear of the week(reset day is every Tuesday at I think 5 am). If you are unlucky like me, you can do over a hundred raid clears and still not get the drop because I did not clear 100+ Hive raids by doing them once a week. I clear multiple times a week every week and only get armor and weapon drops on Tuesday reset day. 
The only thing that you do get daily that could potentially be useful, but its not for most people are the damaged gorgon's eyes. You have to do an insane amount of perfect scaled up expeditions(dungeons basically). This is just to get 1 hive cache that has a random rolled piece of gear in it from the raid. Most people don't have groups that can consistently clear these expeditions to that level which means that those eyes will just pile up until the devs decide to make a change(I recommend just holding onto them, if we are lucky, maybe they will become useful.)

Hive of Gorgons: Hive is not a piece of content that is easy to get into because the community is pretty toxic when it comes to giving new players a shot at clearing. I had to lie to get into hive raids saying that I was experienced and new what I was doing to start getting into them, and most of the time, that didn't work because they will ask to check your gear before inviting you.

If you want a chance to start getting into Hive and start getting good solid experience, please read what I am about to say:

There are multiple roles that you can play in hive, this is not exactly as simple as dps, healer, and tank. You have to build a bit more specifically if you want an invite to the raids unless you are lucky.

List of widely known roles: Tank(usually want sword and shield with the leadership perk in the skill tree to boost your groups damage by 10%. Offhand could be a few things, won't get much into that rn.)

Healers(Need a lifestaff, and void gauntlet with the oblivion perk in the skill tree. wont get into details rn).

Dps(this is the role that has a lot of diversity, and it is going to be your best shot at getting into a raid).
As a dps, there are a few main roles that are needed in a proper Hive comp. Evade Rapier, Bleed Rapier, and Rend Bot.

Evade: This is your best option to get into a raid and get some clears without people staring at you constantly. Just follow the group and work on maximizing your dps. In this game, gear score does not matter nearly as much as gear perks, so here is a list of perks to get before linking your gear to raid leaders: 4-5 pieces of enchanted ward on armor, 4 stacks of refreshing on armor/jewelry(no more than that as its max stack is 4), omnidirectional evade on an armor piece, and leeching flurry on an armor piece. Do not have regenerating on your earring as that can lead to pulling aggro from tank, avoid that heavily. Good way to find gear like that is to go into the trade post and filter for a perk until you get all of the perks needed. You will want your gear to be mostly yellow tier, with some red tier(can only have 1 artifact piece for armor, weapons, and jewelry on at a time.)
The artifacts you will want to start with to get into the raid are going to be Attuned Leather Pants(artifact pants from main story quest ending. Make sure to put health on these pants while learning so people don't question your life choices. This requires upgrading at a gypsum kiln. I won't explain how, you will just need to figure it out or research since I am limited here). Make sure to stay in a light equip load as any dps role. ALP are a medium pair of pants, so build accordingly because in a light load you get +15% damage.
Finisher(This is an artifact rapier that is pretty much best in slot if you add the perk, distained infliction as your upgraded perk. This is very important, do not leave this out in your evade build.)This rapier will be obtained in elysian wilds on the isle of zurvan. You have to get a group together to kill the 3 elemental elephants, and wait 6 minutes for the big one to spawn and kill that until you get the drop. Best way to get a group is to go into recruitment chat and say x up for finisher farm or something like that, then invite players to a group that x up in chat.
Endless Thirst(This is a solid starter artifact that helps make health potions heal for more and some other useful perks for survivability. Just put refreshing toast on it to counter the longer cooldown on potions.) 

If you have all of that stuff, you should be good to go as an evade. Just make sure you are using the rapier skills, Evade, Flurry, and Riposte or you are not playing as an evade. Please look up a build for evade rapier and follow that for the skill tree. That will help tons. 

your attributes should be set like this: 25 focus(5%cdr), 25 strength(+5% damage to melee weapons), 350 dex(as close as you can get), and the rest into intelligence. Constitution is not desired as a dps, your goal is damage, so get used to dodging attacks, but use con food if you need the extra health(attribute food from trade post).

make sure while learning to use a bow/musket as your offhand. These scale well with rapier, and are really good for first and 3rd boss. 2nd boss, always melee(its a dps check. melee does more damage with rapier, and staying on the boss avoids a bunch of mechanics.
I will not get into each of the other roles rn due to limited space. I am just posting evade in its full form because it is your absolute easiest way to get into Hive, and you can expand from there when you know the raid.

With over 400 hours spent in New World, I can say this game has been a rollercoaster of exploration, experimentation, and evolution. What first pulled me in was the sheer beauty of Aeternum and the weighty, satisfying feel of its combat system. Over time, what kept me coming back was the depth of the crafting system, the sense of progression, and the moments of large-scale conflict that actually felt meaningful. There have been ups and downs, and the game has changed quite a bit since launch, but watching it grow and improve has been part of the experience. Whether I was gathering resources deep in the wilderness, fighting alongside others in intense wars, or simply refining my build for the next challenge, New World always gave me something to sink my time into. It is not a perfect MMO, but it has a soul and a rhythm that resonates with players who enjoy investing themselves in a world that rewards patience, adaptability, and persistence.

It's trully not a bad game, I love it's mechanics, how simple it is, the pleasure it gives from playing, but continuesly bad management is just drowning this game over and over again. Whenever they do something to bring players to the game, they have to keep repeating the same mistakes. If you just want to play a game that you will like, and soon later watch how they kill it, go on.

Worth mentioning, due to constant lack of players online, you will not be able to do some of the content.

First off I want to say when I first started to play this game when it came out in 2021 I was addicted, coming from playing WoW it felt fresh and interesting and was fun and satisfying to go from completing dungeons to chopping down trees and levelling crafting skills. But after a while I lost interest as the end game felt like it was lacking the appeal to play anymore, anyone that got to endgame in 2021 knows it was not great there was little to do and the progression felt tedious. 

Because of this I stopped playing, but when I saw they were re-launching the game I thought the developers might actually be trying to do something, so I when it re-released as New World Aternum I thought why not try it out. 

When starting a new character to see the new starter area I felt the abundance of NPC dialogue was nothing but slop that they felt they had to write so the characters didn't just seem like mannequins staring at us, as I continued to play it seemed like there weren't many changes to combat and AI movement with the mobs and that is where I decided to stop playing. Needles to say I was disappointed that the game felt worse.

Also the fact that end game is locked behind a $50 dollar DLC when the game is $90 is absolutely ridiculous and honestly disgusting to see for the developers to do, it really made trying to get friends to get back in the game with me so hard, as I was riding around on a mount they asked "how do you get that?" and I disappointingly had to respond saying you have to spend $30 dollars to be able to get mounts in the game, and they were pretty put off by that which is fair.

Overall the changes were fine but I felt there was nothing drawing me back into the game. I would not recommend playing this game if you are a hardcore mmo player but if you are casual player I would say the game is ok but there a better games out there.

I played this game at launch, and really loved it. I no lifed it for like 2 weeks until the fiasco started with chat bug sausages, immortality exploits and so on. 

I just came back after years, because I told myself "this game was amazing, for sure they fixed the insane bugs right?" and YES they did.

Aeternum is a waaaay more polished version of the original game. The Main Story Quest leveling is amazing, the new zones are amazing, new weapons are cool. Everything is just so much better. They made more niche changes that improved the game a lot, which a total noob will not see, for example healers would stay in heavy armor and be immortal. That is not a thing anymore because you get -30% healing when you are in heavy.

Housing system is nice, crafting is nice, gathering is really satisfying. They made these interesting sounds when you kill something or when you gather, kinda like Battlefield or other FPS "clink" sound, which is very addictive.

Open world PvP is just insane and I started a regional war just last night because I was camped by 6 purple dudes. Called in the boys and it was a literal battlefield. In what MMORPG can you hide in bushes, making your name plate disappear? You can ambush people!

Honestly, people are trashing the game too much and that's just because modern gamers are delusional. You see people with 5k+ hours, even 10k stating that "the game is bad" because there is no content. Bro...I don't have 10k hours in dota2 and I play it since 2013. There is a lot of content, and you have a certain freedom other MMO's don't provide.
There is no treadmill like WoW.

The devs make some mistakes but whatever, my server is packed, content everywhere and it looks/feels amazing. Play this game!

This game has definitely seen some improvements as of late. The push for cross platform compatibility has also improved some features that make the game, particularly combat systems, faster paced. The Linux support has always been phenomenal and it is clear they put serious effort into making the game compatible with the latest iterations of Proton that are included with Steam. I have had no issues playing on Arch, despite the "Silver" rating on ProtonDB. 

The gameplay, is great. Graphics are great. New storyline is leagues better than what they started with. Grinding tradeskills/gathering professions have been streamlined to be quite a bit faster (it will definitely still take a lot of time).

That said, $70 game that has had to be re-released in such a short time? The audacity of that is very strange, but if you get this on a Steam sale it is a great addition- especially for Linux users.

If you bought the OG New World. You not going to have the heartrune in Brimstone Sands. It has a level 62 requirement now and is DLC past 60. You are effectively locked out of the game you purchased. "A fine line of theft almost." (PEOPLE WHO NOT PURCHASED ORIGINAL RELEASE DOES NOT INCLUDE DLC)

Like many, I played New World at launch and have kept up with it's downfalls over the years. I stopped playing some time ago. BUT I will say, if you have played it in the past and haven't been back in awhile, take the chance. There are many games that make an amazing comeback after some rough years, and this IS one of them.

If you're choosing not to play based on negative reviews and the angry individuals that are hung up on the past, you will miss out on an awesome MMO. Just saying.

I've been an avid MMO player for 20 years. Played everything on the market that can even be considered an MMO. And even all the sandbox survival crafting, RPG, etc. New World feels fresh, and revamped. I normally get bored quick with things, this has kept me occupied like games used to years ago. Which is rare. The starting area takes a minute to get past before you really see the games potential. Make it past that and you will start to see everything unfold. 

Questing doesn't feel like a chore. They have combined elements from different genres in my opinion, to make it an MMO. But it works, and feels fluid. I'm excited to continue leveling and see where things take me. I am just sorry I didn't make it back to New World sooner! This will be my main squeeze for awhile, as I am bored out of my mind with WoW. 

I have no run into any bugs or lag whilst playing. Servers are refreshingly MORE populated than I had expected. Going into New World from a fresh perspective, I was worried all the negative Nacy's had scared away the player base, but it is definitely there. And the game doesn't feel dead at all. I've seen more people in the open world questing and farming to craft, than I do on my WoW servers. Here's to hoping New World continues to get a steady flow of new players, it's a whole new game and deserves some credit. 

I found a large Company / Guild that is friendly and actively doing end game content, that's very open to new players. I didn't expect that either. There's a nice community of people in this game.

Long story short, BUY the game and give it a fair and honest try. If you have played it when it was in it's darker years, TRY it again, it's well worth it now. 

Happy leveling, see you in New World!

Horrible compared to any other mmorpg in just about any metric. Price should be free to play with how much you need to purchase in their cash shop to make it almost feel like a real game. Hours played is just because of leaving the launcher on.

You need to pay money for features in any other game, the rest of the "features" are things noone ever wants in a mmorpg. 
Mount? You need to pay for it.
Transmog equipment? Pay for it. 
Emotes? Pay for it.
There's a very limited bank storage, but it's all stored in different banks across the map.
there's limited emotes, but you need to pay for them. 
Want xp boosts? you can pay for it.

You have a WEIGHT system in a mmorpg? nobody every wants that, this isn't a survival game.
Web interface systems for like maps, social panels, any gui, most fail to load randomly, or fail to accept your inputs.
Want to bind your respawn point? fails to load. 

Want skill variety? You get 3, with 15-35s cooldowns, you'll be left clicking more than in path of exile 1 (sorry Chris)
Graphics are about as good as elder scrolls online, where it somehow feels dated already, the environment is okay. and that's what saves it so far. 
There's no sub-classes, no skill variety, no class variety, no uniqueness to any of the classes, it feels like they intended for this to be a mobile game, and somehow failed to do that, but ported it to PC anyway. 

I think if you took elder scrolls dated graphics and somewhat action targeting system, removed all of it's mmorpg features aside from a character that could not even sprint and and no skills, combined it with Once Humans cash shop and hilarious attempt at "corruption", removed even it's poor attempt at an endgame you'd have New World. 

It feels like someone made a game, where every update has a meeting where the only direction is "how can we remove functions and features, and replace them in a way to make us money"

for a studio with an unlimited budget for features and ideas, this "game" is unacceptable

You cannot block-cast, cannot roll dodge cancel an ability, cannot bar swap at anytime. So you actually need to know your timings really well but when you do M3 expeditions you just get one shoted by everything if not a tank.

I will say this, the game combat is phenomenal. I have 2200 hours in this game for a reason. It's genuinely enjoyable when it comes to how the game plays. The PVP is exceptionally fun, the PVE is challenging in a way that I have not seen in other MMOs - especially tab target MMOs like EQ2 or WOW. However, the harshest criticism I would add is that there is a lack of new content in the game and the development team doesn't seem to understand what is wanted in an MMO. 

Seasonal servers are not the direction that we need to go moving forward. MMOs are about building the character you have and exploring new content annually. Adding the Hive of Gorgons was a great addition, but running the same content week after week becomes monotonous, especially when a lot of the content has been in the game for years. We need a few things in this game to make it great:

1. New Raid Dungeon each season. Seasons should introduce a new storyline, and new content for PVE. Right now, we don't have an engaging new addition to the storyline since Rise of the Angry Earth. This is needed to maintain gameplay.

2. We need a new overland zone. There is talking about the Dev team reworking Reekwater - which is nice, but at the same time, part of what makes me enjoy MMOs is that occasionally there is something new to explore. New storylines to uncover. New harvestables to go get. We have been missing that.

3. We badly need new expeditions and mutations. I love the expeditions in this game, they are well thought out (minus certain mechanics that are added purely to waste time - such as carrying the Azoth Staff half way across the map in Garden of Genesis and Starstone Barrows). Additionally, only allowing 3 mutation dungeons per week makes the game feel far too grindy. Like there are only 9 in the game, and yet each week I am limited to running the same three over and over and over which makes a game which is already small seem even smaller from a PVE standpoint.

3. We need new PVP maps - luckily there is another OPR being added, but we need new matches besides 3V3 and OPR. We need some new games like capture the flag.

4. The PVP zone in CK is an utter failure. It really adds very little to the game besides going to get your goldcursed coconut every Tuesday. A better method would be the PVP from Nagrand in WOW. Where every 4 hours somebody can take over a town. Then the three colors can fight for it every so often.

5. Storage needs to be consolidated and I should be able to manually organize things. It is so frustrating that each time I come back to my storage shed items are in a different order. Also the search bar at the top is annoying because if you type two letters, it makes me open different screens.

Make some quality of life changes, and add content, and this game would be wonderful. I would even pay a sub fee if it meant NEW CONTENT.

It feels like a nearly completed MMORPG. It plays like a single players RPG where the ending is nearly impossible to play unless you min max from the beginning. 

Pros - You can completely change "class" and respec on the cheap. Leveling to 0 - 60 is fairly quick. 

Cons - Most missions/quest feel the same. Items can only be sold at the player driven market. Upgrading equipment is expensive and requires PVP. End game content is lacking. I spent a lot of time waiting to get invited to the only raid where I could continue to develop my equipment. There is no reason to join a company. You are pretty much forced to join a faction. Very few players are willing to help with anything. 

Overall, there are other MMORPGs that do this same thing better.

Game play is unique but development is slow and poorly implemented (very buggy, forced content). The recent expansion sidelined 90% of all content (crafting, previous rewards and events) in favour of one bug-filled dungeon for best-in-slot gear. By the way, that dungeon is gate-kept by sweaty players in-game who make it a horrible experience to run.
As far PvP is concerned, as soon as any build gets popular for casual gamers it gets nerfed into the ground (Amazon Game Studios seem to have an aversion to any fun being detected).
Its new and robust it actually has a premise and invites a level of character to the game that was lacking before.

KINDA LIT
I feel like I have been sleeping on this game. The game looks great and is fun I have not found anything I dislike yet.

As a new player. i enjoyed most of the beginning stories, sides and monster concepts. the archetypes(classes) and their 3 main resource skills that start at level 50 SEEMED like a good variety

   Story: 6/10. decent obvious story. you can play on your own all the way through the story. the story beats: here is an issue, go solve it/find this person. do the good deed through several connecting area quests and saunter on to the next region. side quests as well. great amount of side quests never not something to do. like most games slows down when at current end game area.

Cinematic. 4.5/10 Good early cinematic scenes but it takes a sharp dive into concept art/full art story board with added narration. there should be some epic cinematic moments that are just missing.

Combat: 6/10 simplistic and easy to follow.  until you get into pvp which can be a different but learning curve is fine. the use of potions and food buffs is very much needed for pvp and end game content. combat is one of the games better features.

Attributes: 6/10 six attributes. strength, dexterity, focus, intellect, stamina, constitution. Weapons/gathering skills are tied into the attributes. for example, an occultist, has fire staff/ice Gauntlet weapons and their damage is based from 100% intellect. the tie into the gathering skills lowers it for me and just feels out of place. the bonuses are nice but they really ought to have them intertwined with the skill's themselves.

Weapon Skills: 6/10 instead of the player having a skill tree the weapons do. you can play around with different ideas to run each weapon, your gear will also play a role in this, some gear gives unique bonuses to certain weapon skills. as i reached max level on my occultist i noticed other occultists using the same builds and the only difference that separated us was the gear we had vs pvp sets.  You are not stuck using just your starting archetype, you can train and use every weapon as long as you meet the level requirements and of course respecing your attribute points to work on a different build is 100% doable at any time for a small cost.

Gathering skill: 5/10  mining ore, skinning animals, woodcutting, picking local/rare flora for special ingredients/cloth fibers, and fishing in your favorite watering hole. Gathering skills are really fun and you'll be doing them forever so let that adhd run high. the issue. you are going to be fighting with a lot of players for some resources. you'll be competing for the more rarer nodes later on. you have a chance of getting special materials as a rare drop when Harvesting a node and most are needed for crafting recipes and Gems for jewel crafting when mining ore. maxed out skills have nodes that are added to the skill experience circle. each node has a star rating crate with materials in them that you earn.  1, 2 and 3. contains decent materials so farming doesn't feel empty.

Production skills: 5.5/10 From Smelting ore, weapon crafting, armor crafting, stone cutting, jewel crafting, Weaving, Cooking, Workbench(for tools, unique items., Tanning, and arcane(potions, unique magic weapons/potions and Materials). you will have a lot of materials and most of the stuff you make you'll end up just salvaging to get resources back. midway through and quarter through some skills will need multiple sources of materials. Materials get costly and leveling some skills like armor/weapon crafting can be expensive whether you buy or farm materials. speaking of costs.

The Trade Post (auction house): 4/10 the biggest thing about the game is gold, getting gold, buying things, selling things. working on craft and prepping for content. you will find that the amount of gold vs amount of time gathered does no equal up and as always the devs and the player base are to blame. with either very minimal type of an item being over priced then to over saturated gear taking up pages no one buys from. end game content and pvp are the main focus so a lot of gear that would be good is grossly overpriced. that gathering skill you've been working on well someone else is already selling 15000(not an exaggeration) of that resource you want to sell at an already heavily cut and cheapened price. making both gathering/crafting skills almost seem pointless until you get to the late game items and even then the most important items you need drop from raids or certain higher difficulty. not user friendly and the search options are not accurate/wrong when setting them. trade-post effects the gathering/production skills score in this review because together they effect the overall economy in the game.

Making other characters/alts on the same server: 0/10 don't bother. you do not have a shared storage and no mail system like warcraft. you can respec points anytime to try out a different build. you'll be doing enough dungeons/buying getting sets of gear for pretty much every build. players will sell low tier at high cost, have alt buy item to transfer gold.

Factions: 4/10 3 factions. Gear/items store available. more stuff per rank. complete quests until you reach ranking tiers, then do a special quest to rank up. Faction tokens and gold to buy items. the gold needed for items in the last ranks rewards are outrageous.  pvp locations for your faction for bonuses. settlements can have a faction in lead of it. giving unique perks. definitely a fun thing i see people fighting a lot so i know it is something pvp'ers enjoy doing. BUT server pending factions are over populated and have a tendency to reign supremacy so some real QoL changes are needed. there are other pvp things to do which i have not done but there is enough to have fun. the equipment you can buy really is not that great and outdated from what i can tell. i wouldn't mind owning a set of the faction gear for the looks but i cannot justify the price. also the store has some items that you absolutely need for some crafting. the gear is not updated to end game gear-score. factions feel more like an after thought. you've beaten the base game and just want to keep busy and max out rank.

Dungeons/raids:  6/10 easy once you get into doing them a few times. extra bonus for doing random Dungeons twice a day.

Elite areas: 5/10 hate them. you need to play with others. you'll need to bug general chat or play on a busy day and hope to run into others.

Battle pass: 5/10 the rewards you get with the free portion of the pass are mediocre for a while until you get to the higher levels. premium costs about 20 dollars. you have a Bingo card to fill in and challenges to earn stamps for that card, then you get a new card and keep adding exp to the battle-pass. there is a list of challenges you cant get unless you purchase the premium pass. the premium rewards are far superior right from the very beginning.

MONSTERS:6/10 great enemies but half way through you start seeing the same enemies in just different cosmetics. with a few differences to area bosses ect. 

Mounts: 5/10 you get three mounts for free by doing the quest to earn each one. others need to be purchased.

Conclusion: New world Aeternum is an average mmo experience with a few highlights. then it starts to kind of go down hill because of dev choices or lack of. since it's debut it has had numerous server mergers to help with population issues. which then in turn cause economy issues and pvp faction issues.  they also have created seasonal servers which only separates the player base and does not help in the slightest. The game is fun all the way through but max level and endgame content is where things started slowing down. if you do want play new world i suggest buying it while on sale.

Thank you for reading this. please leave a reaction and of course i am open to comments. plus if i got anything wrong or off don't be afraid to let me know. i want to be a good reviewer one day. i do expect trolls and trolls are important. I've been Vexed and this is another review see ya next time.

- Un syst√®me de tirs tr√®s agr√©able et qui n'est pas en vis√©e auto (+retomb√©e de fl√®ches, quasiment pas de distance max, voir pas du tout ?)
- Un MMORPG o√π l'on retrouve pas mal d'interactions entre joueurs, beaucoup de rencontres sympathique !


N√©gatif : 
- Les bugs que l'ont a eu au d√©but (mais comme tous les jeux qui sortent j'ai envie de vous dire), on retiendra aussi les files d'attentes qui on √©t√© une catastrophe, mais pas besoin d'approfondir ces bugs √©tant r√©solus)
- Les changements de serveurs r√©currents d√ª aux Hypes du jeu que l'on a eu au d√©but, lors de DLC..
- Personnellement, les serveurs temporaires ne sont pas ma cam du tout, je n'aime pas et je ne peux pas recommencer 10 fois le jeu, cependant  le recommencer apr√®s 3 ans et tout le travail fait autour de l'histoire est un plaisir ! 
- La gestion des inventaires dans les villes, qui a √©t√© simplifi√© avec le temps, ce n'est pas catastrophique non plus, mais j'ai eu l'impression de passer beaaaaucoup trop de temps √† ranger / d√©truire etc .. (A savoir que je suis un gros farmeur et que je m'int√©resse √† tous les m√©tiers, donc une infos √† prendre avec des pincettes)
- Une population assez basse, et peut √™tre que comme moi certains attendent un vrai renouveau et un contenu sp√©cifique pour revenir sur le jeu (Comme les serveur full PvP)
-  Un peu frustrant de devoir payer pour acc√©der √† tous le contenu (Zone, monture ..), mais il suffit de comparer le prix d'un abonnement chez d'autres MMORPG pour se rendre compte que c'est tout √† fait correct. et tout travail m√©rite salaire.
- Le syst√®me de commerce pourrait √™tre am√©lior√© / simplifi√© parfois


En r√©sum√© je dirais que pour un MMORPG, il a beaucoup d'avantages, en passant de la beaut√© du jeu, du gameplay tr√®s satisfaisant, aussi pour le co√ªt qui est correct, ou le syst√®me n'est pas li√© √† un abonnement, Des devs qui sont √† l'√©coute, et qui communique, + un jeu qui √©volue en partie avec les critiques de la communaut√©.
Un nombre de joueur un peu bas √† mon go√ªt, mais qui se maintient, en plus avec l'ouverture de NW sur console (et pour un MMORPG il est encore tr√®s jeune)
L'ouverture de serveur PvP est une tr√®s bonne id√©e et pourrait me faire relancer New World, bien que je n'ai pas envie de recommencer un personnage sur lequel j'avais beaucoup investi, surtout sur un serveur temporaire.

Merci pour le travail des √©quipes NW en tout cas, de tr√®s bons moments pass√© dessus !

The combat system is what makes this mmo extremely fun and addictive. The voice prox. makes for some really cool and fun social interactions. The pvp is still going strong and what initially grabbed my interest of the game. But now the pve, from the leveling experience, expeditions, raids, and world events, have come leaps and bounds from the initial launch and now find myself more of a pve'r in the current state of the game. The music and in games sounds are SO good, specifically the sounds when mining, cutting trees, and harvesting.

My only TRUE dislike are the artifacts that are locked behind the pvp track system. Every other grind in the game doesn't really feel like a grind but grinding the pvp tracks, especially if you don't have a group for 3v3's or OPR, isn't enjoyable for someone who wants the artifact for pve content. I think that if you are going to place artifacts behind the pvp tracks and pve content then you should be able to access all artifacts in both areas of the game and not forcing people to play the game modes they have no interest in. 

Just my 2 cents! Overall I love this game and can see myself continuing to play this game for years.

Ah, New World, the game that asks the question: What if we made an MMO where 90% of the content is chopping wood, and the other 10% is complaining about balance changes?

You start your journey shipwrecked on a mystical island, armed with nothing but determination and crippling resource addiction. Your first quest? Kill three boars. Your second quest? Kill more boars. Your third quest? Please, for the love of God, kill even MORE boars. And just when you think you're done‚Äîguess what? The boars respawn.

Combat is dynamic and engaging, in the sense that you will engage in combat and then dynamically get stun-locked to death by a level 6 turkey. And PvP? Oh, it‚Äôs glorious. Nothing quite like running for 20 minutes across the map, only to get deleted in 0.3 seconds by some guy in a glowing purple hat named "xX_DeathWizard_Xx" who has literally never left the warzone since launch.

The economy is a beautifully broken masterpiece. Need gold? Too bad! All your crafted items are worthless because everyone else is crafting the same junk and dumping it on the market for 0.01 coins. But don‚Äôt worry‚Äîjust take a few deep breaths, sell your soul to a faction, and do your daily taxes like a good little settler.

And let‚Äôs talk about the real endgame: chopping wood. Forget raids, forget dungeons‚Äîtrue power in New World comes from your logging level. You will spend hours leveling it. You will lie to yourself and say, ‚ÄúJust one more tree.‚Äù And before you know it, it‚Äôs 3 AM, you‚Äôre half-asleep, and you're questioning whether you‚Äôve become a virtual lumberjack in a past life.

Yet, despite all this‚Äîthe grind, the pain, the endless faction drama‚ÄîI keep coming back. Why? Because somewhere between being scammed in the trading post and dying to a mosquito, New World does something magical: it makes suffering fun.

10/10. Would lose another war because my faction refuses to log in again.

I decided to leave a review after 400 hours of playtime. This game is amazing for the first 400 hours. Currently I have decided to put a pause on it because I have maximized my dps character and my Tank Build is pretty much complete as well. So here  is my pro and con list:

Pros:
1. the classes are super flexible, you do not have to make different characters when you want to switch from dps to tank for example. This makes quality of life amazing on the game. I had a hard time deciding on what weapon to use so I easily made a gear set for each and picked what I liked the most.
2. the scenery is beautiful, great graphics.
3. with the market place your choices to making money are endless. you pick the price you want to buy or sell, it's like the stock market where I like to buy items for low prices and then try to sell it to make profit.
4. the dungeons are fun to play.
5. there is a grind to farming gear but for the most part it is not exhausting. most of the time an item drops after a good days worth of grinding. unless if you want life ring... that can take a week or 2 haha.
6. The players you meet are very helpful, I have made some good friends in this game. 
Cons:
1. Lack of content when you get to end game. I can see many things I can max out when it comes to crafting and gathering however I am not that guy. All that's available for end game is a weekly raid called hive of the Gorgan. It is daunting when you first try it however once you get your gear in line and have a solid team you can run through these once a week. what's there to do after? nothing really. I only get one once a week for the raid then I end up playing something else.

2. PVP tends to be a bully fest. If you are not in the best faction in your server, you will get out numbered in pvp areas. I am talking 10 v 1 demolitions. There are PVP match making like outpost rush which is an even 15 v 15 but it becomes repetitive since it's always the same map. then there is 3v3 Arenas but that is a pain because anyone can que up as tank so 9 times out of 10, your team loses because you don't have a true tank to take the damage. 

3. unfortunately people are losing interest so lately it has been a little rough trying to match up with people for random dungeons or farming items from world bosses that requires atleast 5 people that are farming for the same item as you.

Message to the Devs:
Stop putting focus on Throne and Liberty. It's only advantage is its Free to play. Listen to your new world community and give us more end game content please. I love this game but I need there to be more things to do in the end game.

New World ‚Äì Oder: Warum ich mehr Zeit mit Holzf√§llen als mit K√§mpfen verbringe

Ich wollte ein episches Abenteuer in einer mystischen neuen Welt erleben. Jetzt stehe ich seit drei Stunden im Wald und hacke Holz, weil ich meine Siedlung verbessern will. Abenteuer? Nein. Ich bin offiziell zum mittelalterlichen Waldarbeiter geworden.

Gameplay ‚Äì ‚ÄûWarum rennen die Wildschweine schneller als ich?‚Äú

New World gibt mir eine riesige offene Welt, spannende K√§mpfe und eine Story ‚Ä¶ die ich komplett ignoriere, weil ich zu sehr damit besch√§ftigt bin, nach Eisenerz zu suchen. Ich wollte ein Held sein, jetzt bin ich ein professioneller Sammler von Leinenstoff und habe eine tiefe pers√∂nliche Feindschaft mit Truth√§hnen entwickelt.

K√§mpfe ‚Äì Schwert, Axt oder doch Magie? Egal, ich treffe eh nichts.

Das Kampfsystem ist spa√üig und dynamisch, bis ich feststelle, dass ich meine Ausdauer in den ersten zwei Sekunden verbraucht habe und jetzt wie ein ersch√∂pfter Rentner um den Gegner herumrolle. Und wenn mich ein Boss trifft? Sofortiger Besuch auf dem Friedhof.

Wirtschaft ‚Äì ‚ÄûWillst du 500 Steine f√ºr 2 Gold kaufen?‚Äú

Die Spieler√∂konomie ist wild. Ich versuche, meine hart verdienten Waren zu verkaufen, nur um zu sehen, dass jemand anderes sie f√ºr den Preis eines nassen Toastbrots anbietet. Also gut, dann behalte ich halt meine 500 gesammelten B√§ume und starte ein eigenes M√∂belgesch√§ft.

PvP ‚Äì Wo ich lerne, dass ich doch kein guter K√§mpfer bin

Ich dachte, ich bin bereit f√ºr den Kampf gegen echte Spieler. Dann treffe ich auf eine PvP-Gilde, die in perfekter Formation anr√ºckt, w√§hrend ich noch versuche, mein Schwert aus meinem Inventar auszur√ºsten. Spoiler: Ich habe verloren. Schnell.

Fazit

New World ist wundersch√∂n, macht s√ºchtig und gibt mir das Gef√ºhl, wirklich in einer lebendigen Welt zu sein ‚Äì aber wenn ich nicht gerade k√§mpfe oder laufe, dann sammle ich Holz, jage Truth√§hne oder fluche √ºber das Auktionshaus.

Bewertung: 4.5/10‚Äì Ich kam als Krieger, wurde zum Sklaven.

The game combat is one of the best combat systems in an MMO. Recently they released the game for console PS5/Xbox, and with it they added AIMLOCK to the action based combat system. This essentially turned the combat system into a tab-target game where ALL console players can hit you with 100% accuracy at range. There are videos out talking about this and I recommend you do your research on the aimlock problem before buying it. With these changes, the combat feels very arcadey, with a very very LOW skill ceiling. 

I do not recommend this game to any one who does not want to play aimlock game, likes PvP, and wants a game where skill matters, not who has aimlock enabled.

Dont buy.

Been playing for 100 hours now. I consider myself a casual player as I play about 2-3 hours a few nights a week after my kids go to bed.

This game is fun. Its very casual friendly with its set up, class system and crafting. I basically play the game solo, aside from haphazardly scattered meetings with IRL friends to meet up and do dungeons...errr...expeditions.

New World has had ups and downs. Mostly downs, but like any abusive relationship, the ups are just enough to make me think its changed and that things are better now. Like every abusive relationship, however, I was wrong. The game itself has been ultimately enjoyable, albeit unbalanced and rather lacking in mechanics for how long its been out, and how clear the fan base has been about what they want. The Devs made one thing clear in the last 4 years; They don't care. Makes some sense since this entire game is a proof of concept for some lotr project. They only follow through with their promises when things start looking bad for them. The thing is, everything I've mentioned so far I've accepted as the norm. Just like any abusive relationship, I've been tricked into accepting this unacceptable behavior. the anvil that broke the camels back, however, is a recent server merge. Maramma to Valhalla. Valhalla is a "Legacy Server" Which is AGSs fancy way of saying that there were so many bugs back then that the economy is permanently damaged. Now they merge what was once a fresh start server into an economy so bad it would make the US Government blush. The whole point of the fresh start was to leave that shitshow behind. After over a thousand hours of grinding, putting up with Amazons BS, Surfboard great swords in a game that is supposed to be realistic, you tell me i'm being forced to go to the same place that I deleted a rich, exploited character in the first place? I'm done with your shit amazon. There's better games that wont lie to me. That alone is enough for me to leave this shitshow behind.

Season 7 introduced NOTHING new and is leaving current players wanting new content. AGS should not be allowed to continue work or stay in the gaming industry in their current state. 2000 hours wasted. Don't give AGS your money. They wont do anything with it.

The game had incredible potential, but those lazy and blind devs just killed it. It¬¥s slowly dying and in my opinion nothing can revive it for more than few weeks. Lack of content, (really) slow bug fixes and stupid decisions killed the game. But yeah, for first few hundred (maybe 150-300tops) hours it¬¥s so amazing game. But after you reach endgame and good gear you will see what i¬¥m talking about. I love it but i just can¬¥t recommend the game, it will be dead soon.

After putting in over 2000 hours playing during launch and various times throughout game, I can safely say the game has a great concept, but AGS has ruined this game. 

Between a lack of any good new content for years (hey we get a new OPR map after three and a half years which is the exact same game play as the original with more PvE to do, because that's what we want in a PvP match is to cut down more trees and stone nodes to build a bridge we can easily just run past to get to same area? for real? lol). 

Heavy restrictions on already time gated seasons, (looking at you PvP server with random dungeons during a short duration season) you cannot easily attain the better gear for pvp/pve unless you have people to run with daily, at one item a week if you craft the item, this hurts new players largely with legacy servers being incorporated with fresh start servers in OPR matches. should have never allowed this and kept legacy with legacy and fresh starts vs each other since you now go against fully geared people on a fresh start server makes no sense and some games you just get utterly steam rolled by said geared players.

Waiting is this games literal end game as their is no end game except waiting for next weeks dungeon or Gorgons/Worm raid and talking politics in Global, most the dungeons are not difficult unless you get to the higher Mutated levels and even then its simply gear based, not a challenge of difficulty.

 Weapon balancing in this game is near non existent, with clear favoritism towards some weapons, firestaff specifically being a busted weapon with little balancing since start of game where 50% of your matches are going to be one weapon being spammed by players who kill you in two hits simply due to burn damage not skill which makes PvP in this game very mundane and not fun. 

Wars in this game are also boring and buggy and need some form of change, the open field aspect is okay, but not ideal since it just promotes blob fighting on a capture point. The respawns have also been broken for some time making losses much easier simply due to the game not loading your character after 45 seconds which is insane even on a high end computer.

The recent changes to TTK have also ruined the skill base aspect of this game for PvP making it simply who can hit who first and do the most damage with their styles (or burn), its no longer having to time abilities to try and work thru that heal pot to kill a person or land your abilities in good order, just smash and go which is a sad state for this game with how it was designed for PvP being technical combat, now its lack luster.

Is this a good game to kill time with? sure, is it worth any of the hype around the combat or endgame? No as the combat was recently gutted and end game is non existent unless you like to afk in towns or spam Out Post Rush with a majority of firestaff and musket players. 

Will many stick around due to this games end game or combat? Highly doubt it.
