Avant ce qui suis je pr√©cise que je tourne sur les MMORPG depuis 2004 en ayant commenc√© sur le magnifique Guild Wars. Ne vous √©tonnez donc pas si vous me trouvez exigeant voir excessif.

Alors voil√† j'ai pas mal d'heures sur New World comme vous pouvez le constater. Force est de constater que le jeu est tr√®s beau et fluide √©galement. Bref il est nickel sans demander une configuration de malade.

Je commence par la cr√©ation du personnage. Elle est assez simpliste contrairement peut √™tre √† TESO certes. On se sent n√©anmoins un peu limit√© en terme de Gabaris voire dans l'√¢ge de votre personnage. Par contre pas mal de tronches sont originales :).

On arrive donc au jeu proprement dit. Vous avez droit a une petite intro d'initiation sympa √©galement.

L'originalit√© de ce jeu est qu'il n'y pas de classes proprement dites. C'est vous qui d√©finissez vos capacit√©s avec le d√©veloppement de vos armes et la gestion de vos points de comp√©tences.

C'est pas trop mal, en gros vous pouvez choisir un peu de r√©sistance en boostant vos PV au d√©triment d'autre chose certes mais √† vous de voir. Le seul point un peu n√©gatif √† ce syst√®me peut √™tre est que le d√©veloppement d'une statistique (par exemple la force), aurait pu peut √™tre offrir des choix √† effectuer malgr√© tout. On a le sentiment d'une grande lin√©arit√© h√©las. Facile √† dire certes j'en conviens. Ce syst√®me se rapproche un peu de celui de Guild Wars I en tout cas :).

La grosse originalit√© de votre personnage vient alors du fait que contrairement √† la plupart des MMORPG, donc Guild Wars bien s√ªr, vous devez conna√Ætre un maximum de passifs et peu de comp√©tences actives.
Ma√Ætriser vos choix en terme de d√©veloppement d'armes revient donc √† bien conna√Ætre ses passifs dans un premier temps (oui je sais TESO le fait aussi). Les comp√©tences actives ont en revanche de longs cooldown : il faut donc les utiliser avec parcimonie. Why not apr√®s tout? cela change des jeux ou ils faut spammer comme un malade ses touches.

Bravo donc. En revanche je tenais √† dire que toutes les statistiques n'offrent pas le m√™me volume d'armes et que certains manques existent depuis le d√©but. Eh oui, si vous jouer la caract√©ristique du soin par exemple, il vous sera difficile de'avoir le choix avec une autre arme r√©ellement sauf celle en d√©g√¢ts du vide ce qui est paradoxale un peu pour un soigneur. Ceci alors qu'il manque certaines comp√©tences de protection pour votre groupe d'une part, et de gestion de dps √©galement d'autre part. Ne vous √©tonnez pas de crever si vous p√©ter votre aggro en levelling. Ne vous √©tonnez pas de mettre un temps fou √† tuer des mobs. Certes c'est le levelling et le farming mais √ßa compte pas mal dans ce jeu. Un b√¢ton de protection avec un l√©ger support de soin ou un b√¢ton de combat aurait pu compl√©ter cette situation par exemple.

Voil√† en ce qui concerne le personnage! Passons au contenu maintenant.

En terme de taille du monde je dirais que trop de cartes sont ax√©es sur le leveling. Une fois fait vous aurez peu de zones HL h√©las. Peut √™tre qu'on en a pas besoin d'une multitude certes. N√©anmoins TESO g√®re cette contrainte tr√®s bien certes. Peut √™tre que les d√©vs ont √©galement quelques id√©es √† ce sujet mais bon ...

En terme de de m√©tiers un nerf appr√©ciable a √©t√© fait. Avant il vous fallait une √©ternit√© et des trains entiers de ressources pour up. Je souligne que c'√©tait peut √™tre la volont√© de d√©part des devs d'atteindre les plus hauts niveaux difficilement accessibles ce qui n'est pas en soit une mauvaise chose pour rallonger la dur√©e de vie de leur jeu. C'√©tait un risque commercial peut √™tre √† revoir dans sa conception certes. D'o√π le nerf actuel. Mais j'appr√©cie l'originalit√© une fois encore.

C√¥t√© JcE, le jeu √©tait tr√®s pauvre au d√©part car l'orientation JcJ devait dominer le jeu.  Encore une fois ce f√ªt un choix risqu√©. En effet beaucoup de joueurs aiment profiter d'une initialisation √† leur rythme, jouer p√©p√®re dans leur coin ou avec des potes aussi. Quelques zone instanc√©es ont donc enrichie un peu le jeu.

On arrive au JcJ le coeur du jeu. Vous pouvez d√©cider ou pas d'activer le JcJ sauvage et √ßa c'est une bonne chose. Quoiqu'il aurait pu √™tre obligatoire dans certaines zones HL why not ... Cela n'a pas √©t√© abord√©. Passons aux ar√®nes (les d√©ferlantes). Sympa comme dab dans tous les MMORPG. PAr contre le syst√®me central qui consiste √† conqu√©rir des territoires est nul de chez nul. Grosso modo vous arrivez sur un champ de bataille √† r√©surrection infinie. Le champ de bataille lui m√™me √©tant pas ouf. C'est une bataille rang√©e entre deux groupes. Je r√©sume sec et comme tous les jeux JcJ actuels... c'est hors classement donc les d√©butants n'ont malheureusement aucune chance. Peut √™tre aurait il mieux valu cr√©er des serveurs en fonction du niveau JcJ qu'en fonction des pays. Facile √† dire encore une fois j'en convient. Mais ne vous √©tonnez pas de voir du frenchy sur de l'anglais sur le canal de discussion √† la base... Sans compter que le nombre de territoires est limit√© et donc que donc peu de guildes peuvent poss√©der.

Quand √† la guilde sa cr√©ation est simpliste et les modes de recherches tr√®s limit√©s en terme de param√®tres voir inexistants. Petite d√©ception de ce c√¥t√© l√†.


Conclusion : J'ai √©t√© long mais exaustif du moins je l'esp√®re.
New World offre pas mal de bonnes choses, certaines originales aussi. Par contre il faut reconna√Ætre que ces tentatives se sont heurt√©es √† un public qui est justement vari√© comme toujours. Le coeur m√™me du jeu √©tant lui m√™me confront√© √† ce probl√®me. Le nombre de serveurs √† donc litt√©ralement fondu depuis le d√©part refl√©tant ainsi la baisse du nombre de joueurs pr√©sents. J'ai cependant mis une note positive car c'est peut √™tre le meilleur MMORPG du march√© actuellement malgr√© ses carences & d√©fauts.

As a long-time "on-and-off" player of Old School RuneScape (OSRS), I find myself returning to a game that has had its ups and downs. While it's easy to understand why some players might harbor frustrations due to its rough past, the direction the game is heading in gives me hope. The future feels bright, and I‚Äôm optimistic about the updates and changes promised by the developers.
One of my favorite aspects is the skill progression system. It's something that OSRS players can easily relate to, and it brings a sense of nostalgia while introducing some fresh concepts. Just like in OSRS, the game offers a chance to chill and grind skills at your own pace. Whether it's the peaceful and meditative act of cutting trees or mining ore, or the more intense action involved in expeditions and special in-game events, there's something for every type of player. You can choose how involved you want to get, making it incredibly accessible to all types of players.
PvP, though somewhat minimal at the moment, is another element I keep an eye on. While the current PvP offerings aren't as extensive as some might like, the game has shown a clear focus on improving this aspect with upcoming updates. For players who enjoy the thrill of combat and competition, these upcoming changes could offer a lot more depth and excitement.
It‚Äôs always been my belief that this game has potential for a thriving player base, if only more people gave it a chance. The world feels alive with possibilities‚Äîthough I‚Äôll admit, it‚Äôs hard not to imagine what it would be like if the cities were as bustling as they were a few years ago. Still, the community is welcoming, and there's always the promise of new things to come, with future plans looking solid.
While the game has certainly had its struggles, its future prospects give me hope. For anyone who enjoys the journey of skill progression, the balance of casual and intense gameplay, and the potential of the game's future updates‚ÄîPvP included‚ÄîI‚Äôd highly recommend giving it a try.

*reviewed as an MMORPG Rather than an Action Role playing game due to game not changing enough to define it as a different genre after re release*.Despite putting as many hours as i have and continue to put into this game, i cannot in good conscience recommend this game to new players. Prospective players would likely see their money wasted on a game bound to a slow death should development not take a fundamentally different direction on the way they approach maintaining, and adding to their product.


COMBAT: Most players relate the combat To Dark souls games. Dodging/Blocking is essential for late game activities. A light medium or heavy armor rating either improves suitability at a severe cost to damage, or increase damage significantly at the cost of survivability, or something in between with medium. There are currently 15 weapon types, each with a Skills tree with 6 abilities to choose from, only being able to have 3 active to use for each weapon.

LEVELING: The new player experience is mediocre despite being improved from launch, adding more cinematic, and voiced dialogue. The leveling experience is usually enjoyed right up to about level 45/65, Where things start slowing down. When you get to max level, You will likely find yourself in a weird position where you still have about 10 hours of Main story quests you have to do to fully unlock everything you need to do (brimstone quests and elysian Wilds). The rewards of doing these quests aside from heart-runes, is not comparable to what you can get from chest runs, and dungeons, leaving it to feel like "Busy work".

CRAFTING: Trade skills range from level 1-250 and require refining and gathering skills to craft gear, or consumables. Crafting starts out extremely rewarding. using the items you've gathered in the world from chests and gatherables, you can craft fine tuned armor at an early level that will be far better than any dungeon or quest while also getting good experience. This changes around level 35 items, as you start requiring so many resources to craft just one item that it is far more efficient to level up by doing dungeons, and use the gear from that instead. New world requires the previous tier resource to craft the next one. with there being around 5-6 tiers of gatherables, it can require a mountain of the most basic resource to craft one tier 6 resource. for example, It requires about 20,000 Stone (Tier 1) to craft 1 Prismatic block (Tier 6). You get about 20-30 stone per rock you mine, with each node taking about 4-5 seconds to mine.

ENDGAME: End game is difficult for new players in the sense that many resources/gear that you need to progress to the next level of content is either timekept by the game, or gate kept by the community. Timekeeping in new world consists of items that are needed to upgrade good gear to the highest Gear score they can be can only be purchased one per day. You need 3 to upgrade one item which means it requires a new player 30,000 Gold (players get about 5-6k per day if they run the minimal amount of dailies) and a minimum of 3 days in order to upgrade ONE armor piece. veteran communities largely dont like to run endgame content, but farm it. they want groups that already have the best possible gear in the game to run the raids that drop the best gear in the game. This has been a problem of the community since new worlds conception, With Groups requiring an Average 625 gear score to run the only dungeon that drops 625 gear score items back during launch for example. As a veteran player that already have the necessary items to be "christened" for Raid runs, it is not a problem for me, but is a problem for newer players that i wouldn't wish upon anyone trying to just casually enjoy a video game.

PVP: New world has a ridiculous skill ceiling for pvp. some of the best items in the game are locked behind a PVP level experience. Players have to have a minimum of 30 hours of PVP in order to start getting some of the Best PVE items in the game. Yes you have spend Copious amounts of time in PVP to get PVE items.

SUPPORT: This is my largest Criticism of new world. Amazon Game Studios (AGS) has grossly failed to provide support or updates for their game in an efficient manner. AGS mostly releases new "Content" and bug fixes once per business quarter (3 months). The first month most player have already digested what new content there was, leaving 2 months of virtually nothing entertaining to do in a game. Even worse, New content may be bugged, or exploitable. Rather than fixing it on the spot, AGS normally doesnt fix it until next update cycle (3 months) or if it is really bad, will disable the content for 3 months. No matter the Developer, Bug fixes should be dished out weekly, or at worst, monthly. Items or content shouldnt be disabled for months. There are smaller indie developers that are providing more content, and support than AGS by a long shot. demands from the community that are practically unanimous are not seriously considered. Since launch, the communities have demanded mounts to reduce boring travel. it took AGS 2 Years to implement mounts into the game. This has grown the veteran community that still believes in the game to grow bitter and foul in temperament towards development and other players, and is understandable.

WHAT I THINK NEEDS TO CHANGE: 
NEW WEAPONS
WEAPON BALANCE (Make all weapons viable in moderation to a group composition)
WEEKLY BUG FIXES
MONTHLY UPDATES
EXPANSION EVERY YEAR (Not a "Re Release")
CHANGE PVP TRACK TO A PVP SHOP (Allow player to purchase items they want once a certain pvp level has been reached)
MAKE PVP ARTIFACTS THAT HAVE PVP ONLY UNIQUE PERKS. (PVE players shouldnt be forced to grind PVP for hundreds of hours to get a BIS Items for PVE)
MAKE HATCH/FORGE RAIDS 710 GS ITEMS TO GIVE NEW PLAYERS BETTER GEAR FOR THEIR FIRST HIVE RUN
SIMPLIFY REFINING (Either eliminate need for Refining Reagents, or remove intermittent refining resources like steel, rugged leather, and sateen)
SIMPLIFY CRAFTING (Less requisites to make 700GS items. Have options for 725 GS crafting aside from raiding schematics)

CONCLUSION: New world has a great foundation in a corrosive environment. AGS laid out the groundwork for an amazing game, but have left it to slowly rot away to the point that it has lost 98% of its player base (Peak concurrent 900,000. Now is 9,000-10,000). AGS needs to pull a 180 in their vision for the game, or sell the rights to somebody who will if they hope to restore faith in the player base or for more players to invest in the game.

Before i got hooked on this game i had previously bought and returned it. They recently came out with season 7 which forces open world pvp after level 15. And while that can sound intimidating for people who aren't big on pvp, Imo pvp is what separates this game from the rest. It forces you to interact and mingle with other players, which makes it feel like an actual mmo. Without open world pvp the game is just another single player hack and slash rpg lite, gathering sim with a Morbius tier main story that takes forever. 

Gathering is more risky but rewarding. Somebody else taking your farm? Wipe them out. Bots are somewhat reduced because it legit is a slaughter fest out there. People are more social on the pvp server too. Wow classic forces you to engage with other players by making the over all pve content difficult. When you're in the open world in NW and you hear the ping of another player mining ore while you're a newbie, you'll be on the edge of your seat, hiding in a bush prone to make your nameplate invis.

Over all if they keep a pvp server game is 9/10 near perfect just needs more content

A Complete Trainwreck ‚Äì Stay Far Away

New World is one of the most mismanaged, broken, and incompetent MMO disasters ever released. Amazon Game Studios has proven time and time again that they have no clue how to run an online game. Instead of fixing the countless game-breaking bugs, they apply half-baked patches that create even more issues, making the experience progressively worse.  

The customer support is a complete joke. Any appeal or complaint is met with lazy, automated responses, showing absolute disregard for the players. Unjust bans and penalties are handed out without proper investigation, while actual cheaters run rampant. The enforcement is nothing but a biased, inconsistent mess.  

Gameplay-wise, the grind is tedious, PvP is horrendously imbalanced, and PvE is uninspired and repetitive. The economy is a disaster, plagued by exploits and AGS‚Äôs sheer incompetence in managing in-game systems. Server populations are plummeting because players are sick of dealing with the same nonsense over and over again.  

New World is a sinking ship, and AGS is too clueless to fix it. Save yourself the frustration‚Äîdon‚Äôt waste your time or money on this dumpster fire.

A Disastrous Mess ‚Äì Amazon‚Äôs Biggest MMO Failure

New World had so much potential, but Amazon Game Studios has completely mismanaged it from the start. What was once an exciting MMO quickly turned into a frustrating experience filled with game-breaking bugs, imbalanced mechanics, and poor developer decision-making.  

The customer service is abysmal‚Äîany appeals or reports are met with copy-paste responses, showing a complete lack of care for the player base. Instead of fixing long-standing issues, AGS applies blanket penalties without proper investigation, punishing players unfairly while ignoring their own mistakes.  

The game itself is plagued by constant exploits, bot infestations, and a broken economy. Patches often introduce more problems than they solve, and AGS has failed to listen to community feedback. Server stability is still a major issue, and content updates feel half-baked and uninspired.  

After investing countless hours and money into this game, I can confidently say it‚Äôs not worth it. New World is a textbook example of wasted potential, and unless drastic changes are made, it‚Äôs only heading toward an inevitable decline. Avoid this mess.

Simply put: This game has the elaborate graphic environments, gear, crafting system and quests similar to Everquest 2 with a combat system similar to Elden Ring. Since these two are my personal favorite games, a combination of both is surreal.
Excellent colorful, realistic looking forests and environments. Combat system looks real and not overly flashy with lights or sound. Accurate dodging and targeting system, both for free-ranged shooting or target lock. Armor system allows you to choose heavier armor for defensive benefits, or lighter armor for offensive benefits. Three dimensional landscape with hills, towers, castles and valleys with many rocks or walls that are climbable. Suited for Solo play early game or group play in end game. Multiple quests that guide adventures and a developed crafting system that aids the ability of players to sell their crafted goods or loot discovered.

The only thing that could be added or that I haven't discovered yet is scaled leveling to allow anyone to join any group quest or raid.
Also, to aid players to form groups - an added tool that allows players to see the names of others who are on the same quests to join them for completion. This would be exceptional if there were several lower level questlines that required groups to take down bosses as the final sequence of a questline tailored to their preferred class.
A single pet bot that fills a specific role (healing, ranged dps, tanking) could be helpful in early levels to help players learn how to be good at their role in a group. These pet bots could be banshed when entering a group only instanced scenario.

Improving crafting: adding specific items that can only be crafted, but that strengthens healing,  defense or offense incredibly - benefits only available while in a group or raid. These added crafted effects or items could not only aid in these performance areas, but could change the look of the player when the effect is in force: i.e. - the tank gets larger, the healer glows with white light, the wizard burns or is surrounded with ice, and the rogue or archer is cast in moving shadows. This would help in locating specific individuals in the chaos of a large raid.
A side note: I don't know if the developers will actually read this, but hey great job. Phenomenal looking game, smooth action and awesome replay ability across several classes. I just wish there were more abilities to acquire! :)

It's an interesting but weird (in a bad way) game. I like the lore and the skill systems, but the questing is implemented in a bizarre way.

If you play the main quest, hit up sidequests along the way, do crafting (ie just play the game), you'll hit 40 in a fairly short period of time. Not a big deal, except that the main quest still has you in the lvl20 area. As it's been 2 years since I last played, I started a new character. 40 hours in, and my new character is lvl 56, but the main quest has *only just* moved me into Brightwood, a lvl 26-35 zone. The questline is just so completely out of whack with the leveling.

Add to that with the usual MMO bullshit that "the game begins at 60"(even though you still won't have completed the main quest, which is required to unlock certain class abilities), and it's an extremely isolated experience playing the game. It's very pretty, but it's just... a shit experience.

Don't let the reviews turn you from the game. The graphics are good, the world is vibrant, the details are amazing. There are many things unique to this game, from playing music (like a DDR mini game) to the FFA pvp areas that I usually dislike. The soundtrack is amazing.  The voice acting is ok, even if the quests are a bit stale. My only gripe is the story which is not bad but not on the level of FFXIV. 8.5/10

You've seen a lot of reviews saying that this game sucks, or the devs suck. Both of these things are true in many ways. This game is broken more often than it's working, sometimes in little ways, sometimes in game-breaking ways. It can be a frustrating game in that regard.
That being said, the leveling experience in this game was the best I have experienced in any game of this kind. It has the usual "go here, get/kill thing, come back" quests, but this game's world is truly a treat to walk through and explore.
My real bread and butter, though, is the skilling. Oh my god, the skilling. I'm an on and off OSRS player, so skilling is kind of my thing, and this game feels like the modern iteration of that. The crafting and collecting skills tie together so well, and watching the numbers go up is so satisfying. That, coupled with the absolutely S-tier sound design in this game makes leveling the best part of the game, for me.
Some people love the combat in this game, I think it absolutely blows. It just isn't good or deep, and feels jank. At least in PvE, it kind of just comes down to who's number is bigger. Spam left click, use abilities when they recharge, repeat. There's a bit more too it than that, but I really don't think that it's anything to write home about.
I have reached the endgame, but it just wasn't for me. I found more fun in making another character and starting over from the beginning, rather than playing the endgame. It relies a lot of PvE content that I just don't find fun, as I said before.
I would not get this game at full price, especially if you're on the fence. But if it's on sale for 40% or 50% off, I would definitely grab it.

the crafting especially is just the worst thing to get into if you love doing that in MMOs, the resources are hell to fight over when its first come first serve and bots run amok stealing them all hours at a time. add into that the need for buff food, 3 buff trophies in 3 houses all costing a fortune when gold is just not farmable like it would be in other games, meaning the "player based economy" is just a couple super rich companies and rich people who play the market without actually using any of the materials, you need a full set of the trade skill clothing too, which has low drop rates from sometimes boss enemies you need friends for.

game breaking bugs have, in the past, ruined the game completely for loads of people. from whole storages being deleted, characters going missing... and the worst ones being the bugs with weapons/armour that affect PvP in horrible ways, like the dreaded machine gun musket back in the day causing havoc.

this game could be fantastic
if only the devs stopped trying to make it feel like a second job to play and focused more on making it more fun for players.

New World: A Promising Experience Ruined by Poor Security and Support 

I should have written this review when it happened, but honestly, I was too pissed off. Even now, thinking about it makes my blood boil.

I was beyond excited for New World. I pre-ordered it, jumped in at launch, and put in about 20-30 hours before taking a short break due to work. When I tried to log back in, I was hit with a nightmare‚Äîmy account had mysteriously racked up over 100+ extra hours while I was away. Turns out, my account had been hacked. But instead of Amazon helping me recover what was stolen, they permanently banned me for something I didn‚Äôt even do.

Let me be clear: Amazon's account security is a joke, and their customer support is even worse. Despite explaining the situation, I got zero help. They refused to lift the ban, completely ignoring the fact that my account was compromised. So not only did I lose access to a game I PAID FOR, but I was punished for Amazon‚Äôs own security failures.

Amazon‚Äôs refusal to properly investigate or assist legitimate players is disgusting. If they actually cared about their customers, they would have better security measures and a support team that does more than copy-paste responses. Instead, they let hackers run rampant while punishing paying players.

If you're thinking about playing New World, be warned‚ÄîAmazon doesn‚Äôt care about you, or your account , its all about money. And if something goes wrong? You‚Äôre on your own.

I reached the main endgame content, and honestly, it felt less like an achievement and more like a relief to finally be done with the grind. After the re-release, the game continues to struggle with issues related to Easy Anti-Cheat (EAC) and problematic algorithmic bans. I've additionally noticed more performance impacts, game stuttering and other issues. I can't go into much detail here on the findings without risking account penalties, but it's poorly implemented.

In short, New World isn't worth your time or money. You're better off watching highlights from streamers than playing the game yourself. Additionally, the inclusion of kernel-level anti-cheat‚Äîregardless of the vendor‚Äîadds another layer of frustration, security risks and leaves a negative impression.

Title: A Dev Team That‚Äôs Set the Bar for Incompetence - AGS is Failing Hard

It‚Äôs honestly wild how bad things have gotten with the dev team at AGS. If you‚Äôve been keeping up with New World or any of their games, you know the struggle. The patches, the hot fixes, the constant broken systems ‚Äî and yet, they NEVER take responsibility. You would think after multiple issues and glaring bugs, they‚Äôd finally acknowledge their mistakes, but nope.

Let‚Äôs start with the most basic problem: Patches that induce 'Exploits'. Time and time again, AGS releases a patch, and what do we get in return? New exploits or bugs and more bugs. 
Every single time! Instead of fixing what‚Äôs broken, they seem to just move the problem around. I'd dare say some of the bugs are critical components to the game, and what do we get from AGS? Crickets. No apologies, no official statements, just a lack of accountability. It‚Äôs like they don‚Äôt even care that players are not getting the service the paid for months on end.

We‚Äôre talking about game-breaking bugs that affect the economy, PvP, and overall player experience. People exploit bugs, make tons of money, wreck the economy, and then AGS just... Banns everyone and moves on, like they haven‚Äôt just let their community down again. The worst part? They never admit their failures. They just slap on a quick hotfix (Which creates more bugs), hope players forget, and then repeat the cycle.

How can a dev team be so out of touch with their player base? They push changes without proper testing, let known issues persist for far too long (Elemental Band and many known faults), and completely miss the mark on what players actually want. I mean, the game is riddled with performance issues, glitches, and bad balancing (Artifacts that have no purpose), and we‚Äôre all expected to sit back and pretend everything is fine?

It‚Äôs honestly embarrassing. AGS should stop pointing fingers elsewhere and start owning up to their mistakes. How hard is it to admit that you screwed up and actually fix things in a meaningful way instead of doing the same patch-and-pray nonsense? Until they take real responsibility and prioritize fixing the actual game, they‚Äôll remain the gold standard for how not to handle game development.

AGS, do better. The community deserves it.

This was my favorite game a few years back. The graphics and combat are mainly what have kept me coming back. No other MMO in my opinion has combat like this. That being said, they have made some major changes to the game so that they could re release it on consoles as a "new game." I was happy to have console players added to the very small player population. 

Because this was just a cash grab by AGS they didn't actually do anything to change the game. They just added target locking to help controller players, but they allowed target locking for all players. The once fun and challenging PVP aspect of the game has now become a trivial tab target button masher and whoever has the best gear wins. 

Not only was this a major change that made the game not fun anymore, they also decided to introduce seasonal pvp servers. This would be a great idea if this game actually had the player base of any mainstream MMO, but it doesn't. So now the player base is so divided that all of the servers feel empty. 

The economy is completely broken because of the lack of players and on top of that they introduced yet another game breaking weapon along with a change to healing so that this weapon is EVEN MORE game breaking. Yes I'm talking about the "Burnanator" firestaff. It's super easy to get and super easy to make a dominant pvp build with it. The problem is that I don't want to play firestaff in pvp, but I'm already at a big disadvantage playing anything else. How is that supposed to be fun? This game is filled with fun to play weapons and builds, but they aren't viable against someone playing with a broken "meta" build. 

To conclude, this was once one of my favorite games and instead of fixing the endless bugs that have plagued this game since day 1 PC release, they continue to update it with things no one asked for, introduce new game breaking bugs, and overall just make the game not very fun to play anymore. 

I'm sad to be saying goodbye to this game. Maybe they'll redeem themselves in 10 years when they finally release the Lord of the Rings version of this game.

Bought this game when it first launched, played about 500 hours and then didn't touch it for several years. Decided to come back with some friends when the game relaunched and have almost clocked another 500 hours. 

At the moment (Season 7) I think there are too many servers universally. I don't think they are dead like some people constantly claim, but at times it does feel like the players are spread a little thin. Introducing PvP servers with how many people are currently playing the game right now wasn't their best idea. I think its a great idea in theory, or if the game had more players but it does just spread out the remaining player base.

Another thing is that I feel the devs are sometimes a little slow to actually nerf or buff things that need it. That doesn't mean it's impossible to play normal PvP or anything, but rather you will just end up running into irritation a little more frequently.

Deep down I think the devs actually do love this game, and like everyone that is still playing it we want them to have a big win. I just don't think they have quite found their niche yet, but they are definitely getting closer.

Personally I think this is one of the best MMO's that has ever been made. I've played a good many in my time gaming but none of them have felt as good as this one.

Played this game when it first came out, thought Id try to get back into it now that its rebranded and started doing seasons.
Hideously buggy game, very poorly optimized.
Very long loading screens, textures take forever to appear.
Login takes 3+ minutes, finally spawn in town. My character is IN THE FLOOR of the in, below the map. I am one of MANY characters down here, clipped into the floor. 
The exp bar literally cuts off the top of the emblem that shows what level you are.
The Options cog in the top right corner when the menu is opened isnt centered. Not just isnt centered, but is halfway out of the box.
Opening the map takes 15+ seconds.
Entering any town causes HUGE graphical stuttering, as well as lag spikes.
Opening any crafting menu or searching crafting recipes takes 10+ seconds
Overall, the entire game feels like a cheap, mass produced knockoff of the original game, not sure how all these issues got added when they were never present before.
Might try changing some settings around and see if I can fix it, but my specs are well beyond the games requirements, so I highly doubt its me.

Put 95 hours into the game, I feel comfortable saying that the game designer had no understanding of game theory. This is an objective based video game where you will spend two weeks of playing just to get to the actual game (lvl 65 or endgame). During the two weeks, 90% of your time will be spent running between objectives and 10% of the time will be actually playing the game. Need help to understand how to play the game, no worries! The tool tips will pop up as you are fighting something so you either can read it or die to the mob. Everything from the objectives, PvP damage structures, Item crafting organization and overall concept to the game shouts inexperience. The cherry on top, its so buggy it's 50/50 on if it will even let you log in. If you want to be frustrated by a game, just go play League, this one is not worth it.

Ajouter √† √ßa que le farm tr√®s long au d√©but, qui s'est un peu r√©duit aujourd'hui, √† fait que de nombreux anciens joueur avais farm √† mort pour qu'au final leur √©quipement soit au m√™me niveau que ceux ajout√© ensuite, ce qui en a d√©courag√© plus d'un.

The world is beautiful, combat is fun and the quests are enjoyable, if a wee bit repetitive. Armour and weapon design is a bit wanky. I personally hate the huge, great-sword, axe and hammer design but that is a personal preference. Please note that a lot of negative reviews come from the fact that players are actually afraid their game is not gonna last long because of how poorly AGS manages it.

New World had a great potential to become next legendary MMORPG like WoW, and I believe it still has if it‚Äôs ever bought by some competent company.

That said, I‚Äôm having time of my life playing the game. Unlike most of the titles of this genre, it emphasizes the player‚Äôs skill, mobility, and fast-thinking (at least in the end game‚Äôs dungeons and PVP). 

Moreover, New World doesn‚Äôt use multiple skill bars with gazillions of abilities glued to every edge of the screen. The player can equip up to 2 weapons with 3 abilities per item. 

What also surprised me positively, is that the game uses an equipment weight system, similar to Dark Souls titles - you can roll in light garments, dash in medium, and awkwardly dodge in heavy armor (there are also different buffs for every weight type).

While I won‚Äôt go further into the game‚Äôs systems, I would only like to assure new players that there IS a lot to do in the end game - unlike it‚Äôs tried to be proven in some reviews.

I have played this game a lot. It scratched a certain itch for me and I enjoyed the social interactions and friends I've made. 

However, this game has long since run its course. The new hive content was challenging, however - the manner in which they implemented it was awful - particularly combined with the dying population. Essentially it boils down to time gating gear. They provided a promising road map eventually, and I think most people were sorely disappointed with the first season of said road map (based on the game's most recent population). 

I think the development team is incapable of taking this game in a good direction - and in fact, I don't think they want to. They released a bunch of ridiculous skins and obvious cash grabs, while making changes detrimental to the gameplay of the average player and exceedingly disrespectful of their time. I advise everyone to ignore this game.

I played the beta before launch and then, of course, played on launch. The game had so much promise. The combat is player controlled vs combat like WoW where it's a race to mash the most buttons. The diversity in weapons was cool and I enjoyed the PvE and PvP combat. The Companies was a great idea with being able to conquer territory through PvP events, declaring war on other factions, and setting taxes and fees on crafting and refining to fund the Companies. I thoroughly enjoyed that. It gave the Companies purpose instead of just being a purely cosmetic social hub like most other MMO's, even if it makes it easier to group for raids and dungeons.

The main story was alright at first, then they introduced a more in-depth campaign with more cutscenes and cinematics to drive the narrative and make it more immersive. I thought that was a good improvement. I also thought more waypoints to fast travel was a good quality of life update.

The crafting system is one I like. I've dropped this game and picked up primarily for the aesthetic of the PvE and the crafting. It hits the spot in ways other MMO's don't. They made some updates to where you don't really have professions that fall behind. Wood gathering was one that started off the most annoying as it was the slowest grind. You could deforest a whole zone and it would only give maybe half a dozen levels. Meanwhile, your other gathering skills are double, if not triple, that of wood gathering.

What became an obvious faltering point was endgame content. It was severely lacking. There were the two high-level zones, but there wasn't much to do other than the respective dungeons and grind for the mats to craft legendary gear that didn't really mean much since it wasn't necessary to grind in the high-level zones. Eventually, there was more content added, but endgame content being overlooked like that is something that can kill a game as it's supposed to make a difference on how the entire leveling process and playstyle is conducted, whether it be PvE or PvP.

The part that makes me dislike the game is the fact that the devs blocked off First Light, then paywalled it as a "DLC", throwing in a mount and new weapon. Even though it's only one zone, the devs have orchestrated it to where OG players had to buy it twice. I have yet to do so and a mount and new weapon isn't enough to entice me to buy that zone a second time. I paid for it once when I bought the game. I'm not buying it again.

What shows that this game isn't doing as well as AGS likes to believe is that they've had to do numerous server merges as there haven't been enough players to justify the number of servers they first had. To go from what many called "queue simulator" because the servers were bloated to multiple consolidations shows just how far the game fell. Then they rereleased the game when they made it available for consoles, adding a subtitle like it made a difference. All it did was wipe the mixed reviews from the first iteration. Rather than permitting the deception, the players carried the reviews over as to maintain honesty.

Despite the features, mechanics, and concepts that I like, I do not recommend this game. What I personally enjoy isn't enough to endorse the game in its entirety. I'd be doing a disservice to the developers by saying this game is worth spending money on in its current state. We need better quality games, not rebranded mediocrity. I'll probably play it in small increments, but other MMO's scratch the overall MMO itch better than New World ever will at this point. It's a shame. This game had so much potential. I foresee that unless a massive expansion with a rework or a sequel comes out that addresses and fixes what went wrong with this game, it won't be long before they're forced to stop supporting it. With only a handful of servers left, it's seems like an inevitability.

[h3]New World: Aeternum ‚Äì Eine Sch√∂nheit mit Schw√§chen im Detail[/h3]

[b]Grafik und Atmosph√§re:[/b] 
Aeternum ist eine Augenweide. Die detailreichen W√§lder, dichten Nebelschwaden und das stimmige Lichtspiel sorgen f√ºr eine der immersivsten Welten in einem MMO. Das Gef√ºhl, durch dschungelartige Ruinen oder schneebedeckte Berge zu streifen, ist unvergleichlich.

[b]Gameplay: [/b]
Das actionorientierte Kampfsystem bietet ein angenehmes Gef√ºhl, aber die geringe Anzahl an F√§higkeiten pro Waffe begrenzt die taktische Tiefe. Das Handwerkssystem ist umfangreich, aber der Grind ‚Äì insbesondere bei Rohstoffen h√∂herer Stufen ‚Äì kann schnell monoton werden.

[b]PvP und Kriege:[/b] 
Die Massenschlachten um Territorien sind ein Highlight, allerdings von Performance-Problemen und unzureichendem Balancing geplagt. Die Dominanz gr√∂√üerer Gilden schr√§nkt kleinere Spielergruppen oft ein.

[b]Endgame:[/b] 
Hier liegt das gr√∂√üte Problem: Nach Level 60 fehlt es an motivierenden Inhalten. Die Dungeon-Mechaniken sind interessant, aber der Fokus auf Grinding und sich wiederholende Expeditionen f√ºhlt sich uninspiriert an.

[b]Mein Fazit:[/b] 
New World ist eine visuell beeindruckende Reise in eine einzigartige Welt, die jedoch unter wiederholenden Inhalten, unausgereiftem Endgame, schlechtem Balancing und technischen Schw√§chen leidet. Es bietet starke Momente ‚Äì vor allem in der Erkundung und im PvP ‚Äì verliert jedoch schnell an Reiz, wenn die anf√§ngliche Faszination der Welt verblasst.Es ist ein Erlebnis, das eher visuell als spielerisch gl√§nzt.

I don't think Amazon understands what's wrong with this game. I understand the season worlds but the leveling up to 65 is WAY too fast for an MMO. You shouldn't be able to play for two to three days and then be able to experience all of the content in an MMO. Now with seasonal worlds, you can play through the same story, but just faster? The first play through of this game is amazing, I will not lie. Amazon has done an amazing job and ensuring that there is zero replay-ability. Sure you can do it, but why? You don't gain anything new. You don't gain access to anything new. You use the same weapons. It's boring after the first 50-60 hours. Once you hit max level in this game, it just kinda stops for a semi casual player. Grinding skills doesn't feel good, it feels pointless. I honestly can't believe how much fun this game was week 1, just for them to fumble the rest of it. The game is not worth $60. If it goes on sale, play it once through which is all you really can do.

The not so good bits:
- the key bindings feel a little awkward and non-intuitive

Bear in mind this is after just 24ish hours of nothing but harvesting and crafting. I haven't progressed too much past the initial quests... But also, that's 24ish hours of nothing but harvesting and crafting and I am not bored yet.

Play on, lads.

I bought the game last Christmas (almost a month ago), and I've already put over 240 hours into my character. The game is extremely fun. I honestly don't get the bad reviews. I'm having a blast!

The leveling experience is perfect. Not too much of a grind, but not super fast either. There's plenty of stuff to discover while leveling. The mount system is very well made. Crafting is incredible. You can gather almost everything you see around you. The environment is truly beautiful, and the music is also great. The immersion is there. Player housing is a cool part of the game as well. Combat is fun, modern and satisfying. Being able to swap your "class" by changing your weapon is awesome. Dungeon design and boss fights are truly incredible. Mutated dungeons are no joke, but the rewards are worth it. The story is decent enough to keep you interested, but it could be better. I skipped most dialogs but I enjoyed the cutscenes alot. Gearing up, finding upgrades and working on your artifacts and BiS is a fun process. The season pass is also fun to complete, with the "bingo card" mechanic. PvP is fine, but I'm bad at it so I can't really comment.

Of course, the game is not perfect. But, with all the bug fixes and stuff that arrived with Season 7, plus the roadmap for 2025, I'm confident that the game is gonna get even better.

I truly recommend it, but I would probably buy it on sale. The regular price is expensive.

Gamers today are spoiled brats. These reviews are no where near fair. That said, I played in the beta (when it worked) which was pure trash. I played at launch and really enjoyed the game. It is one of the few games like Black Desert Online or Eve Online that allow you to literally waste a day just life skilling or questing or dungeoneering. Your level is the only thing that limits you. What I see in the reviews are gamers that want everything handed to them or don't want to pay money for a game and DLC. It's a good game. So far I have over 400 hours in it and have not been bored once. But this is my opinion and I enjoy a game with tons of stuff to do. I don't care for games where you smash one button until you win and everything is easy. Which, in my opinion based on the reviews, is what gamers want now. Maybe I'm too old and don't mind earning things.

Cependant, ce niveau de d√©tail a un prix : sur un PC gaming datant de 10 ans, le jeu est tout simplement injouable, m√™me avec les param√®tres graphiques au minimum.

2. Gameplay et m√©canique de jeu
Le gameplay de New World se concentre sur un m√©lange d‚Äôexploration, de combat en temps r√©el et d‚Äôartisanat. Le syst√®me de combat, qui repose sur des comp√©tences actives et une gestion pr√©cise des esquives et des attaques, est √† la fois dynamique et satisfaisant. Les joueurs peuvent choisir parmi une vari√©t√© de styles de jeu gr√¢ce √† des armes comme les √©p√©es, les arcs et les b√¢tons magiques.

L‚Äôartisanat est particuli√®rement bien d√©velopp√©, avec un syst√®me complexe qui r√©compense la collecte et la cr√©ation d‚Äô√©quipements. Les factions et les batailles de territoire ajoutent une dimension comp√©titive et sociale int√©ressante. Toutefois, la r√©p√©titivit√© des qu√™tes et le grind n√©cessaire pour progresser peuvent devenir lassants √† la longue.

3. Histoire et narration
Le jeu propose une intrigue centr√©e sur l‚Äô√Æle myst√©rieuse d‚ÄôAeternum, o√π des forces surnaturelles et des secrets anciens attendent d‚Äô√™tre d√©couverts. Bien que l‚Äôhistoire principale offre quelques moments captivants, elle manque parfois de profondeur et de personnages marquants. Les qu√™tes secondaires sont souvent g√©n√©riques, se limitant √† des t√¢ches classiques comme √©liminer des ennemis ou collecter des objets.

4. Bande-son et ambiance sonore
La bande-son de New World est immersive, avec des compositions orchestrales qui renforcent l‚Äôambiance myst√©rieuse et √©pique d‚ÄôAeternum. Les bruitages environnementaux, comme le vent dans les arbres ou le cliquetis des armes, contribuent √† l‚Äôimmersion. Cependant, le doublage des personnages est minimal, ce qui peut diminuer l‚Äôimpact narratif pour certains joueurs.

5. Dur√©e de vie et rejouabilit√©
New World offre une dur√©e de vie impressionnante, gr√¢ce √† son monde ouvert vaste et √† ses activit√©s vari√©es, comme l‚Äôartisanat, les batailles de territoire et les exp√©ditions. Les joueurs investis dans les aspects multijoueurs, comme les guerres entre factions ou le commerce, trouveront beaucoup de raisons de rester engag√©s. Cependant, pour les joueurs plus occasionnels, la nature r√©p√©titive du contenu pourrait limiter l‚Äôattrait √† long terme.

6. Points positifs
Graphismes magnifiques et direction artistique immersive.
Syst√®me de combat dynamique et satisfaisant.
Artisanat et √©conomie bien d√©velopp√©s.
Batailles de territoire comp√©titives et engageantes.

7. Points n√©gatifs
Requiert un PC puissant : injouable sur une machine datant de 10 ans.

Histoire principale et personnages manquant de profondeur.
Difficult√© √† √©quilibrer les factions, ce qui peut frustrer les joueurs.

Conclusion
New World: Aeternum est un MMORPG ambitieux qui brille par ses graphismes impressionnants, son gameplay dynamique et ses nombreuses activit√©s sociales et comp√©titives. Cependant, ses exigences mat√©rielles √©lev√©es le rendent inaccessible pour les joueurs disposant d‚Äôun PC plus ancien, et sa r√©p√©titivit√© pourrait d√©courager certains. Pour les amateurs de MMORPG avec une machine r√©cente, le jeu offre une exp√©rience riche et immersive, bien qu‚Äôimparfaite.

New World is a game that sparks both admiration and frustration in equal measure. On the one hand, it showcases some of the most impressive technical achievements in the MMO genre. Its engine is nothing short of outstanding, delivering breathtaking visuals, seamless landscapes, and immersive environments. The combat system, without a doubt, is the best I've ever experienced‚Äîfluid, engaging, and brimming with potential to redefine action-based MMO gameplay.
But here's the kicker: the brilliance of New World is being systematically sabotaged by its own leadership, particularly Game Director Scot Lane. This man seems utterly clueless about what he's doing. For years, the community has been voicing the same issues and offering clear feedback. And what does Scot do? He insists he knows better, leading the game deeper into a quagmire of poor decisions.
Let‚Äôs talk specifics:
1.	PvP Content: There‚Äôs only one Outpost Rush (OPR) map and two arena maps‚Äîand it‚Äôs been like this for years. The matchmaking for PvP modes is horrible you wait way to long for a quick match with randoms. There should be a FFA mode or Team Deathmatch etc.
2.	Story Mode: The story has been reworked multiple times, leaving players to slog through revamped content that lacks coherence or excitement. The recent 40GB update is the worst offender yet, introducing a disastrous PvP server concept that defies logic and alienates the community.
3.	Incompetence on Display: Upon the release of the latest update (21.01.25), players were logging out in droves right after completing the tutorial. Why? Because no one wants to relive the same rehashed story year after year. Scot Lane‚Äôs grand vision for New World is complete garbage‚Äîan absolute train wreck of wasted potential.
The community is unanimously disappointed. No one I know has anything positive to say about the developers, and this speaks volumes about the leadership. New World could have been the perfect MMO, but under Scot Lane‚Äôs direction, it‚Äôs spiraling toward its grave.
Amazon Games, it‚Äôs time to wake up. Either fire this man or prepare to bury New World for good. This update might very well be the final nail in the coffin.
Final Verdict: A flawed masterpiece held hostage by poor leadership. Save yourself the frustration unless drastic changes are made.

I really enjoyed leveling my character and questing and the world is beautiful.  The campaign was engaging and fairly well written.  I recommend the game solely based on that.  I think it was worth the purchase price.  

However, both times I played through the game I felt underwhelmed at end game and stopped playing shortly after.  There just wasn't enough to do to keep my attention and making money was an incredible grind and got old fast.  Doing the same dungeons over and over and over again with folks literally just running through them to get finished and get the money bonus was soul draining after a while.

The faction system and how territories change hands is also incredibly flawed.  Guilds and players pile to one faction and the server remains unbalanced and then dies.  For a non-sweat adult there really wasn't much of a way to participate and not be surrounded by ill tempered rage lords with the social skills of a rock.  Not a pleasant experience.  

There is definitely fun to be had in this game, but my time with it has come to an end.

New World: Aeternum is like moving to a magical island paradise where everything wants to kill you, and you spend 90% of your time questioning your life choices. At first glance, it‚Äôs stunning‚Äîlush forests, sparkling rivers, and epic mountains. But once you start playing, you realize you‚Äôre here for one thing and one thing only: grinding.  

Let‚Äôs talk about the crafting system. Oh boy. You want to make pants? Hope you‚Äôre ready to spend an entire week gathering materials just to sew together some ugly trousers that you‚Äôll never wear because the stats are garbage. And don‚Äôt even get me started on all the random stuff you have to craft just to level up your skills‚Äî99% of it goes straight into the scrap pile. It‚Äôs like they turned a survival game into a full-time job, and the paycheck is disappointment.  

And then there‚Äôs the endgame content, which feels like Minecraft and Skyrim had a baby, but it inherited all the grind and none of the charm. Sure, there‚Äôs stuff to do‚Äîside quests, farming, and building‚Äîbut the loot? Meh. After hours of slogging through endless farming and fighting, you finally get a shiny new item... that‚Äôs slightly better than the garbage you were already using. Woohoo.  

The PvP is fun if you‚Äôre into faction wars and smacking strangers with a giant hammer, but it doesn‚Äôt do much to distract from the repetitive grind. And the side quests? Let‚Äôs just say they involve a lot of killing the same mobs and picking up shiny things like a very violent Easter egg hunt.  

New World isn‚Äôt a *bad* game‚Äîit‚Äôs just a game that demands an unreasonable amount of your time and rewards you with a shrug. If you love grinding, crafting, and farming until your soul leaves your body, then Aeternum‚Äôs got your name on it. But for the rest of us? Maybe just visit the pretty landscapes and call it a day. 6.5/10, would chop wood and regret it again.

Look there are a ton of split opinions on this game and honestly both sides have valid points. I personally love this game and have played it sense the beta test, but it may not be for everyone. 

Now to address some things, yes the game has micro transactions however they are not pay to win, they are mainly skins and cosmetic items, the only slight boost that you can pay for is to unlock premium rewards during season events, when I say "slight boost" I mean you get some better, cooler crafting supplies and extra cosmetics form the premium season event rewards, to note the crafting supplies you get from the premium pass can be obtained by anyone as long as their crafting levels are high enough (it is just extra that you don't need to spend mats to make). As for the lore that really just falls under personal opinion, I personally like it because its unique and interesting due to it including a few cool cultures from history and being set in what i think is the late 1600s, however I can also see a lot of people finding it boring and bland so there is that to consider if your thinking of buying it for the RP. Now for the grinding aspect of this game, I personally think its fine and really quite addicting, I have heard people complain a lot about the amount of time and grinding it takes to reach max levels but looking at it from a gamer perspective what mmorpgs don't take a lot of grinding and time to fully level up crafting skills, I will say tho if grinding is not something you enjoy and it is something you actively despise don't buy this game because there is definitely a lot of it.

The game itself has plenty to do between main quests, side quests, pvp, faction pvp, dungeons, crafting, exploring, world bosses, special events and mat grinding so it is hard to get bored. One of the things I find nice about the game is you can really decide what you want to do day by day and are not forced to do one thing or the other. As for pvp it can be really fun and interactive, I don't personally play the pvp aspect of the game very much but when I do I really enjoy it. One of the most interesting aspects of the game to me is the faction pvp as it adds game politics which in itself is an interesting thing to watch.

One last thing to note before buying this game is if you are hoping its a modern WOW you might as well not buy the game, they are both great games but have completely different mechanics, visions, game play and ideas behind them so trying to compare the two is pointless. I do however recommend this game to people that enjoy mmorpgs as it is one of the best modern mmorpgs that I have found.

[table]
    [tr]
        [td]Playability[/td]
        [td]4/5[/td]
        [td]It isn't hard, and the controls are easy, but some abilities can be persnickety.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Difficulty[/td]
        [td]3/5[/td]
        [td]Does a decent job keeping you away from areas out of your league or that you need others' help with - though sometimes inconsistently.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Graphics[/td]
        [td]3/5[/td]
        [td]Pretty balanced! It's nothing new at the time of my review, but even at high settings, it's also not particularly taxing.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]4/5[/td]
        [td]The music is pretty great and builds a fantastic atmosphere. Overall sound is just all right.[/td]

    [tr]
        [td]Story & Writing[/td]
        [td]2/5[/td]

I was late to the game, as it were, but still pleasantly-surprised. Most of the friends I had were already "done" with it by the time I decided to give it a chance, so I started alone - like most people probably do. I think that this helped to highlight New World's strength as a solo-friendly MMO, and encouraged me to "be social" with my fellow players, though this wasn't overly-necessary.

Finding groups for some of the lowbie dungeon content was hard at times, but while the dungeons are pretty fun, they're neither necessary nor (from my experience) particularly a highlight of the game.
[table equalcells=1]
    [tr]
        [th]BEST[/th]
        [th]WORST[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Easy to start and get into, and the variety of gameplay styles keeps it interesting, if not quite "fresh."[/td]
        [td]You can't quite do [i]everything[/i] alone, and there's very little interest for most veterans for a lot of early group content - so you may never see it.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table] 
[list]
    [*][b][u]In-Game Purchases[/u][/b]: Lots, but largely-unnecessary outside of cosmetics and conveniece.
    [*][b][u]Learning Curve[/u][/b]: Easyish
    [*][b][u]Replayability[/u][/b]: Medium-high; you can keep the same character and (re)try pretty much everything you'd ever want to, though. Pretty much no real need to reroll.
    [*][b][u]Recommended Purchase Price[/u][/b]: $15 or less
[/list]
It has been a long time since I last played an MMO, so I got rusty. New World is very easy to learn and very easy to enjoy. I have put a lot of hours into it, and I am still in love with it

The game initially seemed like a promising temporary fix for a gaming itch...until you try to play with IRL friends. My buddy and I was not told by the game that because we spawned in different starter areas that we would not be able to sync up either for a very long time or ever from what it seemed like. 90% of my 3.8 hour run time was troubleshooting and running back and forth testing, and recreating my primary and only character in hopes to spawn in my buddies starting zone or sync up with his quest zone npc's apparently up to the point where the game told me I made too many characters today and put me in time out for 20hours.
Even worse, playing it on PS5 for a little bit since they had a 4hr free trial....deleting the character before purchasing on steam hoping I can reuse my character name, NOT POSSIBLE. It seems like my character/gamer name I've always used as a primary character name is now forever locked out. 
So with zero characters, and unfortunately no option to get a refund from steam since 90% of my game run time was freaking troubleshooting, I'm uninstalling this garbage.
I shouldn't have given into peer pressure and wasted 60usd and I should of kept playing Palworld.

es un juego con mucho potencial en el que la habilidad como jugador lo es todo. les dejo mis puntos de vista para el que quiera leer , tengo 3400 horas de juego y juego desde su inicio dej√°ndolo varias veces .

PVE : para los jugadores a los que les gusta mucho el pve  , farmeo de materiales y jugar al comercio tienen contenido de sobra por que hay tantas cosas para farmear y vender  y el mapa es gigantesco con muchos recursos.
tambi√©n hay instancias de 5 / 10 / 20 personas con cierta dificultad en el que hay que matar boss sincronizando con las demas personas 

COMUNIDAD :  a los jugadores que les gusta pertenecer a una comunidad  y hacer amigos podran encontrar eso en las companias(clanes) o faccion  en la que se forman vinculos de amistad en donde se habla por horas en discord hasta la noche todos los dias. 

PVP : y a los jugadores enfocados en el pvp que es lo que mas me gusta,  el sistema de combate es muy bueno en el que todas las armas sirven y puedes usar diferentes combinaciones donde demuestras tu nivel de habilidad  y competitividad. tiene varios modos de contenido como arenas 3 vs 3 /  outpost 20 vs 20 / guerras 50 vs 50(companias/clanes)  y pvp open world en donde puedes ir solo o con amigos ademas una isla en el que es pvp todos contra todos con ciertas recompensas en el que matar a alguien en un combate dif√≠cil te da una gran satisfacci√≥n  especialmente si te haces 1 vs varios.
la mayor√≠a de los jugadores que juegan al pvp son muy competitivos y se arman muchas rivalidades  y odio en la que la mayor√≠a de las veces  se termina en amistad ya que comparten el gusto por el pvp‚ô• 
tambi√©n hay un ranking pvp / outpost / arena por si te gusta estar entre los mejores.

les recomiendo que les den una oportunidad a este gran juego en el que si bien tuvieron muchas fallas horribles, mal enfoque y muchas cosas desmotivantes que hac√≠an que cada vez mas gente deje de jugar(me incluyo), aun as√≠ no se han rendido y han pulido cada vez mas el juego y aprendido de sus errores  siguiendo adelante con el paso de los a√±os .
no se dejen guiar por comentarios o rese√±as de gente que solo ha jugado en sus inicios y paso por un disgusto criticando el juego sin parar y sin volverlo a probar o llegar a su end game (ser lvl max no es end game)  no se dejen influir por personas negativas  que van de un juego a otro criticando todo.

y una cosa negativa  de destacar que tiene actualmente es su elevado precio que no da oportunidad a mucha gente de probarlo 
si bajaran su precio mas gente se animar√≠a a probarlo.
pesimo, cada vez que entro pega bajones de fps de 75 a 10 o menos, luego de un rato asi se desconecta solo.
buen juego la actulizacion lo mejor mucho nuevas zonas nuevo equipo buen contenido,

Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game to anyone in its current state. There are ALOT of bugs the devs seem to not care to fix. I like the game and want to play it, however the many bugs make it unplayable trash. For example, literally about the finish the main quest, and after awhile of trying to beat Isabella over and over again, I suddenly get a message saying "Login block, suspicious software or corrupted install." 

 Now I had this problem before. I uninstalled and reinstalled, verified steam files, and no, I am definitely not running anything suspicious. Even restarted PC several times with no change. I gave up and stopped playing for a few weeks. Recently came back to try it and I did not get the error anymore. I thought they fixed it, but after today, definitely not.

The game is real fun; however, after about 50 hours and a week in I suddenly started getting booted from the game every 30 seconds to a minute. If I wait a few hours it will work again,  then after about an hour of playing, I go right back to the game becoming unplayable. I looked it up, and found out that this is a known issue as of Dec 18th 2024 (it's likely an issue with the anti-cheat software the game runs). I really enjoy this game, but I can't stay can't play if I can't stay logged in.

---Update - February 2025 - Game still has an disconnect issue. The game becomes unplayable for random amounts of time (game won't stay logged in for more than 30 seconds). This seems to become significantly worse after large patches for 3-5 days after the patch. I will update again in March. 

March here, Go fuck yourself Amazon. I've done everything on Amazons 4 year old list of not getting flagged by the anti-cheat for no reason. Still can't play the game normally. Always disconnecting. I only play this game because I have friends that do. Do yourself a favor and play go play Final Fantasy online if you need a break from WoW. This game sucks.

I'll make a list

-Game disconnects randomly due to anti cheat - No permanent fix currently available
- The tool tips for items that came out well over a year ago are just incorrect on what they do
- Amazon has systematically removed all methods of measuring your DPS including target dummies. Why? Now everyone uses the same weapon, the rapier, and even more boring they use the same rapier "The Finisher"
- Total shit interface. In other MMO's you can save a prebuilt spec and gear. This game you need to pay for an item set, but that item set doesn't respec you so you'll need to redo attribute points and weapon builds every single time you want to play a different role on the same weapon.
- They disabled fall damage because there's no penalty for death. IE instant teleport if you jump off a cliff. When I finish a quest I just let a mob kill me so I can fast travel for free. Just let me fast travel for free then. How stupid.
- I can just keep going, but I'm bored now. I'll keep bitching about this game in April.

From a title in game it seems I pre-ordered but forgot all about this game. The game isn't subscription based, you pay for what you get.
Anything surrounding the $41 I wont have anything to really say about. It's $41, I'm just not paying it. New World despite some (what I can only assume are) bugs is a pretty alright game. Strong 6/10 for me personally. I like the way the crafting and collection all interweave with each other, I find it humorous to pay rent if you own a house in a town. I enjoy playing a red mage because void gauntlet damage scales with intelligence and focus, thus leading me to use the fire and ice magic. I like being able to wear whatever armor weight I want especially if a certain piece looks stupid. I dislike not having a mount to move faster but I end up getting more resources because of it.
Overall I don't recommend this game though. It feels like it lacks polish and from what I've read they burned the fan base while trying to reach into their wallets.

As a jaded mmo player who is still stuck on memories of vanilla Wow, NW has rekindled my passion for mmo gaming. It has improved alot of its systems and more. Better performance, better story/dialogue/characters, a lot more to do both pve and PvP wise. Even the terrain is fun to jump and climb on, where it turns into a game of super Mario and parkour. However, It is grindy, and this is a hit or miss for players. But it isn‚Äôt like some games where there‚Äôs nothing to do at end game‚Ä¶there is plenty to do. It‚Äôs one of those games where it‚Äôs ok to take it slow, like RuneScape for example. The gear balance is decent for an mmo, unlike some where getting the best gear really puts you leagues above others. To get best in socket gear depends on what you‚Äôre trying to do. I‚Äôve managed to get to a respectable gear level despite 95 hours as I write this review, being able to do content and stay on par with players. 

The community is lively and people talk to each other, especially with the feature of VOIP talking in game. hearing someone talk on the mic in town is funny sometimes and adds life to the world, especially when many MMOs suffer from the curse of toxicity or no interactions. The game has alot of sweats but it‚Äôs not as bad as some other games. But you also have alot of casuals as well, as the community seems to be a bit more emotionally intelligent‚Ä¶maybe not super happy and rainbows like FFXIV but better than others.  I‚Äôve found the community to be gamers averaging around 30 years old, although there are some younger gamers present as well.

On one hand, all the systems smoothly integrate into each other. Crafting has many purposes unlike some MMOs where it becomes an afterthought. There‚Äôs a good balance of both pve and PvP with an emphasis on PvP. The territory control mechanics are alright compared to some other MMOs I played (throne liberty, mortal online, etc)‚Ä¶while gate keeping is a common problem in these open world PvP type games, it‚Äôs implemented here in a way where you don‚Äôt have that issue and many servers have a good balance of healthy PvP. PvP is optional if you wanna keep your flag off but there are some areas where it gets turned on‚Ä¶those are end game areas. It‚Äôs not punishing too much if you do die, unlike some other PvP loot MMOs that are very unforgiving and you lose all your stuff‚Ä¶because let‚Äôs be honest, no one likes their time wasted. I

The combat is some of the most fun I‚Äôve had in a mmo. I‚Äôve phased out a bit from tab targeting and NW makes combat more engaging due to its real time action rpg elements.  You can turn the game into a dark souls game as a melee player or a fps 3rd person shooter if you have the bow musket or blunderbuss‚Ä¶healing is more fun in this game than other MMOs too. 

There‚Äôs so much customization in builds you can do and all the weapons are pretty balanced, although there are some obvious combinations that are very strong‚Ä¶you can make anything work technically depending on if you do pve PvP or both. I‚Äôve spent alot of time theory crafting and it‚Äôs honestly one of my favorite parts of the game. You don‚Äôt have to min max with the meta builds but it is good to still know what they are so you don‚Äôt get too weird with your build and you‚Äôre wondering why it doesn‚Äôt work in some areas of content. I would recommend finding a guild or friends and running content that way so you don‚Äôt fall into pugging with randoms and being succumbed to the usual link gear, gatekeeping aspects. Choose your play style.

Getting to max level doesn‚Äôt take too long (less than a week if you‚Äôre fast). But even the leveling isn‚Äôt a bad experience, as exploring the world, climbing mountains and finding all kinds of things is quite interesting.

The story and voice acting is pretty good. It‚Äôs your typical mmo lore but it does have its own flavor and uniqueness being in a 1700s fantasy theme, which is unique.

If you have a good pc system, the graphics are breathtaking.  It looks pretty good on console too. 

There‚Äôs also a roadmap now so the game is doing pretty well. AGS managed to turn the game around with releasing it to console and fixing many systems.

There‚Äôs a cash shop and some ways to speed up certain processes but definitely not pay to win, although it can get expensive for skins. The game has good default skins so you don‚Äôt necessarily have to use the cash shop. AGS has to support the game somehow, right? You can do everything free if you wanted although the season pass is nice with exclusive skins, bonuses and materials to make life easier and faster. 

I can go on and more but wanted to highlight some of the more talked about points to dispel some confusion. Despite some of the reviews, it‚Äôs a great game but definitely not for everyone. Would I recommend it to a person who has a wife and kids and can only play an hour a day? It would probably take you awhile to progress and there are better games for casual play. Do you have 2-3 hours a day to spare a day or even a couple days a week? You can make it work. You still geta good amount of gameplay out of it if you don‚Äôt burn yourself out trying to get to max level fast‚Ä¶.which for some reason, people feel inclined to move fast. I moved a bit fast myself but I still paid attention to the story and mingled with the community. Just live in the moment and enjoy it. While no mmo will ever replace old mmo gaming, this comes pretty close.

I'm ... disappointed.

There are a number of game mechanics that are awesome and the graphics are really good. I'm disappointed because for all the polish, the couple of pinch points are really bad.

1. Gear drops are 100% random. In 45 levels I've maybe found class gear three times. Everything I'm wearing I've had to make.

2. Classes are very ambiguous. It's almost like, if you put the stats in (and you can respec whenever) and have the gear for a class type, you are now that class. It's a little confusing tbh.

3. The story moves VERY fast. I stopped to do a few side quests and found myself outpacing the main story line by several levels. A little more time collecting the materials to build all my gear due to #1 and now I'm like 15 levels ahead of the main story. Just ... Why?

4. I started this thinking I would have a longer list, but like the games content, it ran out early.

This is one of the hardest Review I have had to do for any game I've reviewed on steam. I have put in just over 100 hours since buying this game about a week ago and I have been enjoying it, for the most part... It's easy to say that for everything I like about the game, there is something about it that I dont like. If you haunt played it you have to go into the game knowing that just about any game that has a PVP focus is going to come with a majority of immaturity. In my 100 hours I have met three people who didnt put out vibes of a teenager trying to seem cool in a room full of adults. There is also NO name restrictions for guilds or characters, so there are a lot of... creative.. Names. The chat system is a cluster, causing people to not know if they're getting a direct message and a lot of the community have the different chats off because of the trying-to-be-cool-teens. However if you do meet someone, make a friend and quest together or take down a giant boss, dungeon or PVP together, like any mmo, always makes the game better.

The war system is a cool, but complicated system, unlike games like conquerors blade where people can just up and take it with numbers.. this game provides lots of stages and gives both sides preparation before one side can overtake the other. It's a steep learning curve, but getting into a Company (Games Guild System) can help with that.

On the topic of companies, I got pulled into one recently and they do not like new people, most people I've interacted with dont.. There are lots of tutorials and websites on the internet to answer questions and I suggest you find them because if you ask a question in this game, you will get laughed at... teens..

But with all its downsides brought on by a not-so-friendly community, If you have friends to play the game with it is a good game.. The structured PVE is fun but doesn't hold you hand like some MMOs, PVP is unforgiving, causing you to focus because one bad move can turn the tide and ruin the match for your team. The questing is hard, but fun.. Picking a class you like and learning to survive with it is great, however, with a no class system you can always switch.

Overall, I wish the community was a little more new friendly, but I, like many others, turn my chat off and enjoy the times when the teens are in school and the game is fun.

A Thrilling Adventure for the Whole Family: New World Aeternum

As a family of five, finding a game that engages everyone can be a challenge. However, New World: Aeternum has become a staple in our household, delivering thrilling adventures and immersive gameplay that we can't get enough of. We play together almost every evening, and it's been a fantastic way to bond and explore a rich, vibrant world.

New World: Aeternum is an MMORPG that takes you to the mystical island of Aeternum, where adventure awaits around every corner. The game's stunning visuals and dynamic environments draw you in from the moment you start. Each member of our family, from the youngest to the oldest, finds something to love‚Äîwhether it's exploring uncharted territories, battling fearsome creatures, or crafting and trading to build our collective strength.

What truly sets New World apart is its versatility. The game offers a wide array of activities, ensuring that everyone finds their niche. My eldest enjoys the strategic PvP battles, while my youngest is fascinated by the crafting and gathering systems. The rest of us revel in the thrill of co-op dungeons and faction wars, often strategizing and laughing together as we take on new challenges.

The community aspect of New World is also a highlight. We've formed alliances with other players and families, expanding our in-game circle and enhancing the experience. The camaraderie and teamwork have made our nightly sessions something we all look forward to.

Moreover, the game developers are constantly updating and improving the game, which keeps it fresh and exciting. The seasonal events and new content ensure that there's always something new to discover, keeping our family hooked.

New World: Aeternum has become more than just a game for us; it's a shared adventure that brings us closer together. If you're looking for a game that offers endless exploration, epic battles, and a chance to create lasting memories with your family, this is it. We can't recommend it enough!
