Summary: I can't recommend this game anymore, but I do respect the good times provided to me, and the people I had the great honor to meet through this game.


 Expanded: I've been playing since testing phases and launch day, and because of that I really got to enjoy the journey of what made this game great and unique as it grew into the game it is now. Cross-play is HUGE for an MMO and I love that they did that. While it didn't launch with the most amazing range of content, it still had a major strength in it's game-play and design by allowing players to experience every part of the game on a single character (Weapons, armor, professions, etc. which rewards your time as a player). I was still able to find creative ways to enjoy the game. For example, I would get together with some buddies, we would invite everyone we could on the server to the middle of a town, and DJ lengthy inner town shows where everyone would be naked and use the fire-staff to shoot flamethrowers everywhere.

 I did my best to keep my love for this game, but it currently can't quite find it's own identity and suffers from trying to copy other Live service methods that are not widely enjoyed or healthy to the game, but more so healthy to keep money into the pockets of the people running the game. Which I wouldn't mind, people need to be paid and servers need to be ran. However, it becomes a sad sight when the primary highlights of content releases for this game take the form of refurbishing old areas and quests, a seasonal pass model that expires even when you have paid for it, and a lengthy list of other smaller issues that add up to discourage enjoyment. The map is a good example, as there appears to be such a MASSIVE amount of map space that is not available yet, and has not been available or given to players except in the form of on expanded region and an already existing zone, refurbished to house the PAID DLC Rise of the Angry Earth. A large list of unreleased weapons being slowly drip fed to players over a ridiculously long time, is also another notable issue.

I'm ONLY giving this game a thumbs up because I had great times in the world of Aeternum, with so many good people, doing all kinds of fun stuff with what was given to us at the time. That being said, with nothing but love and respect to the AGS team, I cannot find any reason to continue spending my time in this game any longer. If there ends up being a huge positive shift in the games direction and expansion, I'll gladly be open minded to the growth and coming back to experience it. The looks good, but feels like a wet noodle. I don't know if its just the overall feel, the music, the writing or all of it combined. Its a strong concept, and the combat is fun, but it has that 'I read this mediocre fantasy novel in middle school, it had conquistadors in it, can't remember what it was called or who was in it.' feel.

Its probably way better than it was before, but I get the impression they made the game easier until end game, much easier. There's no ammo for weapons anymore, lock on for ranged, andit gets easy to overlevel resulting in a kind of aimless 'I'm already more powerful than everything around me, can we please get to the big bad already and kill it.'

Maybe I'm just burnt out on the MMO genre, but the most fun thing was crafting, and I can think of a couple games that do that better too.

Visually impressive, the tone is a Fortnite put on its grown up face, but didn't actually get any older.
Audio is good, with cracks from pickaxes and muskets having properly loud and impactful reverb and depth.
Structurally, the game seems like it went into a blender with a bunch of 'this is what MMOs have, right?' and came out the other end.

Its a mediocre game that may possibly be a great game for someone who finds a good community or really dives into the PVP on the extreme competative end. The rest is just kind of window dressing that looks nice, but has clearly very talented and enthusiastic people behind it accompanied by just as many 'phone it in, this won't be a Game of the Year' people.

It could have been what I'd hoped to get out of Elder Scrolls Online, instead it does the combat one better, and then feels about as hollow as ESO everywhere else. I couldn't really even milk the Hour/Dollar margin out of it fishing, which should tell you what the rest of this didn't.

New World is a game that had the potential to redefine the MMO genre with its unique mix of survival mechanics, open-world exploration, and large-scale PvP battles. The concept is truly genius, offering a visually stunning world and a sandbox experience that could have been a masterpiece. Unfortunately, the execution by Amazon Game Studios is nothing short of disappointing.

From the very first release, New World has been plagued by bugs, many of which remain unfixed to this day. For example, in the Outpost Rush mode, you still cannot see who killed you‚Äîan issue that has been pointed out repeatedly by the community but ignored by the developers. Comfort features are also glaringly absent. Simple quality-of-life improvements, such as the ability to sort items in your inventory or storage by name, are still missing, making inventory management a frustrating chore.

The lack of attention to such basic details is baffling, especially for a studio with the resources of Amazon. While the core gameplay and concept are undeniably captivating, the persistent bugs and missing features make it hard to stay engaged. It feels like the game was rushed to market and then abandoned, leaving players to deal with half-baked mechanics and unresolved issues.

If Amazon Game Studios could invest more time and effort into fixing the numerous issues and listening to player feedback, New World could become the MMO it was meant to be. As it stands now, however, the game is a frustrating mix of brilliance and incompetence.

Final Verdict:
Great concept, poor execution. Proceed with caution if you're considering diving into Aeternum.

The hype train led me to believe that this game was the best thing since sliced bread. It isn't. I'm going to get to max level (65) and then drop it like it's hot. This plays like every other MMO out there with the minor exception of muskets. I queued for the 3v3 PvP Arena and after 48 minutes, I just completed some quests and then exited the game. The story isn't particularly interesting. The main story quests are "go here and kill this boss" or "go there and collect these items". Honestly, there are probably Free-to-Play games that are better than this. 5/10. Overall, this is mid.

UPDATED: 
I paid roughly $40 for this game and it just wasn't worth it. This game offers about 10% of what Elder Scrolls Online does and you can pick that up for 5-10 bucks these days. There is no endgame in New World. No prestige system. No champion system. No reason to stick around. Attempting to queue for group events is a waste of time because of the low player count. This game is already past its Amazon Prime and Amazon needs to convert this to free-to-play or its going to crash and burn. I played 600+ hours of Elder Scrolls Online and... yep, I'm going back. There's nothing of substance here. PvP looks like "shoot musket, roll and dodge, repeat" except for the smoothbrains that brought big swords into a gun game. Might as well play COD then. I would recommend this game if you get to play it for free, but honestly, I have absolutely no idea how people are putting more than 50 hours into this without getting completely bored because the zones aren't even level-scaled. If you miss a zone (and by the construct of the story, you will), do you really want to go and do a level 40 zone at level 60? Wtf? Nope. We're done here. 

This is overrated dogshit. Barely three years old and this game is already dying, and that's in spite of the "refresh". That's terrible for an MMO. Elder Scrolls Online, despite being a 10 year old game, has more concurrent players than this shit. More people still play WOW and OSRS. Yeah... this game never deserved the hype. Suck my balls for wasting my forty dollars. 

Reached Level 65, took one look at the sorry excuse for an "endgame" and gtfo. Amazon Games Studios... more like Made in China Studios, give me a break with this dogshit.

The story is interesting enough to pay attention to the cut-scenes but admittedly I did press skip over a lot of the basic dialogue.

The graphics are great, and there's more quests than I can shake a fist at. If you get into it this game can keep you busy for a metric ton of hours. I've barely even cracked into how many quests there are. You can mix and match weapons and pretty much change up your character whenever you get bored of a play style. Plenty of dungeons to run and if you are into PvP there appears to be a few different ways to play with constant competition over points of interest on the main world map.

I would say the games not great but not bad. Worth checking out on sale if your looking for a good grind to kill some time!

No suelo hacer rese√±as pero esta poronga me salio 42 d√≥lares, y me siento cagado arriba de un puente, asi que voy por puntos:

Dise√±o de mundo / personajes / arte visual: 9/10

El dise√±o de mapa, bichos y armas esta bastante bueno, el equipo de arte se saco la poronga, sobre todo en las dungeon donde tenes tremendos planos y visuales desde bosques, desiertos, corrupciones, sangre, etc.

Optimizaci√≥n: 1/10

El peor juego optimizado que jugue en mi vida, anteriormente dije que el dise√±o del juego esta buenisimo, pero los gr√°ficos no dejan de ser algo parecido al Skyrim, y te va a reventar a pijazos tu PC haciendola calentar como puta ovulando.
El mapa te va a tardar en cargar, vas a ver todo invisible, bajonazos de fps ademas de que tenes que jugarlo de por si todo en bajo, ni hablar de querer poner fps a +60 para aprovechar los 140HZ+ de algunas personas, te explota la pc.

Mundo abierto: 7/10

Tenes varias actividades para hacer, tala, cosecha, cuerear animales, pescar y minar, con sus respectivos niveles (0 a 250).
Tambi√©n podes farmear bichos por sus items como cualquier juegito MMORPG. 
El problema de esto es que:
1) Los mercados est√°n muertos: Ya no sirve farmear nada como deber√≠a servir, ya que las nuevas dungeon del ultimo dlc te tiran los mejores items, dejando hecho mierda el lvlear las profesiones.
2) No te sirve dedicar tanto tiempo a todo lo del mundo abierto, por ejemplo supongamos que lvleamos crafteo de armaduras, el m√°ximo lvl que podes craftear es 700, tardar√°s unas 200hs en conseguir todo lo necesario para ese lvl 700 de armadura, y aun asi, en una sola dungeon del ultimo dlc ya tenes asegurado partes de armaduras de 700+. 

Juego en solitario: 4/10

En este juego no te podes divertir jugando solo, todas las dungeon y eventos importantes requieren gente, porque? No hay build que sea destructora en solitario, no te podes solear bichos fuertes, ni dungeons con poca gente siendo "ultra op", por lo que sumado a lo que dije anteriormente, tener 200hs+ para conseguir todo un set crafteado por vos, no te sirve de nada porque todavia asi, no vas a poder solearte nada importante.

Comunidad: 5/10

El juego en PvE est√° muerto, o si no agonizando.
Llegas a querer pedir gente para hacer una Dungeon y vas a tardar 20m+ en encontrar, si queres mandar una dungeon espec√≠fica vas a estar +40m a +2hs, por lo que jugar solo no es una opci√≥n. 
Se tarda eso porque ya el 98% de las dungeon que existen est√°n obsoletas y no sirven ni dropean nada bueno, solo las dos ultimas de dlc, por lo que la gente abandono completamente estas actividades (que son las mejores como dije mas arriba)

Juego en equipo: 9/10

Tenes rol de da√±o, de tanque, y de healer. Cada uno debe cumplir su rol en una dungeon, hacen lo tipico de estos roles, no hace falta explicar. Si tenes un grupo o amigos este juego lo disfrutas un mont√≥n, siempre y cuando no vayas al pvp donde hay gorditos con +2000hs y equipamiento fulleado para pvp.

PVP: 5/10

Rancio. Se puede spamear un esquive cada 1.5s, y lo roto es todo lo que pegue a distancia. No hay variedad en roles de pvp mas que lo que est√° en meta. Si sos un hijo de mil puta que le gusta jugar armas melee te vas a cagar de aburrimiento jugando guerras o 3v3, vas a necesitar siempre un compa√±ero que pegue a rango ya que si alcanzas a un mago/arquero te empieza a dar saltitos cada 1.5s, te ralentiza y stunean y te moriste. No hay variedad de pvp mas que lo que dicta el juego, como ya dije por la falta de perks/opciones en la armadura/defensa.

en conclusion, es un juego que disfrutas mucho con +3 amigos, sino no lo vale. Con 60 dolares te compras 3 4 juegitos mas divertidos que esto, o te vas al Albion Online.

Am Anfang macht das Spiel wirklich Spa√ü, vor allem in den ersten Leveln. Grafisch kann es definitiv √ºberzeugen.

Die Einf√ºhrung von Reittieren und die M√∂glichkeit, endlich richtig schwimmen zu k√∂nnen (peinlich, aber wahr), waren mit dem Aeternum-Update zun√§chst wirklich vielversprechend. Dazu kamen endlich Cutscenes, die es im urspr√ºnglichen Spiel nicht gab.

Das Kampfsystem hat mir ebenfalls gut gefallen, weil ich es tats√§chlich mochte.

Doch je weiter man spielt, desto entt√§uschender wird es. Es gibt einfach viel zu viel unn√∂tigen Loot und gleichzeitig viel zu wenig wirklich interessanten Content, der einen motiviert, weiterzumachen.

Das Housing-System ist zwar eine nette Idee (man kann sein Haus dekorieren, andere Spieler einladen, hat einen zus√§tzlichen Respawnpunkt und etwas mehr Lagerplatz) aber wirklich herausragend ist es nicht. Wer sich an das Housing-System von ArcheAge erinnert, wei√ü wie es eigentlich sein sollte.

Am Ende f√ºhlt sich alles nur noch wie eine endlose Wiederholung an, ohne dass man das Gef√ºhl hat, wirklich etwas erreicht zu haben. Und versucht mal, als Solo-Spieler eine Gruppe zu finden. Es gibt zwar eine Suchfunktion, aber die ist fast immer leer und wenn doch mal jemand auftaucht tritt niemand bei.

Aus Frust habe ich das Spiel wieder deinstalliert und meinen Charakter gel√∂scht. Die erneut sinkenden Spielerzahlen sprechen f√ºr sich, und ich bin wohl nicht der Einzige, der so denkt.

Firstly I want to point out that any reviews saying you have to buy the game again are wrong. I bought the game once when it launched, paid for the expansion when that came out, and didn't have to pay a dime to continue paying for the relaunch. So those comments are just fake news.

Secondly, you have to take negative reviews on MMORPGs with a grain of salt. There are people who legit get more enjoyment writing bad reviews that offer nothing in the way of constructive criticism than they do from actually playing the games. It reminds me of WoW players who talk all day on their forums about how much they hate the game, yet haven't played anything else for 20 years. With this game, people made their impressions based off its launch (which had problems) and refuse to change their opinion from their, despite all of the progress it's made.

Bottom line, this is a good game. The action combat is fun, the graphics are great, and it has a lot of good systems. It's got a solid player base that's only expanded after cross-platforming with consoles, it's a B2P model with ZERO pay to win features, no subscription, and a lot of great content for both PVE and PVP players. Is it perfect? No. But you shouldn't be swayed away from trying the game because of negative review bots who aren't saying anything in good faith anyway. You can easily sink 1k hours into this game and have a good time and that would be worth the box price alone. In terms of PVP it might be one of the best skill-based MMORPGs out there, and I don't think people have really caught on to that fact yet. 

The game is in the best spot it's been in for a while. Don't judge it from a questionable launch years ago. Aeternum is a good MMO.

Cons outweigh the pros with this game.  

Pros:

1.  Nice art style and graphics.
2.  Audio engineering is great.
3.  Combat system is fun to play for both PvE and PvP.

Cons:
1.  Over all the community is really immature, childish and bad.
2.  Game has baked in design features that encourage poor behavior.
3.  Game does not have baked in features that encourage respectable behavior.  
4.  Twitch streamers / currency vendors put content behind pay walls.
5.  Old school players that know the game gatekeep content, thus hampering the games growth and longevity.  New people may have a rough time with unwelcoming / elitist old schoolers and may very well not get their moneys worth out of it.
6.  Extra charge for expansion if you want to see end game content, or 80 bucks for the full version -- see above.  
7.  Only game I am currently playing that desktop crashes, slows down and has to be shut down in the middle of content, which in turn triggers the immature gatekeepers to behave poorly.  
8.  Over engineered with too many menu's and sub menu's.  World immersion suffers as a result.  
9.  Convoluted upgrade paths for gear requiring out of game research for many people.
10.  Server side disconnects happen too often.  

Can't recommend it.  There are funner, healthier games out there for much less cost.

Now, if you are a soloer and into tradeskilling and don't care about the community content, you could have fun for awhile, but ultimately not worth the purchase prices just to do that.

Let me preface this by saying that I am quite enjoying my time in Aeternum. It is a fun game, but I would not call it an MMORPG. It lacks the most significant elements of an MMO. I would say it's more like Conan Exiles. Is that a bad thing? No, not really.

The game opens with you creating your character and then proceeds with you on a ship in the early 1600s, straight off a port from Amsterdam. Some unspecified time in your journey, your ship crashes headfirst into an ominous looking storm. You fight your way to survival on a burning ship against what looks like demonic zombies and wake up on a mysterious island, in which you are quite literally thrust right into the thick of a story that I...am honestly not even quite sure about. lol 

The strengths of New World is what keeps me coming back, at least for now. 

[b]‚´∑ Graphics ‚´∏[/b]

The assets are very well made, especially foliage and trees and general buildings, and is further enhanced by truly beautiful colors. Everything is vivid and stands out (perhaps, to an extent, to a fault concerning UI), and I truly enjoy just looking at how beautiful the world of Aeternum is. I actually enjoy walking through the woods or sitting atop a mountain top and moving the camera around to catch different angles. 

[b]‚´∑ UI / Interface ‚´∏[/b] 

One of it's major problems is UI. The overall designs are very good. The inventory categories could stand out a bit more with actual dividers instead of "Rewards, Tools" etc etc, but overall, their design choices are fine. The issue is that they seemed to have just stopped at "Yo, we need a good pause menu and inventory". So, basically, there's a general lack of and a few bugs/issues.

Where is the group UI customization options? Why can't I pin members of my group to my compass? Why can't I assign them colors? And why isn't there a minimap? You have to pause and open your map any time you want to track your group or anything at all. 

[b]‚´∑ Sound Effects / Music ‚´∏[/b] 

It's very good. The sound effects at least are incredible. I really love the sound of mining and chopping trees, and love that I can hear others logging or mining if I'm close enough. The sharp TACK it makes at contact is extremely satisfying. The sound of the guns or the animals or the wind etc etc is very good. 

The music is really good, but nothing to write home about. 

[b]‚´∑ Controls / Controller Support ‚´∏[/b] 

I initially played it with keyboard and mouse. I hated it. I really do not know how people are playing the other way, except maybe because for some reason when you play on controller, it super zooms you in. The controller support makes the game feel even more like it's just an RPG game your friends can jump into, because it feels like it was designed with controllers from the start.

[b]‚´∑ Character Creator ‚´∏[/b] 

It's honestly one of the worst out there. You have such a limited range of options. On top of that, all color options are extremely limited too. And even worse, guess what? There's no way to change your appearance later on, not even your hair. Another token into the basket of "Doesn't feel like an MMO to me". 

They need to revamp this shit and fast. The people I got into the game nearly quit right there. More options would help out immediately, and the ability to change appearances.

[b]‚´∑ Combat ‚´∏[/b] 

It's not a TAB semi-stationary target MMO. It's a strange combination of Diablo IV and Lost Ark, I would say. On keyboard, you move with WASD. Q, R, and F are your abilities. The 1 and 2 keys is to swap weapons but strangely the tilda key (~) is "put weapon away" and guess what? You go slower if your weapon is out, and somehow the best option to put your weapon away was ~ key. lol TAB is your inventory. ESC is your pause/bigger menus. Right click = guard and left click is "attack". Don't bother with guarding, it's practically useless. Oh, and space bar is jump.  

You engage combatants as you would in a more action orientated game. You run up to them and can move around and use items and what have you as you fight. Again, a lot like Diablo IV or Lost Ark--or if you played it, very similar to Throne and Liberty.

It's okay. Nothing terrible, nothing spectacular.

(combat feels much better with a controller)

[b]‚´∑ Enemy A.I ‚´∏[/b] 

It's bad. 

The enemies are like rocks that can swing at you sometimes. And frustratingly enough, most of them have absurd speed, so they attack relentlessly. Which isn't hard, just fucking annoying. lol

[b]‚´∑ The World ‚´∏[/b] 

The world is beautiful as I said above, but it's extremely small in the grand scheme of things. Another reason it doesn't feel like an MMO at all. I think what would greatly help New World, is to focus future expansions on new lands. They might have written themselves into a corner with the whole "island" plot but whose to say they can't have our heroes expand their horizons? Maybe they can fall into the Bermuda Triangle next and arrive at Hollow Earth to fight King Kong. lmao either way, expand zones dramatically, or you will 100% see the death of this game.

[b]‚´∑ Story / Lore ‚´∏[/b] 

I honestly have no idea if there's a real story going on here but hey, you can collect lore books!

[b]‚´∑ Crafting / Gathering ‚´∏[/b] 

Of all the MMOs I have played, it definitely feels like "the best". Now, I do think classic World of Warcraft and FFXIV generally have a better crafting environment (in what you can do with it), New World's gathering/crafting is truly a lot of fun. Maybe not fun to fight over nodes, but still so good that I genuinely believe it is the game's strongest aspect. The crafting is also very engaging, and usually requires other gathering professions involved to create things of importance.

It's my favorite part of the game easily. I would say the only way to improve, is to give us more to do with crafting/gathering itself. 

[b]‚´∑ Conclusions ‚´∏[/b] 

I haven't touched PVP or the town management yet, doesn't interest me, but Steam is complaining I can't write anymore, so yeah. 

Overall, a very enjoyable game, but definitely doesn't feel like an MMO to me at all. I'm not sure how long I will play, but I imagine once I beat it, I'll dip, because the world is just way too small to sustain these numbers or interest for long. Give up on those stupid ass seasons and give us ACTUAL expansions.

Get it on a sale if you wanna try it out.

I DO think the game was mostly enjoyable up until endgame, as far as MMO journeys go, and the world feels unique amidst the typical high fantasy stuff we get. New World ist ein MMORPG, das mich auf Anhieb mit seiner beeindruckenden Welt und dichten Atmosph√§re in den Bann gezogen hat. Entwickelt von Amazon Games, entf√ºhrt es die Spieler auf die mystische Insel Aeternum, wo Abenteuer, Geheimnisse und Gefahren an jeder Ecke lauern.

Was sofort ins Auge sticht, ist die Grafik. Die Landschaften sind atemberaubend: dichte W√§lder, schneebedeckte Berge, gruselige Sumpfgebiete und charmante D√∂rfer ‚Äì alles ist mit einer Liebe zum Detail gestaltet, die die Welt lebendig wirken l√§sst. Dazu kommt ein dynamisches Wettersystem, das die Immersion noch verst√§rkt.

Das Kampfsystem ist ein echtes Highlight. Es ist actionbasiert und erfordert taktisches Denken sowie pr√§zise Steuerung. Spieler k√∂nnen zwischen verschiedenen Waffen und F√§higkeiten wechseln, was eine Vielzahl an Spielstilen erm√∂glicht. Ob mit Schwert und Schild, Magie oder einem Bogen ‚Äì jede Wahl f√ºhlt sich einzigartig und befriedigend an.

Die Gemeinschaft spielt in New World eine gro√üe Rolle. Die Fraktionssysteme und Kriege sorgen f√ºr spannende PvP-Momente, w√§hrend PvE-Spieler in Expeditionen und Weltbossk√§mpfen auf ihre Kosten kommen. Besonders die M√∂glichkeit, Siedlungen zu √ºbernehmen und auszubauen, schafft ein einzigartiges Gef√ºhl der Zugeh√∂rigkeit.

Auch das Crafting-System verdient Lob. Es ist umfangreich und belohnt Spieler, die Zeit und M√ºhe investieren, mit hochwertigen Ausr√ºstungsgegenst√§nden. Die Sammelberufe wie Holzf√§llerei, Bergbau oder Angeln f√ºgen sich nahtlos ins Spiel ein und bieten eine entspannende Abwechslung zu den actionreichen K√§mpfen.

Nat√ºrlich hat New World seine kleinen Schw√§chen, etwa gelegentliche Balance-Probleme oder repetitive Quests, aber diese werden durch regelm√§√üige Updates und die aktive Community stetig verbessert.

Insgesamt ist New World ein gro√üartiges MMORPG, das durch seine wundersch√∂ne Welt, das dynamische Kampfsystem und den Fokus auf Zusammenarbeit und Konflikte besticht. F√ºr alle Fans von Online-Rollenspielen ist es definitiv einen Blick wert!

New world √® come andare in vacanza alle Maldive ma essere allergici al sole e al polline. Immaginate di fare un bel viaggio fino al livello 65. Vi state divertendo, il gioco vi prende, tutte le cose che cercavate in un mmo ce le ha new world. Poi arrivate al livello 65 e iniziate a starnutire, ad avere prurito fino a quando realizzate che new world √® la truffa videoludica piu grossa che abbiate mai subito. L'assistenza non esiste, crash continui senza motivo nelle arene con penalita non meritate. Ogni giorno un bug nuovo, che sia grafico o di comandi come ad esempio non poter premere il tasto esc perche il gioco non lo riconosce. Immaginate poi che vi comprate l'antistaminico e delle creme per proteggervi dalle vostre maledizioni e arrivano le zanzare e i serpenti: rimpiagerete di aver acquistato non solo il pack cavalcatura ma anche il gioco.
PRO: 
Paesaggi, Non pay to win, possibilita di avere una casa, poter cambiare classe quando si vuole, crafting decente, dungeon carini, stile di combattimento carino
CONTRO:
Animazioni del combattimento (il tuo pg andr√† avanti con gli attacchi base fino a quando si metter√† davanti al boss e verr√† shottato dando agli altri l'impressione che non hai un cervello), la community √® molto tossica,
Ricompense da fine dungeon o nel pvp davvero squallide, non esistono tutorial per i dungeon o per i boss dei dungeon, le skin-abbigliamento/armi sono davvero orrende, le texture degli npc sono fatte con i piedi, impossibilit√† nel creare un personaggio guardabile perch√© non ci sono personalizzazioni di qualit√† nella creazione del personaggio, dopo che acquisti il pack delle cavalcature per sbloccare devi fare missioni super noiose e se vuoi le cavalcature piu recenti come l'orso devi spendere altri soldi, quindi diciamo che lo stipendio potete canalizzarlo dritto su new world cosi fate prima, il colore nero si paga coi soldi veri e potete utilizzarlo solo una volta xD, ogni giorno un nuovo bug (credetemi ne vedrete delle belle), i tank sono super sbilanciati, si ricaricano tutta la vita e non si fanno niente e se li fate avvicinare vi battono con 3 colpi, i nemici sono solo di 4 tipi (scheletri, zombie, pirati e animali che poverini non c'entrano nulla)
Il gioco vi da l'impressione che potete fare quello che volete come volete e quando volete ma in realt√† diventerete schiavi del meta, guardando tutorial su youtube senza usare la vostra fantasia e finirete per andare in 20 contro 1 e fargli pure il tea bag.

I‚Äôm a 31-year-old casual gamer, juggling a full-time job and other responsibilities. Like many, I can‚Äôt pour endless hours into gaming anymore; I typically manage around 10‚Äì12 hours a week, mostly on weekends. I grew up playing MMORPGs - with fond memories of World of Warcraft - but it‚Äôs been about 12 years since I last ventured into any online world. And let me tell you: New World feels like coming home!

From the moment I stepped foot in Aeternum, I felt a rush of nostalgia. It‚Äôs hard not to be impressed by the breathtaking graphics (especially on my 4070ti) and the combat mechanics that stand out from other MMOs I‚Äôve played. Battles feel dynamic and fresh = there‚Äôs a great mix of dodging, blocking, and timing your strikes. The crafting system is incredibly rewarding; gathering materials, refining them, and crafting your own gear is satisfying and gives you a real sense of progression.

One thing that really defines my New World experience is the friendly community. Despite my limited playtime, I‚Äôve already encountered wonderful players. From teaming up on quests to just hanging out in town, the social aspect of New World is a blast. A highlight for me was trying out the in-game music system with a group of strangers-turned-friends. Sure, we messed up a lot of notes at first, but it was all in good fun and brought back those carefree, joyful memories of my teenage gaming years.

I can‚Äôt speak much on the end-game content because I haven‚Äôt reached it yet, but I‚Äôve heard plenty from higher-level players who are busy crafting, upgrading their gear, running PvP quests, and scouring the world for better chests. They seem to have their hands full, which is a promising sign of depth and longevity for those who want a long-term MMO experience.

Sure, the game isn‚Äôt perfect - but no game is. If we sit around looking for negatives, we‚Äôll certainly find them. However, I entered New World with an open mind, especially after the recent updates, and I believe it deserves that fair chance. The positives here absolutely outweigh any negatives by a wide margin, and for me, it‚Äôs been a revitalising journey that brings back the best parts of MMO gaming.

New World has changed a great deal since it's open Beta however my review isn't going to be about the dets of all the tech.There are a million videos and reviews out there about that. As a long time gamer, here's my review based on playbility. 

 I've tried each incarnation and it feels like they've finally hit a note that works for both the casuals and the intense. I can play both and have my favorite way to play. I run with a large group of friends and we vary in styles and intensity. New world has finally found a balance for us all so everyone is having a great time, it's easy to play together, and chat while we're all doing our own thing. Will your intense player friends play forever? no. But they'll play for a solid few months and come back regularly for a weekend or three while you casuals can continue tinkering on at your own pace, collecting everything, doing everything, maxing everything when you have the time. THe point is, unlike many MMO's I've played, this one is nice to come back to and now that they've streamlined the basic required MSQ, it's easy to even start from nothing and enjoy the rebuild or save your end game character and pop in to play with your casual friends for some gorgeous dungeons. 

For me, I ignore the people that bitch about the cost. here's how it went. New world launched at full price. when years later it added new areas and mounts along with some other things, they lowered the price of New World to half and charged the same price for the new DLC with new land and mounts etc. it was a fair price given all the years New World had been out. Now it's combined the original and DLC to make one game and completely changed a lot of the game in massive ways so it's full price for both. It all makes sense and people who complain apparently think the world works for years on games for free.  Don't want to pay? By it on sale. 

Last thing I'll add. This game is colorful and bright without being overly cartoony. The weapons and mounts are ridiculously oversized so it's got an air of playfulness about it. It's a refreshing break from the dark dreary landscapes, settings and storylines of depressing impossibleness or anime styles of recent years. All in all. get some mates or find some in game. Most of the player base is now respectful at least if now just down right friendly and helpful. My review bottom line... It's worth it. If you don't bring friends with you, you'll make friendly acquaintances which come in handy in places where another person is helpful or sometimes required. The game does a good job at watching server populations and merging when necessary to keep enough people around to lend a hand and the end game ongoing raids, races, wars, dungeons, incoming assaults from npc's etc, keep the end game fresh because it's always a different group of people you're working with to succeed. 

Most importantly, I continue to see this game expanding and being worked on. Future things are coming and that's nice to look forward to and hang on for. My recommendation is Very Positive.

"New World" is an incredibly engaging MMORPG that stands out from other titles in the genre thanks to its unique blend of mechanics and exceptional visual design. The game transports players to the beautiful, danger-filled world of Aeternum, where you can shape your fate by choosing from a variety of professions, factions, and activities.

Graphics and World: The world of "New World" is incredibly detailed and full of life. From picturesque forests to mysterious ruins, every corner of the map captivates with its design and invites exploration. Beautiful, realistic textures, dynamic weather changes, and the passing of day and night make the game a visual masterpiece. As you travel through Aeternum, you truly feel as if you're in this extraordinary, perilous world.

Gameplay and Combat System: One of the greatest strengths of "New World" is its unique combat system, which blends RPG elements with dynamic, action-based fighting. Players must demonstrate quick reflexes and precise movements, not just rely on stats. This makes every fight‚Äîwhether against monsters or other players‚Äîan exciting challenge. Additionally, the wide range of weapons and combat styles gives players tremendous freedom in shaping their characters and customizing their abilities.

Creativity and Customization: "New World" offers a wide range of customization options for both characters and equipment. Players can develop crafting skills, gather resources, create items, and even decide how their character will evolve. This is a huge advantage, as it allows each player to tailor their gaming experience to their preferences.

Social Interactions: The game places a strong emphasis on cooperation and competition with other players. Factions, PvP, and various in-game events provide players with numerous opportunities for interaction and rivalry. The robust economy based on crafting and trading also fosters strong player communities. Whether you prefer collaboration or competition, "New World" gives you plenty of opportunities to engage.

Challenges and Rewards: The game is full of challenges, from tough monsters to elaborate dungeons and dynamic territory wars. These challenges are well-balanced, and the rewards for overcoming them are satisfying. The game receives regular updates that add new content, ensuring that "New World" remains fresh and continues to offer new challenges for players.

Summary: "New World" is a title that combines elements of classic MMORPGs with modern features, offering players a dynamic, immersive, and diverse gaming experience. If you're looking for a game that features a beautifully designed world, exciting combat, deep character customization, and engaging interactions with other players, "New World" will surely captivate you. With its ongoing updates and development, the game has the potential to stay on your PC for a long time.

This game is so flawed that it would take forever to list all of the reasons not to play, but I quit for one simple reason: you can't set a maximum level for dungeon groups.

When you enter your first dungeon (annoyingly around level 25), you are forced to either look for party members manually, or allow the game to auto-fill your group. If you auto-fill, your party members will almost certainly be much higher level. This makes it nearly impossible to play the content in a normal way, without being carried. Shame on the developers for not adding one simple checkbox to limit the dungeon group level.

Aeternum is my first experience with New World, so my review is based on this version. Also note that for at least 50 hours I've been playing completely solo before joining a company. 

[b]Like:[/b]
- Voice acting is quite enjoyable
- Everything is unlocked in phases so you don't feel overwhelmed with the game mechanics
- Quests are fun to go through (including the side quests). Still not done with questing almost 60 hours into the game
- Story has interesting elements
- Cinematic reels for certain parts of the story (art is really nice in those)
- You're not locked into weapons or classes. You can change up your assigned skill points whenever you want + you can use all weapons. So you can really try out different builds and weapons and see what works for you.
- Leveling your skills has a real purpose behind it and it's not a terrible grindfest to go through
- I've always been a PVE player, never engaged with PVP in games. But in Aeternum the PVP stuff it's actually a lot of fun.
- Music is quite nice also and the sounds effects are great

[b]Dislike:[/b]
- NPC models aren't the most pretty. But honestly it doesn't bother me because the voice acting is good
- The in-game shop is way too expensive for the cosmetics
- The player driven economy is a hit and miss. I get the idea, but I would really like if there was also a NPC store where you could sell stuff.
- There are some wonky elements in the game but nothing game breaking
- There are no mounts of cosmetics you can unlock via expeditions etc

Overall I didn't expect to like the game as much as I'm currently doing. There are flaws in the game, but I can overlook that for the sheer fun factor I'm getting out of it.
Tons of flaws, developers disappoint again and again and again... but there is no better action combat MMORPG and that's the only reason this review is positive.

I started to play Aerturnum for poops and giggles as I'm sick to death of ESO. Aeternums world is beautifully crafted and outright creepy in some areas. The combat mechanics are fairly basic and the quests are short and simple. If you don't want too much of a challenge and just want to chill out for a while, this is a very enjoyable game.

The new player experience is really good and straightforward. Combat is smooth and not complicated, but has a lot of depth. Gathering and sound design is on point chopping a tree, or mining a rock feels realistic sound wise.

As someone who has played many MMORPGs such as WoW, GW/GW2, ESO, Rift, and more, I was excited to try out a new one and dive into a new world (no pun intended), and decided to give this one a go. 

I have just over an hour invested into this game and most of the time has been spent with the servers absolutely imploding on themselves to the point to where it became borderline unplayable and not an enjoyable experience whatsoever. 
It took multiple attempts to even open up the character creator, and everything takes ages to load up.

I haven't even talked about the bugs either. 
Egregious texture pop-ins, rendering glitches, the character creator background being a white screen with black boxes popping in and out while my character is a floating armor set, the map being a bunch of floating icons with no actual map showing, inventory being a blank screen, invisible NPCs, etc.

The first impressions left a very sour taste in my mouth, the game has been out for over 3 years and this is the state of the game?

It's upsetting because the game (when working properly) looks so beautiful, I enjoyed the look of the first settlement in the game and how many of the buildings in it you can own, I like the classes, it has great gameplay mechanics, and I enjoyed the combat. 

This game needs some serious work it seems.
I'll revisit it eventually, but for now I would rather spend my time on something else.

Point positif :
Globalement tr√®s bon sur le contenu PvE. Le gameplay est bon, la progression est fluide et agreable avec une bonne √©volution et gestion de la difficult√©.
Le systeme de m√©tier est riche et beaucoup moins ennuyeux que sur d'autres mmo.
Le housing est pouss√©.

Points n√©gatifs :
Cependant le contenu PvP (chose pour laquelle j'ai achet√© le jeu) est tres tres mauvais. 
Sur le contenu en lui meme : Il y a que deux modes, 20c20 ou 3c3.

Le mode 20c20 ressemble a un bordel sans nom, des barres de vie partout qui rendent les combats difficilement lisibles et surtout un √©quilibrage a la ramasse. Si vous etes un meta slave n'ayez crainte, il vous suffira de choisir la bonne arme et de rouler votre tete sur votre clavier pour venir a bout de vos adversaires les plus talenteux. Pour les autres, bonne chance.

Le TTK est completement diff√©rent d'une arme a l'autre, 3 √† 5 coups de haches ou d'√©pee suffisent a tuer un distance, alors qu'un archer auras besoin de mettre au moins 10 √† 15 fleches pour esperer tuer un joueur corps a corps √† stuff √©quivalent (s'il n'est pas heal). Mais de toutes facons, arriv√© au stade ou vous l'aurez presque tu√©, ce noble joueur partira simplement en courant en zig zag et vous ne le reverrez jamais. La montagne de fun :D

Il y a aussi des tanks ... litteralement intuables, comptez 2-3 bonnes minutes en 6v1 pour esperer pouvoir le deloger du point de capture, voir plus s'il exploite corretement la m√©canique du bouclier et de la recharge de vitali√© et s'il n'est pas heal ... Si jamais un heal arrive au moment ou vous etiez sur le point de le tuer c'est reparti pour 5 minutes, car la ou vous avez pass√© une √©ternit√© √† lui enlever sa vie, il ne faut qu'une ou deux secondes au healer pour le remettre en plein forme, la montagne de fun :D 

Si vous avez √©t√© attir√© par le gameplay au premier abord, je vous suggere de ne pas vous fier aux apparences, car les nombreux effets de controle rendront vos esquive parfaitement inn√©fficaces voir impossibles. La montagne de fun :D
Et tout ceci couronn√© d'un match making inexistant qui donne des partie si d√©s√©quilibr√©es en terme de composition qu'une des deux equipes au moins une fois sur 5 ne peut meme pas sortir du spawn. 

Ensuite la 3v3. Pour le coup le mode ar√®ne est bien mais il vous faudra passer 5 minutes en file d'attente pour un match qui en dure a peine 2 .. rien de plus a ajouter. 

Et pour finir l'open pvp. N'esperez pas pouvoir y prrendre part avant au moins 150 √† 200h de jeu tant l'√©cart entre un joueur stuff ou non est immense. Vous ne pourrez y participer qu'apres avoir farmer vos items best in slot. MAIS, si comme moi vous avez innoncement fait le choix d'un build qui avait l'air de vous plaire sans vous soucier de la meta, c'est reparti pour des dixaines d'heures de farm :D. 
Car en effet, certaines classes sont tellement inutiles que les guildes ne prennent tout simplement pas ces classes dans les groupes pour participer aux guerres du monde ouvert.. 

Et cerise sur le gateaux, les grosse guildes des serveurs s'organisent en mafia en s'arrangeant pour se distribuer et conserver les territoires afin de conserver les benefices qu'elles en tirent. Ce qui donne des guerres d'influences quasiment d√©sertes. 

En r√©sum√©, je peux le conseiller pour des joueurs PvE occasionnels, les fan de housing et les gens qui aiment les metiers dans les mmo. 

Pour les autres il n'en vaut a mon sens pas la peine. Il n'y a qu'un seul raid vraiment exigeant √† 20 joueurs. 
Et pour les joueurs PvP qui cherchent un jeu pour s'amuser √† travers la maitrise des m√©caniques il n'y a ce stade aucun interet. 

Le jeu a quand meme du potentiel donc a voir dans un an.
